Shingwauk Home
Anglican Indian Residential School

Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario
Dec. 14, 1931

EXD.

Dear Sir:

I enclose herewith three small accounts from Lawrence Limited, Druggists. These are in duplicate and duly O.K.d by the medical doctor.

One of the accounts, for the month of August, was, in some way overlooked, but is herewith enclosed. The three accounts total £19.40.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]
Principal.

Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Shingwauk Home
Anglican Indian Residential School

Sault Ste. Marie, Feb. 17, 1932

Dear Sir:

I enclose herewith account in duplicate from Lawrence Limited to the amount of $12.40 for drugs I have had to get per doctor's orders during the months of December and January. The account is duly certified correct by Doctor McCaig and myself.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]
Principal.

Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Mar. 15th, 1932

ACCOUNTANTS
MAR 22 1932
BRANCH

Dear Sir:

The enclosed account is for drugs I have had to get during the month of February for our school by order of the doctor. The amount is for $5.50, and duly certified by Doctor McCaig.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Principal.

Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6214, file 469-13, part 1)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Dear Sir:

The enclosed account from Lawrence Limited, to the amount of $4.85 represents drugs I have had to buy for our pupils during the month of March. The account is in duplicate and duly O.K.'d by Doctor McGaig. Will the Department kindly pay this account.

Your obedient servant,

Chas F. Hume
Principal

Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
May 10th, 1938.

Reverend Sir,

The Department is receiving many accounts for small purchases of drugs for the pupils of your school. Most of the items can be supplied by the Department through the Department of Pensions and National Health at very much less cost. Kindly have a requisition prepared in accordance with the instructions contained in Drug List No. 3 and endeavour to make it sufficiently complete to supply all your needs.

Yours truly,

A.F. MacKenzie
Secretary

Rev. Charles F. Hives,
Principal,
Shingwauk Home,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.
Dear Sir:

I am sorry to have to present the enclosed small account from Lawrence Limited for drugs I have had to procure for some of our pupils by order of the doctor. I may say that we have had one or two illnesses that have required special treatment, and as we had not the drugs required in stock, I had to get it from the drug store. I am now making up a requisition for drugs, and will try and dispense with the purchasing of drugs from local store.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Principal

Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Dear Sir:

I beg to report that all pupils of our school have been vaccinated during the year, and that all pupils who are receiving their discharge have recently been revaccinated.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Principal

Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES  
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES  
CANADA
DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

OTTAWA, July 6th, 1932.

Dear Sir,

I have to request you to furnish on repayment and send by freight prepaid to destination the supplies mentioned in the attached list. The supplies are intended for the use of Indians at the Indian Residential School in the Garden River agency, and should be addressed as follows:

Rev. Chas. F. Hives,
Principal, Shingwauk Home,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.

Payment will be made by this Department on receipt of your account in triplicate.

Yours truly,

F. H. Jaget,
Chief Accountant & Purchasing Agent,
Director of Medical Stores,
Department Pensions & National Health,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

I enclose herewith an account from the Lawrence Limited, Druggists, for medicines amounting to $18.50. This account is OK'd by Dr. McCaig.

Will you kindly pay this account.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

We are just recovering from an epidemic of Whooping cough, and have landed into a dose of Chicken Pox. At present we have about twenty cases. Will you kindly have sent to us as soon as possible, two gallons of Lysol, thirty pounds of Epsom salts, two gross of disinfectant soap, and nine hot water bottles.

I would be very much obliged if you would have these forwarded at the earliest possible.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]
Principal.

Doctor Stone,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Attention Doctor Stone

Dear Sir:

I am sorry to have to bother you again, but there are three items I neglected including in my requisition for medical supplies, and which we require very urgently.

- Bed rubber sheeting. -60 yds. 3 rolls
- Disinfectant soap 6 gross
- One set of scales for weighing the pupils.

In regard to the first item, I am sorry to say that we have the worst lot of bed wetters I have ever experienced, and if you can give me some advice as to how to handle such a situation, I'd be very grateful.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Principal.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6214, file 469-13, part 2)
January 30th, 1936

Dear Sir:

The account of the Shingwauk Indian Residential School for drugs purchased locally in the month of December comes to $23.19, and contains a number of items included in the Department's Drug List. It is true that school principals have been asked to restrict their orders to one per annum recently, but the regulation has not been very closely adhered to; in fact, there was an order supplied to this school in the month of November. The Department is not desirous of entirely abolishing local purchases, but thinks they should be reasonably restricted to supplies required by the doctor and not available from the Drug List.

Yours very truly,

A. F. MacKenzie
Secretary

G.H. Sims, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie,
Ont.

RBK
E. L. Stone, Esq., M.D.
Director Medical Services,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

I beg to report that we have had an outbreak of Scarlet Fever in the Shingwauk Home. The first case occurred about the middle of December and since that time we have had six cases. We are taking care of the patients in the City's isolation hospital and have the Home under quarantine.

At the outset I gave all the children the prophylactic dose of toxoid and have begun their permanent immunization. We hope to soon have the trouble cleaned up.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6214, file 469-13, part 2)
February 17, 1936

Sir:

Doctor McCaig has reported an outbreak of scarlet fever in the Shingwauk Residential School, dating from the middle of December. I may be mistaken, but this appears to be the first notice the Department has had of this outbreak. I have to quote to you the Department's instructions that a communicable disease should be reported by telegraph, within 12 hours of its discovery.

The Department has no doubt, whatever, that you and Doctor McCaig and the principal of the school are taking good care of the sick children.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie
Secretary

G. H. Sime Esq.
Indian Agent
Sault St. Marie, Ont.

MP

Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.

Dear Sir:

We have in the Shingwauk Home a young Indian girl who is suffering with active pulmonary tuberculosis and who is just now recovering from a very severe pulmonary hemorrhage.

She is not a suitable case for residence in the School and would have a chance of recovery if placed in a sanitarium.

Will you kindly take the matter up with the Department and see if she could be removed to one of the Ontario sanitaria.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Dear Sir:

Quite a number of our pupils are having trouble with their teeth, which should be attended to at once. Will you kindly let me know your wishes in this matter.

Is it possible that Doctor Stone is intending to pay us a visit in the near future. If so, I suppose he could look into the matter while he is here.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Principal.

Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
June 11th, 1936

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of June 8th regarding dental attention required by pupils of Shingwauk Residential School. I should like to know how many pupils require this service, and whether it could be arranged to hold a one day clinic at the school. We have found this to be much more satisfactory than taking pupils in groups to the office of the dentist. When a clinic is arranged in a residential school as many as from thirty to forty pupils receive attention, whereas usually not more than twenty can be dealt with in the office of the dentist. This may be because members of the staff usually assist the dentist in looking after the pupils treated and those awaiting treatment.

If, on receipt of your reply, it is found possible to authorize a clinic, Doctors J. A. and G. L. Shannon will be instructed to make the necessary arrangements with you through Mr. Sims, who has received a copy of this letter.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Reverend C. F. Hives,
Principal
Shingwauk Indian Residential School,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.

A. F. MacKenzie
Secretary

SHINGWAUK INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL
SAULT STE. MARIE, ONT.

June 20, 1936.

attention Doctor Stone

Dear Sir:

Doctor McCaig informed me that he was writing you today regarding one of our girls who requires goitre attention. For your information, I would like to say that this girl is very anxious to enter a School of Nursing this fall. She is in good standing educationally, but before she is accepted, she will require to have her goitre trouble attended to. She is a splendid girl in every way, and I would very much like to see her enter the School of Nursing this year.

Yours faithfully,

Chas. F. Hives
Principal.

Secretary,
Department of Indian affairs,
Ottawa.
Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter No. 13-0-53 of the 11th inst., relative to dental work in our school, I beg to say that I have had a survey made of the pupils' teeth by the Drs. Shannon, and from the findings shown in the enclosed, there are 206 cavities and 17 extractions.

The doctors thought it would be very much more convenient for them to have the children taken to their surgery. But of course, it would be more convenient for us if a clinic could be arranged here. They seemed to think it would be necessary to have a proper chair and engine.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]
Principal.

Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Copies sent to Dr. McCaig
and Rev. C. F. Hives

June 27th, 1936

Dear Sir:

Letters have been received from Doctor McCaig and Mr. Hives regarding some Indian girl who is in Shingwauk Indian Residential School and who has been anxious to enter a school of nursing. It seems her application has been held up on account of the fact that she has a goitre. There is, apparently, nothing urgent about this case except that the girl wishes to go in training. Doctor McCaig does not actually recommend this operation and as Doctor Stone is at present in the West, I think the matter will have to be left until he returns.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie
Secretary

G. H. Sims, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.

LM
June 27th, 1936

Dear Sir:

With reference to our letter of June 11th to Reverend C. F. Hives regarding a possible dental clinic to be held at the school, Mr. Hives has, apparently, called in Doctor Shannon to examine all the children. This in itself may have involved the Department in considerable expense and it was not intended that Mr. Hives should do this. In other schools the teachers examine the children and merely report the number requiring dental attention. Then when the clinic is authorized the teachers send into the room used by the dentist, those pupils most urgently in need of attention. I am returning the slips sent to the Department by Mr. Hives as they are of no use to us.

If Doctors J. A. and C. L. Shannon wish to undertake dental work for Shingwauk School this work will have to be carried out as desired by the Department. We find that much better results are obtained when the dentist goes to the school and the children are handled by the school staff quickly and without loss of time. In many instances an old barber's chair has been rented at small cost and the dentist brings a foot drill and other necessary equipment. $30.00 is allowed for an eight hour day and from thirty to forty pupils can receive attention.

If a clinic such as this can be arranged the Department is willing to authorize two days, it being understood

G. H. Sims, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.
that the dentist provides his own material for fillings, etc., and the cost of the two day clinic will be $60.00.

I think you would do well to explain to Mr. Hives that the Department has no funds available to undertake this dental work in the way he appears to feel it should be done. If the most urgent cases receive attention at this clinic and regular clinics are held, the condition of the teeth of the pupils will vastly improve within the next few years.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie
Secretary

of Shingwauk School.

Ottawa, April 9th, 1937.

Dear Sir,

Reverend Chas. F. Hives, Principal of the Shingwauk Indian Residential School, has included in his recent drug order a request to be supplied with Goltro Tablets. He asks for 4000 and, while the Department does not question the need for this quantity, it nevertheless is of the opinion that it should bear the endorsement of the attending physician. These tablets are not carried in stock by Central Medical Stores and they will have to be purchased on your instruction from approved source locally. When submitting an account for payment, reference should be made to the date and file number of this letter.

Yours truly,

M. Christiansen,
Acting Secretary.

G. H. Sims, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario.

Feb. 3, 1938

Dear Sir:

I enclose herewith account for drugs etc., from Lawrence Drug Store. The quinine tablets were authorized by the Department. The fumigating lamps had to be used after our epidemic of measles and whooping cough last December, and the other articles were bought on recommendation of the doctor during illness of children.

We had quite an amount of illness during the months of November and December, and we were unfortunate in losing three of our pupils during that illness.

Will you kindly forward the enclosed to the Department for payment.

Yours faithfully,

Chas. F. Hives
Principal.

Indian Agent,
Ottawa.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Dear Sir:

In reply to your inquiry regarding pupil No. 6263 Kathleen Stock, who is subject to epileptic fits, and who has been recommended by Doctor McCaig to be transferred to an institution where she can be given proper care and treatment. I hope this may be done in the near future, for these fits are becoming more frequent and much more severe, and I don't think it is good for the rest of the girls to have her here. In fact, I think it is harmful. She had one yesterday in the diningroom while the pupils were at dinner, and it was very severe, and tends to upset the children very much.

I would be glad if the matter could be taken up as soon as possible, and the girl transferred to proper care and treatment.

Yours faithfully,

Chas. F. Rivers
Principal.

G. H. Sims Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.
Dr. A.S. McCaig  
Queen Street  
Sault Ste. Marie,  
Ontario  

Jan. 5th, 1939.

C. H. Sims, Esq.,  
Indian Agent,  
Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Kathleen Stock, a 14 year girl at the Shingwauk Home is a subject of epilepsy. Her attacks are becoming more frequent and more severe. She should be admitted to the Ontario Hospital at Woodstock. Will you kindly take the matter up with the Department.

Yours truly,

A.S. McCaig
Sir:

With reference to the enclosed letters re Kathleen Stock of Shingwauk Home, I beg to say that I have made careful inquiries into this matter, and would recommend that action be taken as soon as possible to have this pupil transferred to an institution where she can receive proper treatment and care.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent,

Dr. E.L. Stone,
Supt. of Medicinal Services,
Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.
January 25, 1939.

Dear Sir:

Reference: Your Letter, January 10th - Kathleen Stock, Shingwauk Indian Residential School.

The Department is prepared to pay the maintenance of this girl at the Ontario Hospital at Woodstock or any other Provincial institute if she is properly certified by doctors at Sault Ste. Marie and admitted in accordance with the provincial law.

If these conditions can be met, you are at liberty to have her removed to the Ontario Hospital, and may make any reasonable expenditure for travelling, clothing, and so forth.

As she is not, properly speaking, a case of mental disease, it is thought that her guardians, if she has any, should be consulted.

Yours truly,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Secretary.

G. H. Sims, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
SAULT STE. MARIE, Ont.

SHINGWAUK INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL
SAULT STE. MARIE, ONT.

Feb. 8, 1939

Dear Doctor Stone:

The enclosed bill from Lawrence Drug Store, is for medicines we have had to get by doctor's order from time to time, with the exception of the citre tablets, which you sanctioned.

At present we have a few cases of Chicken Pox, but nothing of serious nature. I am taking the epileptic down to the Ontario Hospital today.

Yours faithfully,

Chas F. Hives
Principal.

Doctor E.L. Stone,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.
Dear Doctor Stone:

I would like to recommend something to you regarding the visits of the Doctor to our school. Now that a new man is on the job, I wonder if it would not be a very good idea to have a doctor's log book, which he will have to report in and sign. The doctor's visit heretofore have been quite irregular and more or less haphazard excepting when he is called to a case. This is an important work, and well worth doing.

If the idea appeals to you, I would be very much obliged if you would send a Log book along with necessary instructions. The Head Matron, who is a registered nurse, can have charge of it, and in the event of any illness it will be recorded there in case you should want it at anytime.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]
Principal.

Doctor E.L. Stone,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.
March 29, 1939.

Ex. D.

Reverend Sir:

Answering your letter of March 3 to Doctor Stone, I agree that it would be a good idea to have a doctor's log book.

You may discuss this with Doctor Heath, and we will forward you a book which may be used for that purpose. A summary of the entries in the book could be forwarded to the Department quarterly.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

P. E. Moore, M.D.,
Assistant Superintendent
of Medical Services.

Reverend C. F. Hives,
Principal,
Shingwauk Indian Residential School,
SAULT STE. MARIE, Ontario.

N.H.
SHINGWAUK INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL
SAULT STE. MARIE, ONT.

REV. C.F. HIVES,
PRINCIPAL

June 23, 1939

Dear Doctor Stone:

Dr. N.F. Graham, who is at the head of the Provincial Health Lab. of this city has offered to come down to our school and apply the Wasserman Blood test to our pupils, and in case of any syphilitic children he would treat them. He has offered to do this free of charge.

I have known Dr. Graham for twenty five years, and know him to be safe and competent, and would have no hesitation in recommending that he proceed with this business if it meets with your approval.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]
Principal.

Dr. E.B. Stone,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
June 23, 1939.

EXD.

Reverend Sir:

The Department is in receipt of your letter of June 23, addressed to Doctor Stone, with regard to taking blood tests on the children.

The Department has no objection to this procedure being carried out, but it is a matter that you should discuss with the Indian Agent and regular doctor in attendance at the school. If they are agreeable, the Department, as stated before, will have no objection to Doctor Graham carrying out the procedure.

Yours truly,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Secretary.

Reverend C. F. Hives,
Principal,
Shingwauk Indian Residential School,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario.

Feb. 6, 1940

Dear Dr. Stone:

I have to report to you the news of an outbreak of measles at our school. So far, we have two, and these are isolated, but the chances are we shall have more as time goes on. There are over four hundred cases reported in town, and goodness know how many unreported cases are at large, so we have done well to escape as long as we have.

Should there be anything serious, I will let you know immediately.

Yours faithfully,

Chas. F. Hiver
Principal.

Dr. E.L. Stone,
Dept. Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your recent drug requisition the Department wishes to draw your attention to the fact that it does not consider it necessary for the children to have Cod Liver Oil during the summer months. Unless you have special facilities for storing the oil it becomes rancid and unfit for use. For this reason it will not be shipped until early in the fall after the beginning of the school term.

What appears to be an unusually large amount of Epsom Salts has been asked for in the last two requisitions. Is there any particular reason for the amounts requisitioned.

Yours truly,

T. R. L. MacInnes
Secretary

Rev. Chas. F. Hives,

Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6214, file 469-13, part 2)
SHINGWAUK INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL
SAULT STE. MARIE, ONT.

REV. C. F. HIVES,
PRINCIPAL

June 5, 1940

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of the 30th ult., No. I3-0-I3, I beg to say regarding the Epsom Salts requisitioned for our school that we really require the amount asked for. We have 135 pupils in school, and have found out, through long experience, that Epsom Salts are the best and cheapest medicine that can be procured. Indian children are subject to all kings of skin troubles. I assure you, if we had not Epsom Salts to give them, at such times, we would not be able to keep them so free of disease as they are.

We really need the amount requisitioned, and would be very much obliged if you would kindly send us that amount.

Yours faithfully,

Chas. L. Hives
Principal.

Mr T.R.L. MacInnes,
Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

SHINGWAUK INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL
SAULT STE. MARIE, ONT.

Oct. 7, 1940

Dear Sir:

Will you kindly let me know the wishes of the Department regarding dental work on the teeth of the pupils of our school. Some of the pupils require immediate attention; especially some who have just been admitted; and others require to be looked after. Unless this is done regularly, there is great danger of the health of the pupils being impaired, quite a bit of unnecessary suffering, and in the end a large bill to pay.

I had to send a pupil to the dentist for an extraction two months ago. This was an emergency case, as the child was suffering. The dentist informs me his bill for $1.50 for this item was refused payment by the Department. We have several children now, whose teeth are really giving them pain.

Also in regard to eyes attention. Will you kindly let me know your wishes regarding the buying of spectacles when found necessary.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]
Principal.

Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

The Deputy Minister.

About a week ago the Indian Affairs Branch asked for the name of a dentist to take charge of a two-day clinic at the Indian Residential School, Sault Ste. Marie. Dr. George Shannon, Jr., of Sault Ste. Marie might be engaged for this work.

Dr. McGill -
To note.
October 25, 1940.

EX'D.

Dear Sir:

This is your authority to engage Dr. George Shannon, Jr., of Sault Ste. Marie, to do the dental work required at the Shingwauk Indian Residential School at the usual rate of $30.00 a day including expenses. This authorization is for not more than two days' work.

The Department is in receipt of a letter from the Reverend Mr. Hives in which he states that he sent a child to the dentist suffering from a toothache. The dentist later told him that he had not been paid for this work. We would like to know the circumstances of this if you can give us any information.

Mr. Hives also asks about having the children's eyes tested for spectacles when it is deemed necessary. A recent circular states that such authorization must be obtained from Ottawa. If the Principal will write to the Department regarding individual cases, he will be instructed what to do regarding them.

Yours truly,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Secretary.

Re P. G. Laurence, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
SAULT STE. MARIE, Ont.

N.N.

Dear Sir:

I have to report an epidemic of Flu in our school. This morning there were seventy four confined to bed, but I am glad to say we have no serious cases, and trust it will pass off within a few days.

Yours faithfully,

Chas. F. Hines

Sault Ste Marie Agency
For the Month of January, 1941.

Dear Sir,

The general health of the Indians has been good during the month, with the exception of the Shingwauk Residential School, where an epidemic of influenza (mild) is now in progress.

Mr. R. Lawrence,

SAULT STE. MARIE, Ont.

Dear Mr. Lawrence:

There are about 25 children at the Shingwauk School who have small cavities in their teeth requiring simple fillings. I think it would be good business to have these small cavities cared for in time if such meets with the approval of the Department at the present time.

Would you please take the matter up with the Department and let me know their wish in this regard.

Yours truly,

T. R. Heath, M.D.

CANADA
REPORT ON INSPECTION TRIP TO AGENCIES OF GEORGIAN BAY AREA.

Monday morning the Shingwauk School was visited. This is a fine, modern building and would be well suited as a sanatorium for the part of the Province. It is a central point for the Muskoka Lake Sands, the Western Bands as far as Sioux Lookout and the Reserves as far East as North Bay, and North to Charpleau and Moose Factory. Little change would seem necessary to make this building a modern sanatorium.

At the time of my visit as to this school sixteen children were sick with whooping cough. The school children appeared clean and otherwise healthy and the institution well managed.

W.L. Falconer, M.D.
Assistant Superintendent of Medical Services.

**CANADA**
Dear Sir or Madam,

Please note that future drug requisitions must give the amount of all drugs on hand each time you submit a requisition, otherwise, no action will be taken except to return it to you for further particulars. This, also, will apply to requisitions on which are not clearly marked the number of Indians to be served. Space has been provided for this information on the drug order form.

It should also be noted that freezable items should not be ordered during cold weather, nor is it economical to submit an order that cannot be sent by mail or freight. One hundred pounds is the minimum on which freight has to be paid and fifteen pounds the maximum of non-liquids that can be sent by mail. I must ask you, therefore, to bear these facts in mind when ordering drugs.

Efforts should be made to gain the cooperation of Indians in the matter of returning empty bottles, after thoroughly washing them, when more medicine is required.

I would suggest that this Circular be attached to your Departmental drug list for future reference.

Yours truly,

P. E. Moore, M.D., D.P.H.
Acting Superintendent of Medical Services.

CANADA
August 31st, 1943.

I have your letter of August 26th, reporting non-receipt of certain drugs. The Freight Arrival Notice, enclosed with your letter, indicates that the shipment comprised nine cartons or pieces and, before the matter is brought to the attention of Central Medical Stores, I would appreciate being advised as to how many pieces were received by you. This information is necessary in order that a proper check-up can be made at the source of supply.

W. L. Falconer, M.D.
A/Assist. Supt. Medical Services.

Rev. A. H. Minchin,
Principal,
Shingwauk Indian Residential School,
Sault. Ste. Marie, Ontario.

Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir,

The final paragraph in my letter of Aug. 26 stated that the three cartons of Medical Supplies and the six cartons of Fish Oil tins were received intact. We received in all nine pieces as shown on the Freight arrival notice.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Principal.

6 lbs. Ung.Amoniated Mercury.

Yours very truly,

Principal.

Ottawa, Ont. Sept 29th 1943

P.J. Bernard;-

I am enclosing herewith copy of original Bill of Lading and also invoice showing cost of goods missing in shipment.

You will note that it has been very simple to correct this shipment due to the fact that weigh bill was returned by Indian Agent thus we were able to trace where discrepancies originated. I hope that in future all shortages will be reported in this way, it will save a lot of valuable time.

L. Bell

Indian Affairs. (FG 10, Volume 6214, file 469-13, part 2)
October 1st, 1943.

EX'D.

Your letter of August 26th, with enclosures, was transferred to Central Medical Stores for a check up and we are now informed that the shipment in question comprised 11 packages in all. Your acknowledgment of having received 9 pieces indicates that 2 are missing and which probably contained the articles you did not receive. If these have not yet turned up, will you please advise this office in order that a claim may be made against the railway. Please state also if you desire that these be replaced.

W. L. Fletcher, M.D.
A/Assist. Supt. of Medical Services.

Rev. A. Z. Minchin, B.A.
Principal,
Shingwauk Indian Residential School,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6214, file 469-13, part 2)
October 2, 1943

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Letter signed by Dr. Falconer, dated Oct. 1st, just received.

The C.P.R. Freight here has two packages for which no bill of lading has been received. I told them that we were short on a consignment of drugs and understood that they were making enquiries. This was more than a week ago. We need the supplies some of them urgently. We are out of Ung. Ammoniated Mercury and Ung. Zinc Oxide.

May I suggest that the matter be taken up with the C.P.R. from your end as it is evident that some error was made in shipping. I have no shipping notice and no shipping notice has arrived at the local office. Apparently delivery cannot be made without the necessary bills of lading.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Principal.

Attention of Dr. W.L. Falconer,
Assist. Super of Medical Services.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6214, file 469-13, part 2)
October 5th, 1943.

EX'D.

The matter of your letter of October 2nd, was taken up with the Canadian Pacific Railways here and their Sault Ste. Marie agent is being instructed by wire today to release to you two packages of freight for which he has no bill-of-lading. The Company admitted having made the mistake by quoting the wrong number of pieces in the shipment when the bill-of-lading was made out in Ottawa. It is hoped that your difficulties will now be straightened out.

[Signature]

Rev. A. E. Minchin, B.A.
Principal,
Shingwauk Ind. Res. School,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6214, file 469-13, part 2)
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

Rev. A.H. Minchin, Principal of the Shingwauk Indian Residential School, informs me that there are seven children whose eyes should be examined, as they have difficulty in seeing the blackboard work in the classrooms.

Kindly grant permission for these examinations to be made.

The Principal also reports that about sixty children need their teeth attended to. There has not been any work done on the children's teeth since August, 1942. It is not possible at the present time, due to the shortage of dentists, in Sault Ste. Marie, to hold a dental clinic at the School, but where attention is really necessary the children could be brought to the dentist, a few at a time, for the necessary attention.

Kindly advise me if it will be in order to have attention given where it is really necessary.

R.P.G. Laurence,
Indian Agent.
December 22, 1943

The children who require eye examinations in the residential school should have this procedure carried out and the prescriptions forwarded here so that glasses can be supplied.

Would it be possible to get a dentist from Espanola to visit Shingwauk Home? If so, you may make the necessary arrangements, otherwise urgent cases can be taken to the dentist.

P. E. Moore, M.D., D.P.H.
Acting Superintendent of Medical Services

R. P. G. Laurence, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie,
Ont.

LM
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

Consolidated Optical Company Ltd.
104 Sparks Street,
Ottawa, Can.

Dear Sir,

Please supply, at the expense of this Department, spectacles in accordance with the enclosed prescription and the following specifications:

Lenses - equal to Consolidated Optical Company "GENEX."

Frame - strong metal, full frame, cable ear fittings, rocking pearl nose pads, equal to Consolidated Optical Company "ROBIN HOOD" Catalogue No. 3678.

Send these spectacles by the most economical method to the following address:

Medical Services Division, Booth Bldg., Ottawa.

For: As per prescriptions for children attending Shingwauk Indian Residential School.

The account must show the prices charged for lenses and frame separately, eye examination if any, and be sent in DUPLICATE at the same time to the above address. Patient's name should also appear on the face of the account as well as on the envelope containing the spectacles as a precaution against issuing them to the wrong person particularly when more than one order is placed at the same time from the same Agency.

No vendor is authorized to supply more costly frames for an Indian, either at the Department's or the Indian's expense, or on the Indian's promise to pay the balance, or to accept any payment or deposit on these spectacles from any person other than an Indian Agent or recognized representative of the Department.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

A/Assist. Medical Services.

Aug. 17, 1944.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

Re.- Drug Requisition.

All drugs received last month in good order with the following exceptions:

- No Sodium Iodide.
- No Lysol.
- No Carbolic Soap.

I am enclosing voucher and you will note that the following is written in below the list of supplies:-

"I only 5 lb. tin. I only."

Miss Hahn thinks that this probably referred to Sodium Iodide but was not included.

I should have written about this matter sooner but I was on holiday when the supplies arrived.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Principal.
Ottawa, August 21st, 1944,

In reply to your letter of August 17th, I wish to advise that the Sodium Iodide Powder was not sent because it is not stocked by Central Medical Stores. Sodium Iodide Tablets, grains 1, however, are available and these can be sent if satisfactory. Lysol and Carbolic Soap are no longer supplied to Residential Schools. The "I only 5 lb. tin" mentioned is an empty container which was used to enclose supplies usually broken down from bulk and have not their original tins.

W. L. Falconer, M.D.,
A/Assist. Cupt. of Medical Services.

Rev. A. H. Minchin,
Principal,
Shingwauk Indian Residential School,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.

PJB
SHINGWAUK INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL
SAULT STE. MARIE, ONT.

REV. A. E. MINCHIN, B.A., L.Th.
PRINCIPAL

September 20, 1944

Mr. R.P.G. Laurence,
Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie,
Ont.

Dear Sir:

The Matron informs me that there are several children who should have their eyes tested. The teachers find that these children have difficulty in seeing the blackboard.

Would you be good enough to request permission from the Department to have at least 6 children examined with a view to having spectacles provided if found necessary.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Principal.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

You will please find enclosed herewith letter received from the Principal of the Shingwauk Indian Residential School which is self-explanatory.

Kindly advise if it will be in order to have the six children's eyes examined.

RPGI/MY

R. F. G. Laurence,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, Ontario
September 26, 1944

You may arrange to have the six children of Shingwauk School examined for glasses. Prescription including measurement of frames as well as strength of lens should be forwarded to this office to be filled.

W. L. Falconer, M.D.
Acting Assistant Supt. of Medical Services

R. P. G. Laurence, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie,
Ont.

LM
October 17, 1944

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept.of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Re- Drug Requisition.

With further reference to my letter of August 17th and reply of August 21st signed by W.L. Falconer, M.D., we should be glad Sodium Iodide Tablets instead of Sodium Iodide Powder. I think the original intention was to ask for Sodium Iodide Tablets on the Requisition dated June 21st, 1944.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Principal.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6214, file 469-13, part 2)
Ottawa, October 24th, 1946.

I have your letter of the 20th instant, with prescriptions for glasses for children attending the Shingwauk Indian Residential School. Of the nine children apparently examined, orders for glasses are being placed for seven and these will be forwarded when completed. It is observed that "No change in glasses" is written on two of these prescriptions and no frame measurements have been given. They are for Lila Greenberg and Christina Butterfly; consequently, no action has been taken. Presumably, they have eye glasses and require no change at the present time.

[Signature]

W. L. Pulcomer, M.D.
A/Assist. Supt. Medical Services.

H. P. O. Lawrence, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario.

November 13, 1944

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Depart.of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

On Friday last, Nov. 10th., Mr. Laurence, Indian Agent, received a number of pairs of spectacles for pupils of this school. These spectacles arrived in a parcel without cases to protect them. The enclosed pair had one lens broken when received. Mr. Laurence is away for this week so thought it might hasten matters if I notified you at once. Personally I consider it fortunate that there were not more of the spectacles damaged in view of the way they were packed.

On previous occasions when spectacles have been supplied, cases of some kind have been sent with them. I think this is necessary for the protection of the spectacles when not in use.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Principal.
Consolidated Optical Company Ltd.
104 Sparks Street,
Ottawa, Can.

Dear Sir,

Glasses for lens replacement will arrive under separate cover.

Please supply, at the expense of this Department, spectacles in accordance with the enclosed prescription and the following specifications:

(royalty only) Lenses - equal to Consolidated Optical Company "CENTEX."

Frame - strong metal, full frame, cable ear fittings, matching pearl nose pads, equal to Consolidated Optical Company "ROBIN HOOD" Catalogue No. 3678.

Send these spectacles by the most economical method to the following address:

Medical Services Division, Booth Bldg., Ottawa.

For: Abraham Mitchell - Sault Ste. Marie Agency.

The account must show the prices charged for lenses and frame separately, eye examination if any, and be sent in duplicate at the same time to the above address. Patient's name should also appear on the face of the account as well as on the envelope containing the spectacles as a precaution against issuing them to the wrong person particularly when more than one order is placed at the same time from the same Agency.

No vendor is authorized to supply more costly frames for an Indian, either at the Department's or the Indian's expense, or on the Indian's promise to pay the balance, or to accept any payment or deposit on these spectacles from any person other than an Indian Agent or recognized representative of the Department.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Ottawa, November 30th, 1944.

I have your letter of November 13th and a pair of glasses for Abraham Mitchell, one of the pupils, which you report were received in a broken condition. Replacement of the broken lens has now been made and the glasses returned to you.

For your information, I should like to point out that the usual spectacle cases were not available when the seven pairs of glasses were sent to Indian Agent Laurence. We are also not very well equipped with packing material, consequently, we have to make the best of what we have. About three months ago, an order was placed for spectacle cases but, to date, we have been unable to get any action on it. This is probably due to the fact that material for their manufacture is still scarce.

W. L. Falconer, M.D.
A/Assist. Supt. of Medical Services.

Rev. A. E. Minchin,
Principal,
Shingwauk Indian Residential School,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario.

January 2nd, 1946.

Indian Affairs Branch Department of Mines and Resources.

Cannon A.E. Minchin principal of the Shingwauk Indian Residential School has requested permission to have 6 children's eyes tested and 6 children's eyes re-tested for eyeglasses.

Kindly advise if it will be in order to have this work done.

R.P.G. Laurence,
Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie Ontario.
Ottawa, January 8th, 1946.

You may authorize Gunner A. E. Minchin, Principal of the Shingwauk Indian Residential School, to proceed with the eye examination of six pupils and the re-examination of six others. If any of these children require eye-glasses, you may forward the prescriptions complete with frame measurements to this office for filling. Reference your letter of January 2nd, 1946.

W. L. Falconer, M.D.
Assistant Superintendent,
Indian Health Service.

R. P. G. Laurence, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario.

SHINGWAUK INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL
SAULT STE. MARIE, ONT.

March 1, 1946.

Mr. R.P.G. Laurence,
Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie.

Dear Mr. Laurence:

For the past two or three years, through the shortage of dentists, it has been impossible to have anything done for the children's teeth except urgent extractions. Dr. Shannon, who has generally attended to the children's teeth is still very busy and I am wondering whether the Department would be willing to have some dental work done by one of the other dentists. There are one or two who have recently set up offices in the city who might be able to handle the job. This matter is very urgent as a great many of the children need attention, and it is a shame that good teeth should be allowed to deteriorate until extraction is the only remedy. I should be glad if you would be kind enough to bring this matter to the attention of the Department.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Principal.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

You will please find letter received from the Principal of the Shingwauk Indian Residential School which is self-explanatory.

As Dr. Shannon is too busy to take care of this work, kindly advise if it will be in order to try and arrange to have some other dentist do this work as suggested by Mr. Minchin.

RPG/LMY

R. P. G. Laurence,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, Ontario.
March 12, 1946.

I wish to acknowledge your letter of March 4th with enclosure from the Principal of the Shingwauk Indian Residential School, Rev. A.A. Minchin.

It will be in order for you to arrange to have the dental work done at the school by any other qualified dentist if Dr. Shannon is unable to do the work. As you know, we allow $30.00 a day for this work. Neither your letter nor Rev. Minchin's mentioned the number of days that will be required nor the number of pupils concerned. We would like an estimate on this as soon as possible.

In the meantime, I think you should go ahead and try and have at least some of the work done before the end of March so it can be paid from current appropriations.

W.L. Falconer, M.D.,
Actg. A/Supt., Indian Health Services.

P.F.G. Laurence, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.

April 5th, 1946.

INDIAN AFFAIRS BRANCH DEPARTMENT OF MINES AND RESOURCES.

I wish to refer to your letter file 13-0-13 dated 12th March 1946, with regard to dental work for the Shingwauk Indian Residential School.

Dr. Goodfellow of Sault Ste. Marie, spent an evening examining the mouths of all children in this school, and finds that the following work is required:

80 Extractions.
230 Fillings.

Like all dentists at this time, Dr. Goodfellow is very busy, but thinks he can get a good portion of the work done during the next three months. Time required will be at least ten days.

R.P.G. Laurence
Indian Agent
Sault Ste. Marie Ontario.

RPGL/gwc
Ottawa, Ontario.
April 13, 1946.

It will be in order to have dental work at the Shingwauk School proceeded with as per your letter of April 5th.

P.S. Moore, M.D., D.P.H.,
Actg. Supt., Indian Health Services.

Indian Agent,

October 24th, 1946.

INDIAN AFFAIRS BRANCH DEPARTMENT OF MINES AND RESOURCES.

The principal of the Shingwauk Indian Residential School has requested permission to have the eyes of twelve children tested for glasses and six whose eyes should be re-tested.

Kindly advise if it will be in order to have these examinations made.

R.P.C. Laurence
Indian Agent
Sault Ste. Marie Ontario.
Ottawa, Ontario.
October 28, 1946.

I wish to acknowledge your letter of October 24 requesting authority to have children examined at the Shingwauk Indian Residential School.

It would appear that there will be 18 eye examinations necessary and you may make arrangements with an eye man to do this at our usual rates. Please arrange though that if glasses are necessary for any of these children, he should issue a prescription giving the lens detail as well as the frame measurements and the prescriptions should be forwarded to this office to be filled.

W.L. Falconer, M.D.,
Actg. A/Supt., Indian Health Services.

R.F.G. Laurence, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.

R.P.G. Laurence

**FRAME** - strong metal, full frame, cable ear fittings, rocking pearl nose pads, equal to Consolidated Optical Company "ROBIN HOOD" Catalogue No. 3678.

Send these spectacles by the most economical method to the following address:

Indian Health Services, Booth Bldg., Ottawa.

For: Leon Fisher, Charles Somay, Lauretta Nahdee, Francis Johnson, Mary Nahdee and Nellie Day - Snult Ste. Marie Agency.

Patient's name should also appear on the face of the account as well as on the envelope containing the spectacles as a precaution against issuing them to the wrong person particularly when more than one order is placed at the same time from the same Agency.

No vendor is authorized to supply more costly frames for an Indian, either at the Department's or the Indian's expense, or on the Indian's promise to pay the balance, or to accept any payment or deposit on these spectacles from any person other than an Indian Agent or recognized representative of the Department.

104 Sparks Street,
Ottawa, Canada.

Ottawa, March 24, 1937.

Dear Sir,

The Department is in receipt of a letter from Reverend Chas. F. Hives, Principal of the Shingwauk Indian Residential School, in which he states that it has been found necessary to destroy the Holstein bull.

Please inform Mr. Hives that the Department has no funds available to replace this animal.

We have no objections to Mr. Hives writing to Rev. H. W. Snell, Principal of the Mohawk Institute, with a view to securing a bull from the herd at that school but, in the event of his making the purchase, payment will have to be made from school funds.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

G. H. Sims, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.
Toronto-2-
March 13-1944.

Dr. H. W. McGill,
Director
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA - Canada

Dear Sir; Re-Shingwauk Indian School Milk Supply

The local Medical Officer at Sioux St. Marie, has drawn to our attention, a situation that is causing some considerable embarrassment.

I believe that this Indian School is located within the city limits, and it is pointed out that a herd of cattle is maintained at the School, and that raw milk is used by all the children there.

You will understand that legislation prohibits the use of raw milk in any of our cities or towns and this is being observed by others in Sioux St. Marie. Naturally, it causes a good deal of discussion and embarrassment when a government institution permits the use of raw milk and other people are forbidden to use this.

I should be glad to have your comments in connection with this. It should not be difficult to have the milk for use at the School pasteurized by one of the local dairies. That is an arrangement that is followed by a number of places of like nature, and I think that you would have no difficulty insofar as this School is concerned, if you wish to follow this procedure.

Yours very truly,

DIRECTOR
SANITARY ENGINEERING DIVISION

AEB/MLD

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6214, file 469-14, part 1)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Ottawa, March 16, 1944.

Re: Shingwauk Home Residential School
Milk Supply.

Dear Mr. Berry:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of March 12, in which you state that a herd of cattle is maintained at the marginally-noted school and that raw milk is used by the children enrolled at the institution.

I may state that the Shingwauk Residential School, although built by the Government, is operated by the Missionary Society of the Church of England. A per capita grant is paid annually by this Department on the understanding that food, clothing and instruction will be provided by the church authorities. This Department is not responsible for the purchase or maintenance of herds at residential schools anywhere in the Dominion. I am disposed to think that the pasteurization of the milk at this particular school is a matter that might be easily arranged between the medical health officer at Sault Ste. Marie and the Principal of the school. However, I am today sending forward a copy of your letter to the Reverend A. E. Minchin and a copy of my reply. It is altogether likely that you will hear from the Principal in due course.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Director.

A. E. Berry, Esq.,
Director, Sanitary Engineering Division,
Department of Health,
Toronto 2, Ont.

Dear Sir; Re-Shingwauk Home Residential School
Milk Supply

Please accept my thanks for your letter
of the 16th in reference to the above situation.

I note that this is not owned by the
Government but that a grant is paid for the main-
tenance of it. Under those conditions, the respons-
ibility of course would rest with the Principal of

I am glad to learn that you have written
him and I hope that we will have an answer shortly.

There should also be no great difficulty
in adjusting matters between the Principal and the
local health officer.

Yours very truly,

DIRECTOR
SANITARY ENGINEERING DIVISION

AEB/MLD
March 20, 1944

Dr. H.W. McGill,
Director, Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Dr. McGill:

Your letter of the 16th instant re- Pasteurization of milk reached me on Saturday.

It is a curious thing that during the two years I have been in charge of the Shingwauk School no mention of this matter has been made to me either by the local Medical Officer or by anyone else. I have no idea how long this legislation has been in force. The matter is not by any means as simple as it appears to Mr. Berry. The nearest dairy is over two miles away and we often have very difficult roads to travel in the Winter and Spring months. We have only the Farm Instructor and the Engineer to carry on the Men's side of the work during the war. It seems impossible to secure an Assistant. We use an average of 600 gallons of milk per month. A lot of work would be entailed.

As you suggest, I am writing Mr. Berry, Director, Sanitary Engineering Division.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Principal.
Parliament Building,
Toronto 8, Ontario.
July 10th, 1944.

Reverend Canon Dixon,
"Church House",
604 Jarvis Street,
Toronto 8,
Ontario.

Dear Sir:

Further to your visit of recent date to this office, might I say that I have canvassed with the Solicitor for the Department, the question as to whether or not the Indian School is privileged to supply the children in attendance with unpasteurized milk. Dr. Gray agrees with me that this Department has no authority in respect to this matter. I still feel strongly that every effort should be made to have this milk pasteurized.

Yours sincerely,

J.T. Phair, M.B., D.P.H.
Chief Medical Officer of Health.
Dr. H.W. McGill,
Director, Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Dr. McGill:

I beg to refer to your letter of March 16 addressed to A.E. Berry, Director, Sanitary Engineering Division, Department of Health, at Toronto, a copy of which you sent to Rev. A.E. Minchin, Principal of our Shingwauk School.

I may say that we have taken up this matter with officials of your Department and at the suggestion of Dr. Moore wrote to Dr. J. Phair, Chief Medical Officer of the Ontario Government. I now beg to enclose a copy of Dr. Phair's reply to our General Secretary, Canon Dixon.

May I plead that your Department will bring some influence to bear upon the Provincial authorities to have them leave this matter in abeyance at least for the duration of the war. We are experiencing so many extraordinary expenses at the present time that it seems unfair to press such a change upon us now. The expenditure involved would be quite heavy and the difficulty of obtaining skilled help is very real at present. We cannot feel that it is just to demand such action at this particular school where the milk supply is handled under the very best of conditions. If need exists here then it is found in greater measure in all Indian residential schools.

We shall be grateful for anything you can do to assist us at this juncture.

Yours sincerely,

H.A. Alderwood
Secretary.

Dictated but not personally signed because of absence from the office.
Dear Doctor Alderwood:

I am in receipt of your letter of August 4, with reference to the pasteurization of milk at the Shingwauk Indian Residential School.

Very careful consideration has been given to your letter and also to the letters received from the Department of Health at Toronto. We cannot see our way clear to request the Department of Health to exempt the Shingwauk Residential School from a regulation which is enforced on other persons in the same locality and throughout the Province of Ontario. I feel you will realize that if there were an outbreak of sickness at the Shingwauk Home, due to contamination of milk, both the Church of England and the Department would be subject to very strict criticism, if it became known that we refused to carry out the instructions of the Ontario Department of Health regarding pasteurization. I, therefore, trust that the Principal of the Shingwauk Home will make the necessary arrangements to have the milk pasteurized.

Yours very truly,

Director.

Rev. H.A. Alderwood, D.D.,
Secretary, Indian and Eskimo Residential School Commission,
M. S. C. C.,
28-43 The Bible House,
184 Alexander Ave. East,
Winnipeg, Man.
Dr. P. E. Moore,
Acting Superintendent,
Indian Health Service,
Dept. National Health & Welfare,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Doctor Moore: Re: Shingwauk School - Sault Ste. Marie

Our North Bay office advises us that Dr. T. A. Breton, your physician in the Sco., has done no tuberculin tests for the past two years.

We wish to survey this school this Fall but do not feel that we should waste time and films on non-reactors. Perhaps you could bring some pressure to bear to have the pupils tested first.

Yours very truly,

(K. M. Shorey, M.D.)
Clinician,
Division of Tuberculosis Prevention

KMS:A
Ottawa, Ontario.
July 5, 1946.

A letter from the Division of Tuberculosis Prevention requests that we have the pupils in the Shingwauk School tested with tuberculin prior to the x-ray survey which is to be done at the school this fall.

It is realized that there is very little point in taking films on non-reactors so it would be appreciated if you would arrange to do a tuberculin test on the children in the Shingwauk School prior to the survey.

[Signature]

W.L. Malcomer, M.D.,
Actg./Supt., Indian Health Services.

Dr. T.A. Breton,
Wellington St., West,
SAULT STE. MARIE, Ont.

Kenora Agency - Sioux-Lookout Residential School - Church of England - Quarterly Returns. 1946 - 1950.
Dear Sir:

For some time past we have been considering what benefit it would be if we could have a branch of the Canadian Cadets formed here in our school.

We need very much something to teach the boys to be occupied. To be clean and careful with their clothes, and to take an interest in their general appearance, to teach them to respect themselves more.

We are of the opinion that a uniform would be very valuable for this purpose. Our present system of clothing the boys for Sunday service and special occasions is not as good as it should be. We have nothing uniform for the boys, their suits are of different colors and patterns, and do not look well as pupils of a school.

In this connection we have just received a letter from a firm in Ottawa, stating that they at one time supplied boys suits to the Shingwauk, and that they have still on hand a supply of brass buttons, a sample of which they have forwarded to us. And we wondered if the Department would consider using these in the event of our wishes being granted in regard to the matter of Cadets.

If we could have a branch of the Cadets here the boys would get very much benefit, and the matter of discipline would find a place in the working of the affairs of the school that is very hard to maintain in these strange times our country is passing through. And the suits could be worn only to services on Sunday, and other special times.

Please let us know your wishes in this matter, and we shall ever be thankful.

Yours Faithfully,

[Signature]

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6214, file 469-17, part 1)
Ottawa, August 24, 1928.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 17th instant, with reference to the organization of a cadet corps at the Shingwauk Home. I am satisfied that there would be much merit in this activity; but I regret that it is not the practice of the Department to meet the cost of uniforms.

Your obedient servant,

A. P. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Rev. H. P. Fuller,
Principal,
Shingwauk Home,
Sault Ste. Marie,
Ont.

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS

Memorandum of an inquiry into the cause and circumstances of the death of Lily Reddick, Pupil No. 2280, of the Shingwauk Indian Residential School at Sault Ste. Marie who died at City Hospital (place) on Feb. 15, 1926.

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

B. STATEMENT OF THE PHYSICIAN WHO ATTENDED THE DECEASED PUPIL

I attended Lillian Nicowan from July 8th to July 15th, 1936. The immediate cause of death was Scarlet Fever.

The contributory cause of death was acute endocarditis and arthritis.

Do you consider that the Principal of the School, and the members of the School staff exercised reasonable care and judgment in regard to the illness and death of this pupil? Yes.

Did they follow out your professional instructions? Yes.

If in either respect, you consider them to have been at fault, it is required that you express your carefully considered views as follows:

This girl was a resident of the Shingwauk Home. I was notified of her illness on July 8th and visited her that afternoon. Had her removed to the City's Isolation Hospital July 9th and attended her there until her death.

A.T.M. Craig M.D.

Ottawa, December 20, 1937.

EX'D.

Dear Sir,

I am in receipt of memorandum of inquiry into the cause and circumstances of the deaths of Mary Martin, No. 0329, and Howard Greenbird, No. 406, pupils of the Shingwauk Home.

Yours truly,

[Signature]
R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

G.H. Sims, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.
Dear Sir:

It is my painful duty to inform you of the death of one of our pupils, No.289, Beulah Henry, who died after a brief illness. Last Sunday, this girl complained of a slight pain in the back so she was put to bed instead of going to church, as the day was stormy. Monday evening she seemed to be worse, and it was evidently at that time, the appendix was ruptured which caused peritonitis, resulting in her death on Friday. I beg to say that everything humanly possible was done for her under the circumstances. I find it so difficult to teach these children to make known their pains. I have no doubt if the doctor had known of her trouble in time, she would have had a chance, for a ruptured appendix does not come about without some forewarning.

As soon as I knew of the girl's condition, I wrote to the father, and sent a wire, and a second wire the day following. On the day she died, I phoned Mr Indian Agent Moore, and informed him, and asked him to convey the news to the father; and to wire me his wishes regarding the disposal of the body, At the same time asking him to try, if possible, to have the body buried here. He wired me back to that effect, and we are having the funeral this afternoon.

Yours faithfully,

Chas. F. Hives
Principal.

Mr R. A. Hoey,
Supt. Training & Welfare,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.
Ottawa,
November 23, 1938.

Rev. C. F. Hives,

Reverend Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 20th instant with reference to the death of Beulah Henry, No. 0289.

I enclose copies of the form which should be used at the time of the death of a pupil at any Residential School. You should have this completed and signed by the Medical Officer and yourself. In view of the fact that this girl comes from the Caradoc Agency it is not possible to have the Indian Agent present but the form should be forwarded to this Branch through the office of Indian Agent Sims.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Report of accidental drowning of Dudley Shilling, Age 16 yrs.

On Thursday August 15th, all boys of the school went on a picnic, under the supervision of A.B. Hives, Farm Instructor, Miss K. Mitchell, Boys' Supervisor, and Miss M. Loucks, Teacher. The place they had decided on was a safe and beautiful sandy beach near to Pointe aux Pins, some fourteen miles away. They started in the morning, and arrived at a sandy beach sometime before noon, so that the boys went in for a dip before lunch. Here they had to leave the truck, in which they had been conveyed, and walk to the sandy beach, which was their objective, and which was about a mile and a half further on. The boys, who had enjoyed the same experience last Summer, were told to proceed to this place along a well marked road. Presumably all obeyed, but in reality all did not. The deceased, Dudley Shilling, with two smaller boys, made off in another direction toward an island, situated across a channel from the main land about one hundred yards. Here they played on the shore of the main land until Shilling said he was going to swim over to the island. The two smaller boys refused to accompany him, and tried to persuade him from doing so. He more or less dared them to stop him, and started to swim. The water, at this point is about twenty feet deep, owing to the dredging which has taken place, and there is also quite a strong current. He had not swam far before it became evident to the smaller boys that Shilling was in great difficulties, and one of them ran to two other boys who were some distance away, and who came running to the scene. They both stripped and swam out to the drowning boy. One of the boys, Billy Riley, grabbed Shilling, who immediately struggled and very nearly took Riley down with him. Realizing that he could not handle the drowning boy and save his own life, he managed to get away from his grip, and with the aid of the other boy, William Altman, make his way to the shore. Here, both boys lay almost exhausted, but as soon as they could, they ran for a boat. In the meantime, one of the smaller boys had run for more help, and met another boy, Kenneth Benedict, age 15, who came and found the other two boys in a boat rowing to the place where Shilling had disappeared. Benedict swam out, and located the body in about twenty feet of water. Brought it up, and with the help of the other boys, loaded it in the boat, and rowed to the island. They immediately took the body and laid it across a log, and started resuscitation work on it, while one of the boys ran to the U.S. Coast guard at the light house, and brought a man, who saw that Dudley was past all aid.
The police and doctor were informed as soon as possible, and came out to the scene. No inquest was held, as the Coroner, Dr. A.S. McCaig, did not deem it necessary.

The body was laid to rest in the Shingwauk cemetery on Saturday, Aug. 17th.

In conclusion, I would add that no blame could be attached to those in charge. The boys knew what was expected of them. They knew and were told they were not to go into the water until one hour after lunch, and by that time they would be at their objective sandy beach, where they had been before. It is just one of those unfortunate accidents, which, I am thankful to say we have not encountered since nearly eleven years ago.

Chas. Havel

Principal.
Ontario Provincial Police Report.

Death by drowning of Dudley Shilling, age 16 yrs., Ward of Shingwauk Home, Sault Ste. Marie, Ont., at Pointe Aux Pins on Aug. 15, 1940.

With reference to the marginally noted person, please be advised that on the afternoon of Aug. 15th, 1940 I received a call from Pointe Aux Pins, some fourteen miles north of Sault Ste. Marie, advising me that a boy had been drowned there. I immediately proceeded to that point, accompanied by Dr. A.S. McCaig of Sault Ste. Marie, who is chief Coroner for Algoma district.

On my arrival I learned that one Dudley Shilling, age 16 yrs., and a ward of the Shingwauk Home, at Sault Ste. Marie, had, with several other boys from the Home, been on a picnic at Pointe Aux Pins, and that right after his lunch, he had gone in swimming in Lake Superior. There is a small island about a quarter of a mile out from this pointe, and apparently this boy thought he could swim to it. Unfortunately he sank in about twenty feet of water, when about thirty feet from the island. The boy's companion, Kenneth Benedict, age 15 yrs., was about twenty feet from him when he sank, and on his arrival over where Shilling went down, he dived and until he brought the boy to the surface and to the shore.

The American Coast guard patrol saw the fatality and came to the rescue, and by resuscitation endeavoured to revive the boy, but with no results.

After the Coroner, Dr. A.S. McCaig viewed the body, and interviewed witnesses, he deemed an inquest unnecessary and the body was released to the undertaker, T.E. Simpson of Sault Ste. Marie, for burial.

On Saturday afternoon Shilling was buried in the Shingwauk cemetery, with Rev. Canon Johnson officiating.

This boy is survived by one brother, Henry age 14 yrs. His parents being dead.

Prov. Constable

Memorandum of an inquiry into the cause and circumstances of the death of Dudley Shilling, Pupil No. 372, of the Shingwauk Indian Residential School at Sault Ste. Marie who died at Porcupine River (place) on Aug. 15, 1940.

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall they be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

Form No. 414.

Ottawa,
December 7, 1943.

Mr. R.P.G. Laurence, Indian Agent, Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.

I am in receipt of the attached account amounting to $25.00 covering the cost of the burial of Fred Nahwahgezhie, No. 411, Shingwauk Residential School. This boy's name appeared on the September quarter return of the school and presumably he was in residence at the time of his death. If so, form No. 414 should have been completed and forwarded to the Department. As yet we have not received this.

It has not been the previous policy of the Department to pay funeral expenses when a pupil dies in a residential school. Under the circumstances the attached account is being returned unpaid.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
December II, 1943

Mr. R.A. Hoey,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

One of our boys—Fred Nahwehgezhic, No. 611, has died in hospital after an illness of about two months. Everything that could be done for him was done under directions from Dr. Heath. Fred had no parents but I was able to get in touch with his brother in the army who was allowed special leave to attend the funeral.

I cannot find any copies of the form of enquiry to be completed upon the death of a pupil, and should be much obliged if you could have some copies of this form sent on to me. I think it is number 414.

Mr. Laurence, Indian Agent, has just phoned saying that there is some difficulty about the payment of the undertaker's bill. Similar bills have been paid by the Department on two occasions during the time that I have been here. We of course dig the grave ourselves and look after the funeral. The undertaker removed the body from the hospital, provided the casket, prepared the body for burial, and returned it to the college chapel.

Yours very sincerely,

[Signature]
Principal.

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL QUARTERLY RETURN

I HEREBY CERTIFY that the within Return is a true and faithful statement of the attendance and tuition at the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School for the Quarter ended December 31, 1942.
