DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS

CANADA

Ottawa, Sept. 28, 1925.

Mr. McLean,

Plans and specifications were prepared and tenders invited by advertising in the newspapers in Winnipeg for the proposed new Church of England Indian Residential School, located at Sioux Lookout, Ont. The tenders closed at noon today and in response the following have been received:

- J. H. Simmons, Winnipeg, $61,755.00
- Claydon Co., Ltd., Winnipeg, $63,000.00
- M. N. Wyatt, Winnipeg, $90,681.00
- J. Albert Tremblay, Winnipeg, $95,900.00
- Gustiana & Zettler, Sudbury, $111,000.00

All of the above firms have submitted with their tender the required deposit security, with the exception of J. Albert Tremblay, and in this case no deposit security has been furnished. The tender from Mr. Tremblay is not submitted on the tender form as required by the notice to firms figuring.

As the tender of Mr. J. H. Simmons is a fair and reasonable price for the work, I beg to recommend that it be accepted. I would say that this is the firm who erected the McIntosh School last year, and their services were very satisfactory both to the Department and to the Church.

I would also state that the Vote for Indian Education this year includes an item of $100,000.00 for this building.

[Signature]

ARCHITECT.

Memorandum:

Honourable Charles Stewart.

On the 7th of October the Acting Superintendent General signed a Memorandum to Council recommending the acceptance of the lowest tender, that of Mr. J. H. Simmons, of Winnipeg, for the proposed new Industrial School at Sioux Lookout, Ont. Owing to the lateness of the season and the comparative inaccessibility of the location of the school it is highly desirable that the contract should be awarded without delay in order that the contractor may get in the foundations and certain other work done before the heavy frosts set in. In the past it has been our practice to award a contract when the Memorandum to Council was signed and not wait for the actual passing of the Order in Council. Under existing conditions I would like to have the authority of either the Superintendent General or the Acting Superintendent General to follow this same course in this instance.

Acting Deputy Superintendent General.

We have hired a few men to clear on piece work @ $4.50 per acre. They of course will not take out roots etc., this will have to be done later. We are also hiring a few men on wages — so I need contract forms for the piece work, if you send me some.

Royal Alex Hotel, they inform me you paid wrong account your bill should only have been $4.00 not $5.00 so charged you. I return herewith the $1.00 overpayment which the cashier gave me.
I hope the Civil Service get me a Clerk soon it is very awkward being away so often and no one here to attend to things.

However I am never stuck & can manage alright.

Kind regards

Yours sincerely,

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6215, file 470-5, part 1)
I beg to report that on Thursday, Oct. 22nd, in company with Rev. Doctor Westgate, Indian Agent Edwards, and the contractor, Mr. J. H. Simmons, I proceeded from Sioux Lookout to the site of the new Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School, and after a careful examination of the property decided on a location for the main school building and the barn. The site as selected provides excellent drainage facilities, and is well located for a water supply system. It is Mr. Simmons intention to proceed at once with the clearing of the land necessary for the building, and to begin building operations as soon as possible. The building site is located on a point in lot 26, concession C. This point consists of approximately 14 acres, and is at present covered with bush. Captain Edwards is arranging to have this portion of the property cleared this winter, as it is very important, from a stand point of fire protection that the bush does not immediately surround the buildings.

As Indian Agent Edwards has had considerable experience, before entering the service of the Department, in building construction he is well qualified to supervise the building operations and it will therefore be unnecessary to appoint an Inspector of Construction.

There are a few minor changes in the building suggested by Doctor Westgate, and after discussing the different items with Mr. Simmons, I authorized, subject to your approval, the following:

- Changing partitions between class rooms to folding doors, in order that the class rooms may be converted at any time into assembly hall. $186.00
- Changing size of beams in order to give extra support to floor of assembly hall. $52.00
- Providing of a door from the ground floor to the residence. $30.00
Covering the under side of the rafters on the second floor with insulation. $265.00

Changing from lath and plaster in top floor ceiling to metal. 93.00

If weather conditions are favourable it will be possible for the contractor to place all his concrete before winter sets in, and to have the building erected and ready for occupation by the 24th of May next year.

[Signature]

Sir,

As instructed by the Architect of the Department when he was at Sioux Lookout, it is desired that you act as Inspector of Construction on the new Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School and Dorm, and I would ask you to make inspections as often as you think necessary in order to see that the buildings are being erected in accordance with the plans and specifications.

As you are aware the contract has been awarded to Mr. J. H. Stone of Timmins, at his tendered price of $31,756.

It is desired that we clear, at the present time, approximately 14 acres, included in the point on which the school is located. This work should be carried out in the most practical and economical way.

I have to request that you submit to the Department a fortnightly report, giving the particulars as to the progress of the work.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

J. P. No Lean,
Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

WINNIPEG, MAN. November 25th, 1925

R. Guerney Orr Esq.
Architect,
Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

I have located a full set of Plans for the Septic Tank at McIntosh, Ont. On my next visit to the work at Sioux Lookout I will take all distances from the School to the bay for outlet of sewerage and will send you the Plans for the Septic tank and a sketch showing outlet for the sewer and all notes pertaining to the same.

Everything is going O.K. on the work considering the time of the year. I expect that they are about ready to pour the concrete footings. I have advised the foreman to pour the concrete walls in a section at a time, and to house in each section and heat it with stoves. So there will be no danger of the concrete freezing. I have a steam upright boiler on the job for heating the water for the concrete, I have also plenty of galv. iron stacks for heating the gravel, also a concrete Oil Heater, which sends a flame direct into the drum of the mixer to heat the aggregate.

If the fine weather we are now having will only hold for two weeks, we will have no trouble in being ready to start the frame structure in a short time.

I received the additional Blue prints which I requested.

Yours very truly,

J. H. SIMMONS

[Signature]

4th Decr 1925

Kenora, Ont.
Sir—

During my inspection of the Sioux Lookout School the Rev C. Secret asked if it was not possible to put a window in the Principal's house, on the Wall facing East as there is no window on that side except in the basement. The foreman Mr Simons informed me there would difficulty in this, so I promised to bring the matter to your attention. There would be a very good view from this side.

The foreman also suggested that catch basins or floor drains be made in the girls and boys playrooms, in the center of each room, for drainage purposes, and also one in the dining room, as in every case the nearest floor drain is some distance away.

If they were made in the center of each room there would be no trouble in making the doors fit.

The drainage from the Barn will join the drain from the main building and run into the bay West of the School, and so be carried down stream.

The septic tank will be built on a suitable piece of ground West of the School, and will also run into the same bay.

I shall be glad to receive your instructions on the above points.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir,

Enclosed please find certificate for second payment to Mr. J. H. Simmons, Contractor on Sioux Lookout Residential School, entitling him to a further payment of $8646.10.

I also enclose herewith Mr. Simmons' estimate of work performed and material on the ground.

I visited the site with the Rev Claude Secret of Sioux Lookout, who is keeping close watch on the work, last Saturday, November 26th and found the work proceeding well.

We have about 10 acres already cleared but not grubbed, the roots will have to be taken out in the spring when the frost is out of the ground.

The Contractor has done a great deal of the excavating and has a large amount of material on the ground; he has had trouble in locating gravel, but has luckily been able to find some close to Pelican Station about 1½ miles from the site.

Rev Mr Secret has promised to have same tested by Mr Jas White, Postmaster at Sioux Lookout who was an Inspector for the Government in the construction of concrete work on the building of the National Railway.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6215, file 470-5, part 1)
Sir,

I visited the Sioux Lockout School on Saturday the 12th instant. Mr. Simmons, the contractor, also visited the school at the same time. The contractor has the foundation and frame up for the barn, and it should only be a few days before it is erected in. This will be a good place for them to store material and do a certain amount of the work during the extreme cold weather. The most of the excavating is done for the main building, and concrete footings are now in. Fourteen acres of clearing has been done, but of course no grubbing or stumping. This cannot be done until the Spring when the frost is out of the ground. The logs cut will be piled so as to be later used for heating purposes for the school.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

Assistant Deputy Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

GENERAL CONTRACTOR  
306 CONFEDERATION LIFE BUILDING  
WINNIPEG, MAN. December 23rd, 1925

Re Guernsey Orr Esq,  
Architect, Dept. of Indian Affairs,  
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:-

I have today mailed the December Progress Estimate on  
the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School, to Inspector Edwards.

I would consider it a favor if you would rush the voucher  
through as quickly as possible.

Practically all the crew are in for the Holidays with the  
exception of the teamsters and a few laborers.

The Barn is all closed in, and all work practically  
completed that we can do until spring. We will not lay the concrete  
floor in the barn during the winter.

Practically all the concrete footings of the school are  
in place. We will start the concrete walls of the school after the  
Holidays. We will build a separate protecting wall on each side  
of the wall form, and keep the frost away from the walls until set  
with sufficient stoves.

After the concrete walls are poured I will put on a good  
sized gang of carpenters and will soon have the building enclosed.

I expect to be taking my usual trip East this winter to  
see the old folks at London. On my way east I will call at Ottawa  
with a lay out of the proposed drainage and Septic Tank, so we can  
go into the matter together.

Wishing you the compliments of the season,

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Sir,

Enclosed please find Duplicate Certificate for material and work supplied on Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School.

The work is proceeding well considering the cold weather we have been having.

Fourteen acres have been cleared but not grubbed or stumped.

The logs will be gathered up and piled to be used later as firewood.

The Barn is now sheeted in, and is being used for storage and as a work shop.

The heating apparatus for the concrete work is being got in shape, so that on the whole there is very little to report except the receipt of material on the ground.

The men are mostly away for a few days Christmas vacation, but will be on the job again soon after the New Year.

Your obedient servant,

506 Confederation Life Building
WINNIPEG, MAN. January 4th, 1926.

R. Guernsey Orr Esq.,
Architect, Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa Canada.

Dear Sir:-

I am enclosing a sketch, of the Sioux Lookout Indian School, showing the approx. run of the main drains.

Will it be advisable to run the soapy water drain also the boiler room drain to a sump as shown on the sketch? If so it will make quite a saving and save running a separate soapy water drain to the far side of the Septic Tank. The soil at the proposed sump is sand about five feet down.

There is a natural fall from the sump to the bay. By putting in Lye or other preparation in the sump it would clear away any corrosion on the walls of the sump.

You will note I have shown an alternate drain (see dotted lines) from the main soapy water drain to the manhole and beyond the Septic Tank.

You will note figures in red at various points around the basement wall, on the sketch. These are the approx. heights from the grade to the floor. Also that the figures at the extreme rear end show a fill.

Kindly let me know as quickly as possible if advisable to use the Sump for the soapy water, so I can arrange with the Plumber.

NOTE:- If the soapy water does not run to the sump the drain will have to be set up in the fill, on account of the ground being so low at the rear of the building.

On account of the boiler room being so much lower than the other drains, it will be necessary to run the water from boiler room to a sump, even if we do not use it for the soapy water.

Yours very truly,

J. H. SIMMONS
Per. [signature]

Dear Mr. Simmons,

With reference to the drain at the Sioux Lookout School, I beg to say that I think it will be satisfactory, in fact a good arrangement, to have the scaly water drain and the boiler room drain discharge into a sump as shown on your sketch. On account of the location I see no reason why this would not work satisfactorily.

Yours very truly,

R. Gurney Orr,
Architect for the Department.

506 Confederation Life Bldg.,
Winnipeg, Man.

RE: INDIAN SCHOOL - SIOUX LOOKOUT

We are mailing under separate cover two prints of our fire escape details for above school for your record and approval.

ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Sir,

On the 16th inst., in company with the Rev. C. Secret, I inspected the work at the new Sioux Look-out Indian School. There had been very little done during the Christmas holidays, but the men are now back on the work and owing to the mild weather, are putting in the concrete. The footings are nearly all in, as also the basis for the pillars. The concrete wall is up on the west side of the west wing. There does not appear to be any danger of frost as they have the work closed in, with three stoves and two salamanders working. Since then we have had a cold snap and this will likely delay them. The barn is now up and sheeted and shingled, and this gives the Contractor a place to do his framing and other work under cover.

There are a quantity of logs on the ground, and these have not yet been gathered together and piled. This work is being done when the Contractor can spare the use of the teams.
I have given instructions to the Contractor about the floor drains and other matters referred to in your letter.

I remain,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

The Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Department Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Sir,

On Saturday Jan. 30th, 1926, accompanied by the Rev. Mr C. Secret, I Inspected the buildings of Sioux Lookout Residential School.

The men have worked very well since the Christmas holiday, a soft spell enabling them to make unexpected progress with the concrete work, which is well advanced despite a cold spell entailing a few days' stop. They have now attained the height of the main building and of the principal's residence.

The sub-contractors installing the heating plant are on the job, with boilers, piping and steam-fitting supplies on the site. The window frames for all buildings are ready for installation, and the barn complete save for paint and finish.

The logs on the site are not yet piled, this being done by us with the help of a team and men borrowed from the contractor when cold weather prevents their usual work. This is mutually helpful.

Since Pelican, the nearest station to the site, is not a regular stop, I have arranged with the superintendent of the Can. Nat. Ry. to make this point a flag stop for passengers on Nos.1 & 2 on Sunday Tuesday and Saturday for the convenience of the school authorities, contractors and ourselves.

Your Obedient Servant

[Signature]

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6215, file 470-5, part 1)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Sir,

On the fifteenth instant I inspected the new Sioux Lookout school and find the work progressing satisfactorily. The concrete work on the walls would have been done by this time, but cold weather interrupted things for a few days. This part of the work should be done by the end of the week with reasonable weather.

The framing of the west wing has reached the second floor, with window frames in.

Boilers are on the ground, also piping for drains etc.

About 25 or 30 men and 3 teams are employed.

The contractor asks permission to raise the floor above the visitors' bedroom about five inches for the concealment of the pipes for the bathroom overhead. This improvement, he says, would entail no additional expense.

The hot water tank in the boiler-room is shown running N. and S. The contractor claims an E. and W. installation would be handier for the twelve foot length of boiler, and I advised him to do this if no difficulty results.

Your obedient servant,

The Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Indian Agent,
Department of Indian Affairs.
Ottawa.

H/A.
J. H. SIMMONS
GENERAL CONTRACTOR

Architect, Dept. Indian Affairs,

Dear Sir:

With reference to the Cupboards (Detail "C") on the second floor, in the Boy's and Girl's Dormitory, Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School.

These cupboards are seven feet high. On account of the rake on the mansard roof these cupboards could not be set up as per detail, unless they were kept a considerable distance off from the outside walls. Especially the two toward the front of the building, the two towards the rear end of the building could be built full size part of their length.

Kindly advise me what you suggest should be done with these cupboards.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6215, file 470-5, part 1)
Ottawa, Feb. 10, 1926.

Dear Mr. Simmons,

Replying to your letter of the 5th instant, with reference to the cupboards, detail "c" in the boys' and girls' dormitories of the Sioux Lookout School; on looking at the plan I do not see how these cupboards can be placed conveniently on any of the walls, and I would, therefore, ask you to omit them for the present.

If you have an opportunity discuss this matter with Doctor Westgate in Winnipeg, and obtain his opinion as to what style of cupboards he would like, after explaining to him the difficulty of placing them on the walls as shown on the plan.

Yours very truly,

R. Gurney Orr,
Architect for the Department.

J. H. Simmons, Esq.,
506 Confederation Life Bldg.,
Winnipeg, Man.

ines, but forwarded cuts showing what they intended to supply. This

GUARANTEE NEW TYPE MANGLE

Domestic Sizes Price, $250.00 up according to size Laundry Sizes

SOME POINTS OF SUPERIORITY

The great advantage possessed by this Mangle over machines of standard types is the fact that its highly polished ironing roll revolves at a speed of twenty-eight per cent faster than any other surface heat before retouching the linen. This roll travels at a speed four times greater than that of the linen, imparting a highly-polished finish, and revolving in the same direction as the feed rolls obviates the friction and wear that linen is subject to on other types of mangles whose ironing shoe remains stationary.

The revolving ironing roll utilizes the whole of its circumference, constantly presenting newly-heated surface to the linen so that all the heat developed is used—none going to waste. On other types of mangles the ironing shoe is stationary and only a small segment of its surface is used, allowing the entire heat generated to escape.

Guarantee New Type Mangle is controlled by foot, leaving both hands of the operator, who can work sitting down, free to control the work. Linen can be finished direct from the extractor with once through the mangle at a speed of twelve feet per minute. Sheets need be folded only once, and collars are ironed and shaped at the same time.

The bearing shaft on the ironing roll is three inches in diameter running in roller bearings. Gears are made with extra large strong teeth, with a spare idle gear on opposite end of roll. This machine is automatically lubricating.

Heat can be generated by electricity, gas, gasoline or coal. Electric type has two heats, each indicated by word and light. Electric heating elements fusing 3 k.w. per hour—110 or 220 volts guaranteed and encased in steel tube lasting each year. Automatic temperature control.

Mangle is run by a ¼-h.p. electric motor which can be attached to any light socket. Other models to run from line shaft or gasoline engine.

This Mangle together with our smallest Washer and Extractor, with one operator, will wash, dry and iron $3.00 worth of flat work per hour.

The Main Trunion Journals operate in roller bearings. Less power is required to drive the machine and wear is almost entirely eliminated, with the result that all gears are always in correct mesh and alignment. Broken gears, worn trunion journals and bearing replacements are never necessary on this washer. The main bearings are entirely separated from the tub by packed stuffing boxes, which absolutely prevents oil and grease from entering the washer or water from coming out.

The Reversing Movement is our Beaver Ball Bearing type in which all the thrust of operating the belt shifter slides is taken by hardened steel balls. The movement is designed so as to give a positive even shifting of the belts, irrespective of wear, so that the...
Beaver Roller Bearing Washer—Header on End

cylinder runs the same number of revolutions in either direction. The gears are machine cut from solid blanks and the main gear is thirty inches in diameter. The gear has a split hub to facilitate easy removal. A combined gear lock and hand wheel is provided.

The Cylinder is of the best grade all heart stock long-leaf yellow pine with hard Maple ribs. The three lifting ribs are extra deep to ensure rapid washing. The trunions are bolted to heavy brass rings. The hinges are of brass bolted through a brass batten with an enclosed brass lock.

The Outer Case is of the finest clear Cypress and is furnished with a brass apron at the door opening. Inspection plates are provided in each end so that trunion bolts may be tightened without removing the upper half of the case.

The Inlet and Outlet Tees are connected by a 1½ inch pipe into which steam can be injected. When steam is being used to heat the water this construction gives a rapid circulation and absolutely prevents any steam from coming in contact with the wood of the cylinder or case. The water inlet is 2 inches in diameter. The steam inlet is ¾ inch. A 3 inch plug type discharge valve is supplied.

This Washer can be arranged for motor drive, in which case it is driven from the motor through short belts. The motor is carried on a substantial cast iron base bolted firmly to the frame of the machine.

At a small additional cost these machines may be equipped with a Beaver 6 inch foot operated discharge valve, Beaver Water Level Indicator, visible anywhere in the wash room, Beaver Soap and Soda filling doors, and Monel Metal Lifting ribs in the cylinder.

The Curb, Legs and Base are one solid massive casting, weighing almost 300 lbs. more than the ordinary curb. This tends to absorb vibration, allows the Machine to balance easily, and to pick up speed quickly.

THE BEAVER LAUNDRY MACHINERY CO., LIMITED

Beaver Heavy Duty Extractor—Continued

The Wide Square Base distributes the weight over a large area, and allows this Machine to be operated at higher speeds than is possible with a small or round base.

The Basket is of Perforated Copper, heavily tinned and strongly reinforced by steel bands. The Oversize Steel Spindle operates on a hardened ball point and button running in a long bronze bearing. The bearing is supported by two large rubber springs, so arranged and designed as to make this Machine self-balancing. A large amount of working space has been provided round the bearing, making very easy and quick the adjustment or changing of the rubber springs. An oil retaining well is provided, which requires only occasional filling.

All Beaver Extractors have countershafts attached to the curb, and may be for straight or angle drive. The angle drive, as shown in the cut, costs a little more than the straight drive, but effects a saving in floor space, and allows the Extractor to be placed in line with the washers. All Extractors have our improved adjustable friction clutch pulley, which gives a gradual increase in speed without strain to any part of the Machine. Motor drive extractors are direct connected with push button control.

A Galvanized wire safety cover is fitted and so arranged that the cover must be closed before the Machine can be started.

Memorandum:

Mr. Scott,

Mr. Simmons, the contractor for the new Sioux Lookout Indian School was in the office recently. I discussed with him the plans for the Septic Tank required for this building and asked him to let me have a price for same. I have, today, received an offer from Mr. Simmons to install a Septic Tank complete with the necessary manholes and sewer pipe for $1,230.00. As the boiler room in the building is below the level of the remaining portion, it would be more economical to drain this floor with a sump and Mr. Simmons has submitted a price for this work of $274.00. These prices are reasonable for the work to be done and I beg to recommend that he be authorized to proceed with this Septic Tank and the Sump, the cost of same to be added as an extra to his contract.

[Signature]

Architect.
J.H. Simmons,
General Contractor.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Sir,

Enclosed please find certificate #5 for work and materials for construction of the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School.

On Saturday the 27th of February I inspected the school in company with the Rev. Mr. Claude Secret.

We are all very well pleased with the rapid progress now being made.

The outside concrete work is practically complete, the studding of the main building is in position to the roof, and the sheeting of the main building and of the principal's house will be complete by the end of this week. The main floor is laid in the residence and in the two stories of the main building, and the two boilers are in place in the boiler room.

The underground plumbing is laid in the West wing of the main building.

Paint, metal-work and steam-fittings are on the ground, also metal shingles and ceiling. The plumbing is roughed in to the roof.

The sheet-metal workers, electricians, lathers and glaziers will be on the work this week, and the plasterers are expected about the middle of this month.

Referring to my letter of Feb. 17th, in which I quoted the contractor's request for permission to raise the floor above the visitors' room for the concealment of bathroom pipes, the contractor says that on farther consideration a 5" drop in the guest-room ceiling would preferable, which I allowed, since it costs no more and the hidden piping is accessible.

Specifications show 2" nickel-plated strainers in the basement floors. The contractor says that they are liable to become continually obstructed, being fitted to a four inch pipe, and he suggests a 12" cast-iron catch-basin with cover and rings as at McIntosh school. I allowed the change, and hope you may approve.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

The Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

J H SIMMONS.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6215, file 470-5, part 1)
Sir,

I made my usual bi-monthly inspection trip to the Sioux Lookout Residential School at Pelican Falls on the 13th instant.

All the concrete walls are now completed, the main building is practically sheeted in, window sashes are fitted and partly glazed, outside work on main building is primed one coat, the residence is sheeted in and roofed and shingled, residence fireplace is built and the chimney as far as the roof, The main roof is now being raised, all underground plumbing is completed, The boilers are set in and the main lead pipes in basement are in place, the three verandas are completed except the steps.

Electricians, Plumbers, Glaziers, and Tinsmiths are on the work, and everything is being well done and according to specifications.

The Electrician suggested that two alarm bells should be put in instead of one, so as to have one at each side of the partition in the hall and a test switch installed in the office, as this could be done without further cost to the Department, I have given the necessary instructions.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

Assistant Deputy and Secretary.
Department of Indian Affairs.
Ottawa.
J. H. SIMMONS

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6215, file 470-5, part 1)
Ottawa, March 28,
1926.

Dear Captain Edwards,

I beg to advise you that I have today accepted by telegram Mr. Simmons' price of $1,250.00 for the building of the septic tank at the Sioux Lookout School, the tank to be built in accordance with plans prepared for the one at the McIntosh School. I have also accepted their price of $374.00 for the building of a brick sump, four feet in diameter, inside approximately eleven feet high; eight inch wall and cast iron cover, also approximately eighty feet of six inch tile from the boiler room.

There has been some delay in paying Mr. Simmons the amount due on his last certificate, that is number five. The vote for Indian Education is very nearly exhausted and we are arranging to have some funds transferred to this vote, which should take place in a day or so, and when this has been carried out a cheque will be sent to Mr. Simmons in payment of his account.

I am very pleased to hear that such good progress is being made on this contract, and that the work is being carried out in a satisfactory manner.

Yours very respectfully,

[Signature]

H. GUMLEY ORR,
Architect for the Department.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Sir,

On Saturday March 27th, in company with the contractor Mr. J.H. Simmons, I inspected the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School at Pelican Falls, and we were both very well pleased with the progress made.

Concrete Work: Completed except for the floors, the cement and gravel for which are on the ground.

Lathing: Ground floor practically lathed, and two floors in main building ready for lathing, which should be done about April 10th.

Shingling: Main building roof practically shingled.

Electric Wiring: Two thirds of main building now roughed in.

Plumbing: All roughed in for the main building.

Heating: All mains in place and about half the risers for the main building in place.

Painting: Outside main building and barn primed one coat.

Sashes: All glazed and primed.

Millwork: All which is not yet placed is on the ground.

Plastering: All material on the ground, and several days' preparation done by plasterers and help.

Chimneys: Chimney and fireplace in residence complete, also small chimney for laundry. Main chimney started.

Metal Ceiling and Ventilation: All material on the ground and half the ventilators in place.

Edge-grain Planking on ground.

The Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
I should like to know what arrangements are being made for a water supply and storage tank, also whether it is intended to build ice and root houses.

In the course of inspection we noticed that the partition between the principal's house and the main building is only of lath and plaster, and since this adjoins the playrooms, classrooms and dormitory the partition should be deafened.

Mr. Simmons says he is doing this, as he knows the Department's architect will approve, and there is no doubt in my mind as to the necessity of it.

Enclosed herewith please find Estimate No. 6.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.

E/A Enc.

I am now informed the laundry machine is at Sioux Lookout.

Please send a further supply of Certificate forms.
Ottawa, April 22, 1926.

Dear Captain Edwards,

I overlooked a paragraph in your letter of the 5th ultimo, with reference to the water supply system for the Sioux Look-out School. When Mr. Simmons was in Ottawa in the early part of the winter we discussed the water supply system for this building, and when he left here it was his intention to make inquiries in Winnipeg as to the cost of erecting an elevated tank, and promised to let me have full information at an early date. I have not heard from him as yet, and perhaps it would be well if you would mention this to him at the first opportunity. I am of the opinion that the elevated tank system is the most satisfactory, providing it does not cost too much.

It is my intention to pay a visit to Sioux Look-out sometime during the month of May. If there is any particular date that would suit you, probably I can make arrangements accordingly. I would like, however, to go when the building is nearing completion.

I am working on some plans for the outbuildings that is poultry house, play yard, etc., required, and will send them to you in the near future to get prices from Mr. Simmons.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

H. J. GILBERT OHL,
Architect for the Department.

Captain Frank Edwards,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Sir,

On the 17th inst., I inspected the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School in company with Rev. Mr. Claude Secret.

The roof Ironwork is complete except over the chapel. All the main building is ready for Lathing and half lathed. 1500 yards of Plastering are browned one coat. Three outside coats of Paint are on the main building and residence. All inside and outside Sashes are glazed and fitted except for the chapel. All Plumbing is roughed in. The heating plant is complete for temporary Heat. Metal Ceilings are up on the first and second floors of the main building. The sump pit Pipe Line is in. All Laundry Machinery and Plumbing Fixtures are on the ground. The contractor has made a manhole to the roof in the ceiling of the passage. This necessity was not shown on plans.

Rev. C. Secret showed that the chancel floor must be 6" above main floor from the vestry partition to behind the altar, and communion rail hinged in centre for passageway. I have instructed the contractor to do all this, the cost being about $15.

Some arrangement should be made to get a root-house and a boat. Shall I take this up with Rev. Dr. Westgate?

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6215, file 470-5, part 1)
R. Gurney Orr, Esq.,
Architect to Indian Department
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Mr. Orr;

As the management of the new school at Sioux Lookout will require a gas boat, it has occurred to me that as this important item of equipment will be provided by the Department I should offer you some suggestion with regard to the kind which I consider would be most suitable.

As the distance from Sioux Lookout to the school site is approximately 7 miles over a fairly wide sheet of water, and as there will be frequent communication from the school and this Town, I should like to recommend that a boat, capable of carrying a considerable amount of freight, be purchased. It should not be less than 25 feet in length, and as some rough weather may be encountered, it should have an engine of not less than 18 H.P.

As this boat will be used chiefly for freight purposes and would cost the school management too much for gasoline and upkeep to make one trip daily to Sioux Lookout for mail and other things, it would be a very great convenience and saving if a smaller gas boat could be supplied, as well as the larger one. Both these watercrafts seem to me essential to the efficient and economical management of the school, and our Society will be very grateful if your Department will supply them.

I am hoping to visit Sioux Lookout during the weekend May 16th to 17th on my way to Moose Fort, and if you are unable to be there at that time, I will endeavor to furnish you with a brief statement setting forth any suggestions which I may have to make.

Mr. Marshall, who has been appointed Principal of this school, will arrive there sometime during the first half of July. I very much hope that the Principal's residence may be ready for him at that time. I am presuming that your Department will supply the furniture.

Believe me,

Yours truly,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.
May 7, 1946

Dear Doctor Westgate,

I have your letter of the 6th instant with reference to the new school at Sioux Lookout, and I have noted your request that a suitable bed be supplied for the use of this school. This matter will be given due consideration.

I do not think that it will be possible for me to be at Sioux Lookout during the week ending May 10th, but I hope to be able to visit the school by the end of this month.

With reference to your remarks regarding furnishing if the building is completed we ought to be able to have all furniture in place by July. I will be glad to hear from you after your visit to the school around the fifteenth.

Yours very truly,

MEMORANDUM: Mr. Scott.

May 7, 1926.

In connection with the new school at Sioux Lookout, it will be necessary to supply this Institution with a suitable boat in order that they may transport their supplies, etc., from Sioux Lookout to the School, a distance of approximately seven miles. This covers a fairly wide sheet of water, and it will be necessary to supply a strong substantial boat. I believe that one similar to that purchased for McIntosh would best suit their purpose. The McIntosh boat is a plain, large, flat-bottom motor boat, with a good engine and is giving good satisfaction. I would suggest for your consideration, that a letter be written to Captain Edwards, Kenora, asking him to see what can be purchased in the way of a boat. He is well acquainted with the locality and knows exactly what is required. The McIntosh boat was purchased second hand on Lake Winnipeg. The cost will be approximately $1,800.00.

ARCHITECT.
May 7, 1936.

Sir,

The Architect of the Department has reported that a motor boat will be required in connection with the new Indian Residential School at Sioux Lookout, and has suggested that one similar to that in use at the McIntosh School should meet the requirements for Sioux Lookout. Will you please make inquiries and let me know if a boat can be purchased similar to the McIntosh one, and what would be the cost.

There is no particular hurry regarding this matter, but you can look into it at your earliest convenience.

For obedient servant,

[Signature]

J. D. Wilson,
Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

Sir,

On the first of May, in company with the Rev. Claude Secret, I inspected the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School.

The outside work is proceeding rather slowly owing to the cold weather prevailing of late, but on the whole the progress since the beginning of construction has been quite satisfactory.

Mr. Simmons, the contractor, had written Mr. Orr, our architect, regarding the installation of a water-storage tank etc.

The Material for the fire-escapes is on the ground.

The Chapel is sheeted in and the interior work now being done.

Plastering is complete in the residence and stairways, and half-done in the main building.

Metal ceiling is complete for two floors and painted on the second floor.

Outside painting is finished, except for the back of the main building and the chapel.

Lathing is complete except in the chapel.

Trimming and inside finishing on the two upper floors and the residence is partly done.

The outside walls are cement-plastered, and the contractor is back filling.

The Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
All metal roofs are complete except for the chapel.

Brick chimneys are complete except the last staging of the furnace chimney.

The plumbers are installing radiators.

I note that our architect Mr. Orr will be down this month, and I shall hold myself in readiness to meet him at Sioux Lookout.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

R/A
Sir,

On the 12th inst. I inspected the new Indian Residential School at Sioux Lookout. The work there is proceeding in a satisfactory manner.

The plastering of walls on three floors is complete, and the basement browned. Part of the cement floor is poured in. The concrete stairs are poured in. Trimming is complete on the carpenter work of the top floors. The second flooring on two upper floors is now complete. The main stairs are being set up.

All inside ceilings are on, metal work on two floors is painted, and all outside metal work complete. Most of the radiators are connected, and about half of the plumbing fixtures are in place. Fire escapes are installed.

The cement foundations of the barn appear to have been touched by frost, and may not receive the approval of our architect, but I shall point this out to him when he is inspecting the school.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.

The Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Scott,

When I laid out the new buildings for the Sioux Lookout School, I promised Captain Edwards, the Indian Agent, and Doctor Westgate that if possible I would again visit Sioux Lookout when the buildings were nearing completion, in order to make the final inspection. Captain Edwards was anxious that I should make these arrangements as he was acting as Inspector of Construction on the work, and wished to have me make the final inspection before the building was accepted.

The work at the School will be practically completed this month, and with your permission I will make the final inspection leaving Ottawa on the night of June 1st. I am setting this date in order that I will be here on the 3lst of May when the tenders close for the schools on the Pelican Reserve.

Architect.

Dear Mr. Orr:

I sent you a set of blue prints yesterday of a piggery which we have found to be the most economical in construction of any used on our Experimental Farm System. We have another style with a driveway down the centre which is decidedly more expensive to build. The one of which I have sent blue prints may be extended in either direction from the feed room or may be extended in both directions. I would suggest that a farrowing pen be placed next to the feed room on either side if the piggery is to be extended both ways as this make it possible to make use of any warmth that may come from the cooking. If you desire further information you could call Mr. Nicholson, our Draughtsman, here who would be glad to discuss the structure with you.

The Poultry Division promised to send you blue prints of the one-hundred-hen poultry house. No doubt, they will send them but if they fail to arrive within a day or two you might call the Poultry Division at the Farm and ask them to hurry them along.

Trusting that this will be of service to you, I am,

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Chief,

Dear Mr. Orr:

With further reference to my letter of the 3rd inst., and your reply on Apr. 6th I beg to submit the following information relative to outbuildings, etc., required at the Sioux Lookout School:

1. The Ice House. One like that provided for the Chapleau School would in my opinion be the most suitable. It is about 18' x 18' (so far as I recollect) with over half of the space partitioned off for ice and the rest thickly boarded and otherwise suitably fitted up for cold storage of meat.

2. The Poultry House. To accommodate about 200 fowls.

3. The Piggery. To accommodate about 1 dozen pigs.

4. An Implement shed. About the same dimensions as that supplied to the Old Sun school. This is I believe (I am quoting for memory) about 90' long. The one for the Sioux Lookout school should certainly be not less than 70' long. If it were made 90' long, part of it could be used for storing fire wood for the Kitchen range.
I had hoped to be able to submit to you plans for each of these buildings, but have not yet received these from the Manitoba Agricultural College to whom I made application some days ago. Should these come to hand in the near future, I am leaving instructions for them to be forwarded to you as I myself am leaving the City this evening and will be absent some days.

Very kind regards, Believe me,
Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Field Secretary M.S.C.C.

TBRW/JF.

PORT ARTHUR,

July 21, 1925.

Accountant & Purchasing Agent,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

We understand that it is the intention of the Department to build an Indian School at Sioux Lookout.

We build firebox and horizontal return tubular steam and hot water heating boilers. We will forward you today a copy of our catalogue. As we are the only builders of such boilers in this district and as we presume that it is either of the above types of boilers that will be installed in the building, we would like to request that "Pascal" boilers, or equal, be specified.

Our boilers are well known and there are many of them installed from considerably East of Montreal to the Pacific Coast. There are a number of them in the Dominion Government, also Provincial Government buildings. All sales outside of a radius of some one hundred and fifty miles of Port Arthur are made by our Agents, for which reason, to date, we have not had any direct dealing with your Department, but we believe Pascal boilers were installed in one or more Indian Schools in Western Canada. We can also recall offhand that they were also installed in Postoffices at Regina and Kingston, Ontario.

There are no better boilers built by any firm in Canada, or the United States for that matter, and we hope, as a compliment to a firm in the constituency for which the building referred to is to be built, you can meet the above request to have our boilers specified.

We are sending this same letter and one of our catalogues to Mr. R.G. Orr, Architect for your Department.

Yours very truly,

PORT ARTHUR SHIPBUILDING COMPANY, LIMITED

A.B.C.

SECRETARY TREASURER.

I beg to report that on Thursday, June 3rd, I made an inspection of the new Indian Residential School being erected under contract by Mr. J. H. Simmons of Winnipeg at Sioux Lookout, Ont. The work on the building is exceedingly well done, and the Department has a building that is well constructed in all its details.

WATER SUPPLY SYSTEM.

While at Sioux Lookout, I obtained the necessary information for the installing of a water supply system for this building. It will consist in the erection of an elevated tower and water tank, the supplying and installing of a 4" water service from the lake to the school building, a distance of approximately 400 ft., a 3" service from the building to the water tank, a distance of approximately 214 ft., and the supplying of a 2" water connection to the barn. I have obtained a price from Mr. Simmons for this work which is $7,245.00. Using the elevated tank system there will be a good water supply in case of fire, and I have obtained a price of $300.00 for the installing of fire service to the outside corners of the school building, fitted with fire nozzles, valves, etc., complete. As these prices are fair and reasonable for the work I beg to recommend that Mr. Simmons be authorized to proceed with this installation.

ELECTRIC LIGHTING SYSTEM.

While in Sioux Lookout I visited the office of the Superintendent of the Canadian National Railways, in order to see if it would be possible to obtain power for the school from their generating plant at Sioux Lookout. I could not get anything definite and I, therefore, left the matter in the hands of Capt. Edwards, who will submit a report to the Department as soon as the Engineers of the Canadian National railways advise him whether they will be in a position to supply the school with power or not.
I also obtained from Mr. Simmons a price for the installation of the electric lighting plant in the school, and as soon as I receive the report from Capt. Edwards, I will be in a position to make a recommendation.

Fourteen acres of land have been cleared on which is located the new school and barn, but a greater acreage than this will be required in order that the school may start farming and gardening operations, and I instructed the Indian Agent to obtain and submit to the Department prices for the clearing of approximately 35 acres more. I would suggest that the portion to be cleared be selected on that part of the property where the least work will be required to put it into condition for farming. A few small out buildings will be required, and I obtained a price from Mr. Simmons for the following which I think are necessary:

- Ice House, $590.00
- Implement shed, $395.00
- Chicken house, $830.00

I consider the above prices fair and reasonable and I would recommend that Mr. Simmons be authorized to build same. If you approve of my recommendations regarding the water supply system and the out buildings, Mr. Simmons should be notified at the earliest possible date, as he has practically completed his work at the school, and will be moving his equipment.

ARCHITECT.

RE: SIOUX LOOKOUT INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

Dear Sir;-

I agree to supply and install a "Lister-Brusven 6 K.W., 110 volt automatic electric lighting plant, complete, as specified below for the sum of $3,158.00.

Specifications of the "Lister-Brusven Plant.

CAPACITY: The plant to be of sufficient capacity to maintain a continuous output of 6 Kilowatts at 110 Volts and to consist of:-

ENGINE: One "Lister" vertical 2 cylinder gasoline electric lighting engine of substantial construction, especially designed for running for long periods without attention, and ample power to generate 6 Kilowatts at full load. Fitted with high tension magnetic ignition, automatic lubrication, open water tank cooling, also pump fed carburetor (thereby obviating the danger of flooding which often occurs when ordinary float-feed carburetor supplied by gravity from a tank is used) mechanically operated valves. Crankshaft gudgeon pin and cylinder being ground to limit gage, and all parts numbered and interchangeable. Complete with necessary tanks, silencers, standard water and exhaust connections, tools, spare parts.

REGULATION: In addition to the centrifugal mechanical governor, a patent magnetic governor is fitted to the engine, which regulates the speed according to the load, thereby giving practically constant voltage at all loads.

DYNAMO: One semi-enclosed type shunt wound dynamo, capable of generating 55 amperes at 110 volts continuously without overheating, and working at varying loads without undue sparking or alteration of position of brushes, and coupled to engine by means of a flexible coupling. Fitted with ring lubrication and carbon brushes.

CONTROLLER: One automatic rheostat or controller fitted with mechanism for working compression release, to enable engine to start up easily and smoothly, the compression of the engine being released until sufficient speed has been attained to ensure easy starting.
J. H. SIMMONS
GENERAL CONTRACTOR
506 Confederation Life Building
WINNIPEG, MAN.

Arrangement: The whole of the above mounted on a substantial cast iron base, suitable for bolting to ordinary cement or strong wood floor without further foundations.

BATTERY: Suitable battery consisting of 64 cells, having a capacity of 35 ampere hours, capable of working the plant automatically and supplying light to the lamps in use before the engine starts up.

SWITCHBOARD: One enamelled slate switchboard, carrying two ammeters, voltmeter, patent relay apparatus, circuit breaker, fuses etc., enabling the plant to operate in the manner specified above.

TEST: The plant to be tested on full load for at least six hours at The R. A. Lister & Co. Ltd. works and copies of the test sheet with fuel consumption forwarded if desired.

Fuel: Container or 55 Imperial gallon cylindrical tank located outside the building.

Should the Transmission Equipment of the 6 K. W. Plant be used to drive Laundry machinery and Water pump allow for extra installation $204.00 Specifications for same as follows:

Engine pulley,
Counter shaft in engine room equipped with fast and loose pulley, pulley for laundry, pulley for pump, three hangers, safety collars and two belt shifters.

One endless leather belt 3" from plant to counter shaft.
One endless leather belt 3" from counter shaft to laundry.
One endless leather belt 2½" from counter shaft to pump.
Coupled up and left running.

Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Orr:

I arrived here yesterday evening, and have this day visited the site of the new School and examined the land and buildings. As you yourself contemplate a visit to this School in the near future I beg to submit the following observations and suggestions for your consideration.

The Land.

With regard to the land I find that only fourteen acres have been cleared. A greater acreage than this will be required for farming and gardening purposes, especially for growing oats and hay for the horses and cattle, and I would recommend that a total of, say, fifty acres be cleared, that is another thirty-six acres in addition to the fourteen mentioned.

As the stumps have not been removed from the land already cleared, and the land cannot be cultivated until this is done, I beg to recommend that a contract be let for their removal during this summer.

The lower land to the S.W. of the main School building will be valuable for gardening purposes if drainage is provided, and I beg to suggest that an open ditch be dug from the centre of this land to the natural outlet which is the bay on the west side of the school site.

As the levelling up of the grounds around the main School building will be too great an undertaking for the School management to handle, the contract for this work...
might, it seems to me, be included along with that for the additional clearing and the drainage already mentioned.

The provision of a wagon road from the School to the Pelican Station is a matter of urgent importance, and this also might conveniently be included in the same contract.

Wood for Fuel.

The provision of wood fuel for next winter is a matter about which I am much concerned. The trees on the cleared area have been stripped of their branches, but have not been cut up into cordwood lengths. Unless this is done in the immediate future, and the bigger logs split and piled up to dry, it will be very difficult, if not impossible to keep the school properly heated next winter. As a help to the solution of this problem I should like to suggest that an engine and pole saw be provided at once for the use of the School, but that the work of cutting up the poles into cordwood lengths be included in the contract for clearing, drainage, levelling, etc.

Fencing.

The immediate need of fencing is not, to me, very apparent, and expenditure under this heading might remain over until next year when ample provision for the same should be made in the estimates.

Wharfage.

The construction of two wharves appears to me to be necessary. The best location for the larger of these is, as we have already thought, on the east side of the School site on the S.E. side of the farm. All heavy supplies which may require transportation by wagon to the School from this point should be landed at this wharf.

At one end of this wharf a boat-house, or weather-proof shelter, should also be built.

A smaller wharf or landing platform should also be built near the big boulders on the shore in front of the School. This would be for "passenger" service only, and would eliminate the necessity for the lady agents on the staff and visitors to pass through or by the barn yard when arriving at or leaving the School by boat.

Telephone

The installation of telephone connection with Sioux
Lockout via Pelican or any other way, seems to me to be a matter of first-rate importance, and I commend the same to your sympathetic consideration.

The Main School Building.

The workmanship on the Main School Building, so far as it was completed, appeared to me to have been well and carefully done, and I feel confident that, in due course, our General Secretary will convey to you, and to your Department, an expression of our Society's appreciation of the great pains you have taken in this connection.

There are, however, a few minor points to which I drew the attention of the contractor, and which he undertook to refer to you. These are as follows:

1. The windows leading to the fire escapes instead of being on pulleys, and sliding up and down in two sections, would admit of a more rapid exit of staff and pupils in case of fire, if made of one piece and fastened on hinges. The alteration suggested would be inexpensive, and I trust you may authorize it.

2. The cement floor in the fuel room, off the boiler-room, is very liable to be dug up by cordwood thrown in unless covered with coarse planks, and I beg to suggest that this plank flooring be installed.

3. As hardwood flooring has not been provided, the fir flooring is certain to give way if the pupils are not obliged to leave their heavy boots in the recreation rooms in the basement. To do this conveniently cupboards for the heavy boots and heavy winter coats are a necessity in the recreation rooms, and I beg to suggest that they be installed. Some benches around the walls in the recreation rooms should also be provided. The provision of these would not involve so much expenditure while the contractors are on the spot as at a later date.

The lockers in the dormitories are about all that could be desired and I was very gratified to see that they had been provided.

The porch and platform at the main front entrance, might, it seems to me, have been enlarged with advantage, and I hope that at some future date this action may be taken.

The Barn

The barn, which had been erected, would, I felt,
when completed provide adequate and comfortable accommodation for the horses and cattle. The cement used in the foundation did not appear to me to be as firm as it should be, and I trust that the flooring may be of better quality. In completing this building the need of passage ways in front of the mangers, a feed room, a harness room, and breeding stalls, should be kept in mind.

Other Buildings.

The other buildings required have already been referred to in former communications addressed to you. Of these, it seems to me, that a poultry house, an ice house, and cold-storage room combined, and an implement shed should be provided this year. A piggery is also necessary, but this could be left over until next year, if necessary, in order that the provision of all the other requirements mentioned above may not be delayed.

I regret that my letter has reached so great a length, but you will understand, I think, the importance of the various items referred to, and which have necessitated the same. I trust that you yourself may be able to visit the School in the near future and give to the matters to which I have referred the careful attention which, I feel certain, you will recognize they deserve.

With very kind regards, Believe me,
Yours very truly,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.G.

TERW/JF.
May 29th, 1926

Dear Mr. Simmons,

I have received your letter of the 25th instant, enclosing prices for the building of a pigsty and barn house at the Sioux Lookout School. I do not care to recommend the erection of these buildings at such a cost. I am of the opinion that we should be able to build a suitable barn house for not more than $400.00, and a pigsty for around $3,500.00. I will discuss these plans with you when I meet you at Sioux Lookout. In the meantime if you have a chance to figure on what we could erect that would be suitable for the above mentioned amounts it would be of some assistance.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Architect for the Department.

May 22, 1926.

Dear Mr. Simmons,

Replying to your letters with reference to the water supply system for the Sioux Lookout School, I would say that the bottom of the tank should be approximately 10 feet above the top of the roof of the main building, and it will be satisfactory for the supports to splay approximately 12 feet at the top to 30 feet at the bottom.

The pumping outfit required will be a Fairbanks Morse outfit No. 1591, which is a belt driven 5 x 5 Typhon pump, connected to a 3 H. P. "Z" type engine. This outfit is to be located in the machinery room, and the gasoline engine to be so arranged that it will connect with a line shaft for operating both the laundry machinery and the pump.

The elevated tank is to have the tank enclosed with a space approximately 24" all round, including the bottom. This space will be connected by a shaft approximately 3 feet square to the ceiling of a small 8' x 8' house at the bottom, in which we will install a Quebec heater to supply heat in winter. The pipe of course will be enclosed in this heated shaft. All wood framing of the tower should be painted either before or after erection with a good coat of creosote. Your price should include the tank, pumping outfit, and all pipe line from the lake to the building, and from the building to the elevated tank; also a pipe line to supply water to the barn. I would also ask you to include the placing of two fire hydrants, one on the ground at each end of the building.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6215, file 470-5, part 1)
With reference to the electric lighting plant please quote me a separate price for the installation complete of a Lister-Bruston 6 K.W., 110 volt, automatic electric lighting plant. It will consist of a 6 K.W. generator, and a twin cylinder, 12 H.P. gas engine, switch board, batteries, etc. This outfit is handled in Winnipeg by the R.A. Lister Co. Ltd., and they are located on Wall Street. In figuring on the lighting plant you should also include a gasoline storage tank to be located in the ground outside the machinery room. The Lister Company will give you the size required. This machinery is of course to be located along with the pumping outfit in the machinery room which I believe provides ample accommodation.

I expect to leave Ottawa on Tuesday, June 1st, for Sioux Lookout, and will arrive there on Thursday, June 3rd, at noon.

Yours very truly,

R.E. CUMMINGS,
Architect for the Department.

J. H. Simmons, Esq.,
506 Confederation Life Bldg.,
Winnipeg, Man.

Dear Mr. Orr:-

I am enclosing a pencil sketch showing the proposed layout for the water tank and water supply. On account of the first layout received from my foreman not being definite enough, I had to wait for further information, hence the delay in forwarding sketch to your office.

You will notice the distance from the water tank to the building is 214 feet. This is the best location for the water tank unless it is built in a low spot.

The intake at the lake will be in deep water with the proper current.

The distance from the main hole or well to the intake is approx 96 feet. There will be more or less rock to contend with in this 96 ft. and likely quick sand and water which will require sheet piling.

The ground floor of building is approx. 7 feet above the ground at the water tank location.

On account of being the principal in a fatal motor accident, I have been unable to leave Winnipeg and visit the work personally, but I am sure my foreman with the help of Inspector Edwards have selected the best and most economic location available for the water tank and inlet for the water supply.

The school building should be practically completed this month except a few odd jobs. They are having real warm weather this week and are now pouring concrete floors in the basement.

If you intend making a trip west, and intend stopping off at Pelican, I would be pleased to have you advise me so I can be on the job when you arrive.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

MEMORANDUM

Mr. Scott,

With reference to your memorandum of the 14th, regarding the new Indian Residential School at Sioux Lookout, I have received a telegram from Mr. Frank Edwards, advising that the Canadian National Railway are not prepared to furnish power from their generating station at Sioux Lookout to the new school. It will, therefore, be necessary to install our own electric lighting plant, and I would recommend for your consideration the installation of a Lister Brunston 6 K.W., 110 volt, automatic electric lighting plant, which will consist of a Lister 2 cylinder gas electric lighting engine; a 1 semi enclosed type, 55 ampere, 110 volt generator; 1 64 cell, 35 ampere hour storage battery; 1 switch board complete; and the automatic control for regulating the operating of the electric lighting plant. The engine in this plant will also be used, by means of connections to the line shaft for driving the laundry machinery, and the pump for the water supply system.

I have obtained a price for the installation complete of the above mentioned plant, and Mr. Simmons's price of $5,359.00 is fair and reasonable, and I beg to recommend that he be authorized to proceed at once with this installation.

[Signature]

Architect.

Dear Sir:

As I had been informed by the Contractor who built the school that a suitable boat to meet this school's (Sioux Lookout School) requirements was available at moderate cost at Sioux Lookout, I requested the Principal to examine the same and report thereon. On account of the same being in his report on this boat which was built for service between Sioux Lookout and Pine Ridge was not satisfactory. It had many unsatisfactory features, one of which was that it possessed so powerful an engine (36 H.P.) that it would impose a very heavy financial burden on our Society to provide it with gasoline. The cost of this boat I found to be $750.00, while the fuel costs $120.00.

While at Sioux Lookout he examined all other boats which were available, and informed me that, in his opinion, there was one owned by Dr. Mitchell, nearly new, and which the Doctor was willing to sell for $1000.00. This boat which is well-known to you, Mr. Orono, and also to Captain McVea, our Agent at Kenora, is 25 feet long with 6' inch beam, and is provided with a 10-14 h.p. Red Wing engine. The engine alone cost $750.00 and is in good condition, as is also the hull and other parts. The Principal was altogether favourably impressed with the suitability of this boat for the school's need, and I beg to recommend that the same be purchased.

As a "snow" will also be necessary to bring, at times, certain supplies from Sioux Lookout, the Principal learned that this could be built, at a reasonable cost, by a local boat builder there. The Principal recommends that what is known as the "Lumberman's Pointer" be purchased as the most suitable craft of this kind and I beg to submit this recommendation for your favourable consideration. A Lumberman's Pointer, with capacity of about 2 or 2½ tons would be sufficient.

I regret that I am unable to furnish you with an estimate of the cost but am of the opinion that it would not exceed $500.00 if it amounted to so much.

(Sgd.) T. B. R. Westgate.

Field Secretary, M.S.C.O.

July 12, 1926.

Dear Captain Edwards,

A letter has been received by the Department from Rev. Doctor Scottgate, recommending that we purchase Dr. Mitchell's boat at a cost of $1,000.00 for the Sioux Lookout School. I cannot agree that this boat is of the type required as I think it is altogether too good a boat for the purpose for which it is intended, as it is really a pleasure boat.

For your information I am enclosing herewith a copy of a letter which has today been sent to Doctor Scottgate, in reply to his letter, and I still think that a boat similar to the one in which we made the trip to the school, but of more sturdy construction, would better answer this purpose.

Yours very truly,

On the 11th inst. I inspected the Indian Residential School at Sioux Lookout.

Work on the building at present is not proceeding very fast, since the contractor says he is waiting for some material from British Columbia.

The Rev. Mr. Marshall, the principal, is on the ground and is taking much interest in the work. He is writing me a letter covering many points we discussed, and on receipt of the same I shall write you at further length.

I received a letter from Rev. Dr. Westgate strongly recommending the purchase of Dr. Mitchell's boat at Sioux Lookout for this institution. It can be secured for $1,000.00 and is in every way suitable for towing the new building which could be done on day labour under the superintendence of Mr. Marshall if he had authority to purchase the necessary materials.

Mr. Orr knows this boat well, and I would accordingly recommend its purchase at the earliest opportunity as it is urgently needed.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

July 22, 1926.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 14th instant, with reference to the Indian Residential School at Sioux Lookout. With regard to the purchase of Mr. Mitchell's boat it is not considered that this boat is the type most suitable for the school. A plainer type of boat of substantial construction, similar to that built by the boat building at Sioux Lookout would better answer the purpose, and I would ask you to please communicate with this boat builder whom you interviewed when Mr. Orr was at Sioux Lookout, and ascertain for what price he is prepared to build a boat similar to the one he is using at the present time, but of more sturdy construction.

Your obedient servant,

Mr. Marshall dropped his request for eavestroughs on my mentioning Mr. Orr's disapproval of them, but he asked for a concrete floor in the barn with planks on top, to obviate the unsanitary alternative of seeping manure and fluids. In this regard, Mr. Bunn, at our consultation, wrote a wire from me to you, copy of which is enclosed herewith. I asked a reply by wire since the instructions for this work must reach the contractor before the erection of stanchions.

The principal asks for the installation of cupboards in the three staff-rooms and the residential kitchen, also shelving in store room and clothes room to be done by the contractor before leaving, unless we allow the principal a carpenter for a time for the necessary work, we to supply the material.

The principal would like to have the contractor instructed to make a dock.

The principal says water-pipes should be boxed as eventually done at Norway House, and sunk at least eight feet to avoid subsequent expense.

The principal's request for a root-house might be attended to later on, since the only place for present storage of vegetables is the cellar of the residence.

The contractor expects to be finished at the end of this month. He has begun the tank and pipe-line. The lighting machinery is on the ground.

The frozen concrete in the barn is replaced and the walls plastered after scraping to the principal's satisfaction.

Enc. P.S. referring to your telegram received this morning (July 27th), I have informed the contractor, Rev. Dr. Westgate and the principal that we have no funds for the concrete managers, etc., in the school barn.

Sir,

Enclosed please find estimate No.1 for Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School covering the contracts for the lighting plant, farm buildings, elevated tank, water supply and fire service.

Tractor: With reference to your letter 129-6-9 in this regard, Mr. Inspector Bunn is purchasing a tractor, and I have arranged with him for the purchase of the necessary cables, block, tackle, etc.

Siding: Some arrangement regarding the one car siding at the east switch at Pelican should be made now, as I am informed the railway company will not leave cars on the siding after the 21st. of this month owing to the wheat rush, and school goods which are shipped to Sioux Lookout have to be taken down to the lake, brought to the school by water and handled from the water's edge to the building, whereas if they were landed at Pelican and dealt with there, could be taken directly to the site at one handling, but they can not be taken from Pelican station to the east switch owing to the swampy nature of the ground.

Cupboards, shelves, etc.: Referring to your letter 129-6-15 in this connection, the principal requests cupboards in the store-room, lumber for tables and benches in the laundry and serving room, clothes wardrobes in four staffrooms as in main staffrooms, cupboard in the kitchen of the residence, cupboard in office, cupboards in three classrooms, cupboards and shelving in the dispensary, shelving in the store-room opposite the staff dining-room. To do the above would require about 2,000 feet of one inch dressed lumber, also two inch dressed planking, 2x2's and 2x4's, and panel doors as in the kitchen cupboards.

Sidewalk: The principal requires 1,000 feet of 2" planking for a walk at the front and sides of the school.

The Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

R/A

Indian Affairs. (NO 10, Volume 6215, file 470-5, part 1)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
of the school.

Pews: These are needed for the chapel.

Linoleum: Battleship linoleum is required for all halls and passages.

It is impossible to estimate exactly the amounts of materials required for the foregoing work, but I would respectfully suggest that the principal be authorised to get the lumber and materials to an approximate value of $500, with authority to employ a carpenter for two or three weeks to do the necessary work. The shelving etc. are absolutely necessary, and in this way the work would be done to the satisfaction of the principal at minimum cost.

Deck: The materials required for this would be about 600 feet of 2" planking, the necessary logs etc. to be cut on the school property. A small dock, about 100 feet by fifty feet would suffice for the time being, but later another dock and boat house will have to be built. This dock new proposed, in addition to the timber and lumber mentioned, will require 100 lbs of 4" spikes and 150 lineal feet of ½" iron drift bolts, and would take about five days to build.

Water pipes: Referring to my letter of July 26th. on this subject, these pipes should be boxed, as the contractor has struck rock near the water's edge, and there will have to be much filling and some blasting.

Team: The principal requests the immediate purchase of a team, and of a small number of cattle and poultry when the school is occupied. I would suggest that Mr. Inspector Bunn be asked to buy the team, wagons, etc. and have the same shipped as soon as possible.

Implement shed and ice-house: These have been completed by the contractor but are not yet painted.

Chicken house: The concrete for this has been poured and the other materials are on the ground.

Septic tank: This is complete, along with the sewer to the lake.

Laundry: All machinery for this is installed.

Barn and outbuildings: Instructions should be given to the contractor to wire the barn, which needs three lights upstairs and ten below. The necessary lights should be installed in the implement shed and chicken house. Water should be laid to the barn and a plank trough built in the barn.

Electric lamps for building: Should these be supplied by the contractor, or should we purchase them?

Stump Puller: The principal has asked for one of them. Could Mr. Inspector Bunn purchase this?
Hot water heater: This is a coal burner. Would it be feasible to change or convert it to burn wood?

Rev. Mr. Marshall accompanied me to Winnipeg on Sunday last and we discussed matters with Mr. Inspector Bunn, but were unable to get in touch with Mr. Smith, the contractor, and I am not informed of the costs of these various improvements, but all of them are absolutely necessary and not unduly expensive. If general authority were given me I would arrange to have the work done, keeping expenses as low as possible. My annuity payments are now over, and I am getting more time for this work.

Completion of the school should be rushed, so that children can be admitted in September, since otherwise the Indians go off to their trapping grounds and are hard to get.

Rev. Mr. Marshall showed a list of utensils needed, which has been sent to the Department, but this list was far from complete. He is therefore making an additional list which will be submitted at an early date. He would also like to have plans and blueprints showing the school property.

I should be glad to receive instructions on the matters mentioned above at the earliest convenience.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.
Elliot Bros.
Boat and Snow-Shoe Manufacturers
Repair Work a Specialty

Dear Friend,

In regard to your letter of 26th, I may say we would not be able to build you a boat this fall as we have a good deal of work on hand. We have two boats yet should either of these do we are giving a good price the new one at $750.00 and the one for sale at $400.00. It does give service for two or three years yet.

Thanking you for the inquiry.

W.E. Elliott Bros.
Reference your letter #129-6-5 of 5th instant re launch for the Sioux Lookout School.

I looked over all boats at Sioux Lookout that might be suitable for the school, and do not think any of them are more suitable than Dr Mitchell's boat however I informed Mr Marshall of the contents of the Departmental letter quoted above, and he said he would not be satisfied with any other boat, I therefore told him he better write me a letter which I could forward to you, I am today in receipt of the letter which I am forwarding herewith, and should like to get further instructions.

I also enclose Elliotts letter, in which they say they would not be able to build another boat this fall.

The Principal also requests permission to purchase a swing saw, and encloses Messrs Waterous' tender, from which you will see the outfit can be purchased for $77, without the frame and counter weight which could be made at the school. I would recommend this purchase to cut the logs into cordwood for heating, the logs are very large and heavy and this machine can be run from the tractor, and is the most suitable for the purpose.

Awaiting further instructions,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.
