Ottawa

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6215, file 470-5, part 1)
Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School,
Sioux Lookout, Ont.

Captain F. Edwards,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

Dear Sir,

In looking over the many boats offered for Sale, ten in all, we come down to two: one owned by Elliott Bros. and the other by Dr Mitchell. I have made a special investigation into the cost of the power plant of the Mitchell boat and find the prices are as follows:

1 10-14 Model D Engine 4 cylinder 4 cycle Propeller and shaft, cost at Winnipeg.............. $494.10
Electric starter.......................... $168.75
Copper exhaust and couplings............. $60.00
Gas tank & strainer....................... $20.00
Side lights red and green, stern lights and spot light. Cannot obtain price in Winnipeg
Deck cover for boat....................... $24.00

This, amounting (without prices on lights) to $746.85, leaving a balance of about $250.00 for the rest of the boat.

It seems to me the greatest and best bargain of them all as the boat is worth around sixteen hundred dollars and could not be bought for that amount from the builders, but owing, as you know to the Doctor's druggist decamping with his store funds, the Doctor is obliged to sacrifice other things as well as the boat to cover the loss.

The hull is built of the best material, bottom of heavier planking than sides, all of Cedar, Oak frame and combings with deck of Cedar, all in the best condition.
Captain F. Edwards

The Elliott Bros. Boat is much the same model but built of Cyprus planking on an Ash frame with deck and combing of Fir, with canvas covered deck. It has a Niagara engine 9-12 H.P., rebuilt engine, gas tank, no strainer, rear hand starter, no lights, but if equipped with a new engine such as the 10-12 H.P. Medium Duty Scripps engine the whole outfit would then class with that of Dr. Mitchell's boat and I believe that the Doctor would consider letting his go for even $950.00.

This is a full report as far as I can obtain prices and as I have lived the last twenty years with boats, should have some experience and personally, if the Department put a good boat in, it would be better taken care of than one bought for rough work and I cannot see any reason for putting on a semi-freight boat when all supplies could come via Pelican when the C.N.R. have granted the switch, which means a saving in time and cartage.

Am also enclosing prices on saw outfit, the balance of the platform can be built at the School. I would strongly recommend this outfit as the timber is too large to handle on a pole-saw, frame too light. With this outfit the wood could be cut into the lengths required for stoves in School and residence and as the fire boxes in the furnaces only take a 3'8" stick it means 400 cords have to be cut for heating purposes as well.

Yours faithfully,

J.F.J. Marshall
Principal
August 26, 1925

Sir:

We are in need of a suitable motor boat for a new Indian Residential School, which is being established in the vicinity of Sioux Lookout in Northern Ontario. Mr. C. G. Parker of this Department has referred me to you for particulars. I may say that the boat will be required for operating on Lac Seul, which is quite a large body of water, and it should be of a type that is substantial and perfectly suitable in rough water, as it will be used for transporting children from different points on the lake to the school.

I would be glad to have your suggestions as to the type of boat you would recommend, and also a price f.o.b. your factory. Please advise me if you are in a position to make immediate delivery on receipt of order.

Yours truly,

R. Gurney Orr,
Architect for the Department.

Mr. Warner,
Manager, Gladstone Boat Mfg. Co.,
Penetanguishene, Ont.

Sept. 3, 1926.

Dear Sir,

With reference to the motor boat required for your school, I have been in communication with the Gidley Boat Co. of Penetanguishene. Their traveller called at my office today and I outlined to him the requirements of a boat suitable for the school, and he suggests and recommends the boat described in the accompanying circular. This boat is 26 ft. long, and will be equipped with side seats and lockers in place of the chairs shown. It has a speed of 15 miles an hour, and the Ford marine engine gives nine miles to the gallon of gasoline. He showed me letters from parties who have purchased this boat and it appears to have given absolute satisfaction. More mileage is obtained by the gallon of gasoline than with any other type of engine, also all the parts are standard and can be readily obtained in case they require renewing. I am advised that they keep these boats in stock and can ship immediately on receipt of an order. I would therefore be glad to hear from you by return mail advising me if you will be satisfied with this boat.

Yours truly,

R. Gurney Orr,
Architect for the Department.

Principal, Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School,

Louis Loukout Oct.
Sept 9th 1926

R. Gurney & Co. Eng.
Architect

Dear Sir,

Received your letter of Sept 1st and folder on boat.

I think this would be a very diplomatic move as there were many boats for sale, but none of them absolutely fitted for the purpose for which we wanted them, and even when cut down to two, both had old parts. So think it would be wise to purchase the tidy boat.

If there is a 26 foot boat in stock it would help greatly at the present time, and rather than cause further delay we could put the seats in ourselves and utilize the chairs in the school. The men who av...
running boats here claim that the seating cross way gives better balance to their boats when running the rapids.

I fully agree with you on the type of boat and especially repairs for engine.

Kindly drop me a line as to what you do regarding boat so that I can make arrangements to have it unloaded in the mill yard.

Thanking you for your kindness,

Yours faithfully,
John H. Marshall
For some time I have been looking for a suitable boat, that is required for the new Sioux Lookout School, Sioux Lookout, Ont., and I beg to recommend for your consideration that we purchase a Sidleyford motorboat. This boat is substantially built, and is equipped with a Ford marine engine. It is the ideal type of boat for the purposes for which it will be required in connection with the Sioux Lookout School. The Ford marine engine is a very economical engine to operate, and if any repairs are required the cost is the least of any type of marine engine. This boat is manufactured by the Gidlay Boat Co. Ltd., of Penetang, and they have several in stock. Their price on a 26 foot boat is $1,350.00. This price is very reasonable for the boat, and I beg to recommend that it be purchased, with instructions to ship to the school at the earliest possible date, as they are in urgent need of same. I may say that the school is located a distance of approximately 8 miles by water from Sioux Lookout station.

It is customary to get competitive prices and it will be necessary to get Mr. M.O.'s approval to depart from this rule. The season for purchasing boats has practically closed.

Dear Sir:

The question of the fuel supply for the Sioux Lookout School during the coming winter is causing our Society much concern. Dear Captain Edwards:

I understand some correspondence has passed between you and the Department at Ottawa with regard to the switch at Pelican and the store room which the school management require for offloading goods as soon as they arrive. Mr. Marshall, so far as his memory serves him, believes the Department stated that they would deal with this matter at a later date. It seems to me that if the siding is not installed and the store room built before winter sets in, there will be no chance of having this work done by the C.N.R. before next spring. This will place the school management in a very awkward position, as the only place where supplies could be landed would be along the route and transported from there to the school would out of the question. The experience of the contractor last winter in trying to freight material over the ice when everything was lost, serves as a warning to us in this respect. I should like to suggest that you bear pressure on the Department to have this work done at once, and not writing to them direct, but am sending a copy of this letter to Mr. Gray, whose address is to be seen from Kenora and my letter's delayed in reaching you. You should, I think, point out to the Department that the building of the store room could be accomplished much cheaper by the contractor who is now at the school, than by giving the work to another firm. Mention should be made of the annual rental ($825) the C.N.R. will collect. Kind regards.

Yours very truly,

T.B.R. Westgate,
Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

MEMORANDUM:

To Mr. C. H. Attwood.

Re - Sioux Lookout Indian School Water Supply.

Mr. Johnston's letter of October 2nd stated that the Department of Indian Affairs had requested that this office take up with Mr. J. H. Simmons, contractor for the new Indian School at Sioux Lookout, the question of the water supply of the school, with reference to the proper protection of it from frost. After discussing the matter with Mr. Simmons it was considered advisable that an inspection of the conditions be made, and on October 11th Mr. Simmons and the undersigned left Winnipeg for Sioux Lookout and on the day following visited the school and in company with the Principal, Rev. Mr. Marshall, made an inspection.

The school is about one mile north of Pelican on the Canadian National Railway and stands on rising land some 150 feet from the shore of Pelican lake, from which the water supply for the school is to be taken. The water supply system, which is already installed with the exception of the intake pipe into the lake, comprises a suction pipe from the lake to the pump located in the school basement, and from here the water is pumped to an elevated tank located outside the school.

In discussing the matter, Mr. Marshall stated that the only part of the system which he was afraid would be damaged by frost was the last 50 feet of the suction pipe to the lake, which is already laid, and the proposed intake pipe into the lake. Both Mr. Marshall and Mr. Simmons stated that the balance of the water mains had over five feet of covering and were amply protected from frost. It is therefore only this last 50 feet of the suction pipe and the installation of the intake upon which we have been asked for and given advice.

As the danger from frost to the fifty feet of suction pipe is due to lack of sufficient covering, it is recommended that this section be taken up and laid to a depth which will give a minimum covering of four and a half feet to the present ground level, and additional feet of covering to be given by grading. As the additional excavation will be rock it was suggested that two additional feet of covering might be added by grading, but Mr. Marshall stated that for the sake of the appearance of the grounds he could only increase the ground level in this vicinity by one foot.
The proper protection of the intake from frost and damage by ice calls for fairly extensive work due to the shelving nature of the lake bottom which is rock, and to the present high water level which today is three and a half feet higher than the recorded low level. To provide for a depth of water of four feet over the intake, which is considered the safe minimum, it will be necessary, in view of the low stages recorded, to lay the pipe to a point which will give at the present lake stage, a covering of at least seven and a half feet of water. This depth is reached at a distance of about 80 feet from the shore. The shelving bottom of the lake necessitates the excavation of a trench in order to secure the proper grade and sufficient covering for the intake pipe. If the bottom can not be in rock this work will call for a cofferdam some 90 feet long and owing to the necessary blasting, at least 15 feet wide.

It is proposed that this cofferdam be left in place and the pipe covered with earth to a depth of five feet with the remaining space in the cofferdam to be filled in with rock or earth.

In addition to the above it is recommended that an intake well five feet square and from eight to ten feet deep be constructed at a point twenty feet from the present shore line. As shown on the enclosed sketch, the intake pipe runs a short distance below the bottom of the well, with the suction pipe about a foot above the intake. With the intake well a certain amount of control is given over the suction pipe and the intake and any trouble occurring in either could be more readily located and remedied. Though not essential it is considered that the advantages secured by having the well more than offset the additional expense.

As outlined above it is apparent that the installation of the intake will be, for a small water system, quite expensive, but with the shelving lake bottom and the present high water this expense cannot be avoided if a proper job is to be made to assure a reasonable measure of protection from freezing and damage from ice. While the intake is under construction a temporary supply of water may be obtained by connecting up the end of the present main to the lake by means of a two inch pipe, this pipe to be drained each night to avoid freezing.

J. CRAIG,
Assistant District Chief Engineer.
Sir,

I am enclosing a memorandum from Mr. Craig containing his recommendations to protect the intake and the lower fifty feet of the water supply system of the Indian Mission School at Sioux Lookout, as requested in your letter of October 14th.

Mr. Craig inspected this site and states that while providing the intake with a reasonable protection against freezing will no doubt be expensive, that due to local conditions there is no other alternative. You will readily appreciate that any of the measures, if done under winter conditions, will greatly increase the cost and for this reason it is recommended that the work be done within the next three weeks, or before freeze-up.

As instructed by your telegram of even date, I have instructed the contractor, Mr. Simmons, to proceed with the work as outlined in your telegram. Mr. Simmons stated to me that he thought the work could be done within a period of two or three weeks and that he would place the work in charge of men familiar with that type of work and provide all the tools necessary in an endeavour to have the job finished before freeze-up. Under the circumstances therefore, it is essential that a decision be arrived at immediately regarding that portion of the pipe line which will be in the water and that decision wired to me.

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd.) C. H. Attwood,
District Chief Engineer.

There has been considerable delay in getting competitive prices for the boat, and as the season is now so far advanced it is thought better to postpone placing the order until early next year.

Yours very truly,

A.F. MacKensie
Acting Assistant Deputy and Secretary

In response to an urgent request from the principal of Sioux Lookout Residential School I have asked Mr. J.R.Bunn to arrange for the purchase and immediate shipment to the school of a wood-heater for the elevated water-tank, and would be glad to receive your authority for this purchase, which is extremely pressing in its need, owing to the strong frost which is happening at nights. While I can not say with any degree of accuracy what the cost would be, still you can understand that it can not possibly be out of the way in the circumstances.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, November 9th, 1926.

Sir,

I have your letter of the 5th instant, informing the Department that, owing to the urgent request of the Principal of the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School, you had arranged with Mr. Inspector Bunn to purchase and make immediate shipment to the school of a wood heater for the elevated water tank.

In reply I beg to say that the action taken by you in arranging for the supplying of this heater is approved.

Properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the cost should be forwarded in the usual manner.

Your obedient servant,

A.-F. MacKenzie,

Kenora, Ont.
Duncan C. Scott, Esq., C.M.G.,
Deputy Supt. General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Scott:

Re: Fuel supply for Sioux Lookout School.

Owing to the delay in the completion of the School at Sioux Lookout and the fact that a circular saw for cutting wood has not yet been delivered, the Principal informed me that it is absolutely necessary to secure some extra help in order to provide a sufficient supply of fire wood for the immediate use of the heating plant and as much as they can towards what will be required during the winter months. I beg to state therefore, that in view of this information I am engaging one extra day labourer at the same rate as you have allowed for the other men who have been engaged, namely $50.00 a month, and am asking him to proceed to the School at the beginning of next week. I shall be obliged therefore, if you will let me know if this arrangement meets with your approval, and if the salary and living allowances of this additional labourer will be met from Departmental funds.

Believe me,

Yours very truly,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

Sir,

I send herewith certificate #2 for extras at the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential Indian School.

Will you kindly forward payment to Mr. Simmons as soon as possible as this certificate has been delayed in being forwarded owing to a clerical error and had to be returned to Mr. Simmons for correction.

The work on the coffer dam has been progressing very satisfactorily, and the foreman is a man who was at the Pulpmill at Fort Alexander, from all accounts Mr. Simmons could not have got a better man.

The rock is blasted out to the lake to the required depth, and they have pushed out twenty feet into the Lake. On this part they have struck boulders as anticipated, and this is of course harder to handle than solid rock.

The heater for the water tank has been sent as per authority Department letter 129-6-5 of 9th instant.

The saw and outfit has also been forwarded, this was delayed as the Waterous Company had to send East for the saw.

The Principal asks that delivery of the sleigh be rushed, so I took the matter up with Inspector Bunn and this will be attended to at once.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

Ottawa,

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
On Saturday the 4th inst. I inspected Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School. The contractor's men had finished their work and left on Thursday.

The Cofferdam is complete.

At the request of the Principal the contractor had done a little extra work as follows:—installing two laundry tubs in the basement of the principal's residence, extending water-pipes in the stable, and installing a valve and fire-line at the water-tank, to let water be drawn off outside, for fire purposes. Mr. Simmons asks me if these items could be included in the next certificate, as his only authority is the principal's request. These additional things I consider were absolutely necessary, and I have advised him to include them.

The Saw has been received at the school, and the water-tank, boiler, plough and dough-mixer are en route. Material for the blankets has arrived, most of the equipment is in, and the principal is sending things up as quickly as possible.

Rev. Dr. Westgate informs me that they have bought a car-load of coal from the J. Murphy Co. of Fort William at $16.60 per ton F.O.B. Pelican. He is also getting a price on soft coal, claiming he has the necessary authority from the Department. The coal will be used for the heaters in the water-tank and the laundry. The principal says he must use a certain amount in the school furnace this winter, as the wood cut last winter is not yet quite dry, and there has been little time to draw out dry wood. After this winter there will be little need for soft coal. The principal requests that I give him two barrows (steel pan type) for the coal, as well as six medium size coal scoops. He has ordered coat-hooks for the cupboards in the dormitories. The above-mentioned articles are all necessary, and I should be glad if you would ask Mr. Inspector Bunn to purchase the barrows and scoops.

The Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
barrows and scoops.

Mr. Marshall says he received 45 bedsprings 2'6" x 4'6", but claims they were too short and should all be 2'6" x 6'0". He says he interviewed Mr. Brownley of the Simmons Bedding Co. of Winnipeg, and thinks the company would make the exchange without further charge except for freight, as the company might dispose of the smaller springs to children's homes.

Electric Lights. In this connection the principal is awaiting the arrival of the dough-mixer, which is now at Pelican station. The electrical company will then send down a man to meet the inspector of electrical installation, and the lights and power could be turned on.

The water is not yet turned on, as the principal is waiting for the tank-heater. In this connection I am a little afraid that the very cold weather prevailing may cause tank troubles.

Seating for Chapel. I do not know if this has been ordered yet, but the principal would like to get it from the Valley City Seating Co. of Dundas, Ont., as he has experience of this type, and would have no trouble assembling it.

I shall send in the contractor's certificate immediately on receipt.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Rev. Sir:

Rev. Dr. Westgate has requested that a good strong wheelbarrow be supplied for stable use in connection with the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School. I have to request that you will arrange for the purchase of a wheelbarrow of a type considered satisfactory for the purpose for which it is required. Rev. J. F. J. Marshall,
Indian Residential School,
Sioux Lookout, Ont.
The Secretary,
The Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

At the time of my last visit to the Sioux Lookout School, viz., Nov. 25th and 26th, the floors of the boiler, fuel and engine rooms were being flooded with water which came in through the joints between the sections of the metallic roof. The roof, being almost flat, the snow which melted by the heat of the sun in the day time, ran down to the end and froze during the night. The icy barrier thus formed continued to increase in thickness until it was fully six inches thick at the end at the time of my visit. As the snow melted on the chapel roof and came down on to the flat metal roof over the boiler and engine rooms, the ice thus formed held it up and the level rose until it found its way into the rooms underneath through the vertical joints between the metal sections. The Principal cut away the ice, but it formed again and the leaking process begins whenever the snow on the roof melts. A similar leakage is now going on, I understand, between the infirmary and the chapel, and will undoubtedly cause serious damage if not remedied.

I am furnishing you with this information (1) in order that you may ascertain whether the roof has been completed in accordance with the plans and specifications and (2) that you may take whatever steps you consider necessary to have the roofs made water proof. It has been suggested that the soldering of the vertical joints between the metal sheets of roofing would be the best remedial course to take, and I would recommend that, unless you have some better remedy in view, this action be taken.

Believe me, Sir,

Yours very truly,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.O.

WINNIPEG, MAN. Jan. 7th, 1927.

R. Gunney Orr Esq.,
Architect,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Orr:

I am in receipt of yours of the 4th inst., with a copy of Dr. Westgate's letter with reference to the roof of the new Sioux Lookout School.

The roof over the Boiler, Fuel and Engine rooms was covered with galv. iron, lock joint construction. This roof did not leak during the heavy rainy period.

On account of the snow at the bottom of the roof freezing and turning to ice, there was no outlet for the water when the ice or snow thawed, consequently it seeped through the lock joints to a certain extent. If the roof cannot be kept clear of ice, I consider the only way to make it watertight is to solder the joints far enough up the roof to protect the joints against any water that may lie on the roof in the winter.

Dr. Westgate mentions a leak in the roof between the Infirmary and the Chapel. This trouble is over the Sun Room against the wall of the main building. I understand the snow and ice has formed on the roof of the sun room against the outside wall of the main building. This is caused by the drip from the main building roof falling on the snow on the roof of the Sun room until the ice forms to a thickness above the flashing on the outside wall.

This can be remedied by putting on new flashing high enough to take care of any ice that may form over the roof at this point. This part of the roof did not leak during the heavy rains in the fall.

Mr. Marshall the principal of the School was in my office a few weeks ago and mentioned about the leaks and the ice forming on the roof at these points. I explained to Mr. Marshall to keep the ice off the roof so that the water would have an outlet, and that I would have the roof attended to as soon as the weather was favorable.

Yours very truly,

JH Simmons

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Sir,

On the 15th inst. I inspected the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School.

Piping

Some of the steam piping in the dairy had been broken through frost and was repaired by the principal. A certain amount of piping and elbows is required for the drier in the laundry. This was not put in when the machine was installed, but Mr. Simmons assured me, in the course of our last visit to Winnipeg on the 17th inst., that this would be attended to by the numbers. The laundry fan had no spout, and this will be obtained from the manufacturers.

Roof

A certain amount of water leaks under the roof of the chapel and chapel, due to the freezing of moisture under the roof and to the water backing up, but nothing can be done until Spring, and the resulting damage is small.

Ice forms on the metal roof of the main building, and slides off when a thaw comes, having once damaged an iron fireplace, and in another case breaking the balconies of the school rooms. Mr. Simmons can not see any immediate remedy for this, but suggests the rigging of a wire screen to break up the snow into small pieces. Nothing could be done until Spring, but this year, of course, we have an exceptionally great amount of snow, with repeated thaws to make things still worse.

Electric Lights

These are in operation and satisfactory.

Water

This is not yet laid on, owing to the apparent presence of dirt in the pipes. When the principal recovers from influenza I think he will remedy this, as he understands the system.

Most of the staff have been sick with flu. The housekeeper got up last Saturday after ten days in bed. Miss Johnson, one of the staff, quit owing to the school not being able to have pointed out to the principal and to Dr. Westgate the advisability of arresting recruiting until the work is caught up with. Beds, chapel seats and desks are not yet caught up, and there is much that should be done before pupils are taken in. Mr. Marshall needs a good, handy carpenter and perhaps another man to assist for a month or six weeks.

The Assistant Deputy and Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
or six weeks. He should also get a couple of Indians to cut and pile cordwood for the summer, as all these things should be attended to before receiving pupils. The school otherwise will not function properly, although the members already at the school are quite efficient. These matters were taken up with Dr. Westgate, who will see the principal when the latter is able to visit Winnipeg, perhaps this week.

The principal talked of a boat, and now suggests that Elliott Bros. be instructed to build a suitable hull, which I understand they would do for about $600.00. The principal also suggests that an engine be supplied for installation by the same firm. This, I believe, would be better than sending him a boat with which he might not be well satisfied.

Two boy pupils were at the school last Saturday, and two more expected to arrive last Monday, but I advised the principal not to accept any more until the completion of the various unfinished matters would enable him to look after them to good purpose.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

E/A

Ottawa, January 29th., 1927.

Contract - Sioux Lookout Residential School

Under authority of Order in Council P.C. 1861 of October 21st, 1925, J.H.Simmons was awarded the contract for the construction of the Sioux Lookout Residential School at a cost of $81,755.00 to be paid from the Vote for Indian Education.

Payments were made on this contract under certificates 1 to 8 to the amount of $55,742.01, including $3,987.01 in extras and the work under the contract was apparently completed, the last certificate being issued on August 3rd, 1926.

On August 17th, 1926 a certificate was issued for the payment to J.H.Simmons of $9,327.60 on a contract for "Elevated tank, water supply and fire service, lighting plant and transmission, farm building," in connection with the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School. This contract, the amount of which is given on the certificate as $12,799.00, is apparently a new one made with Mr. Simmons for work not included in the specifications of the former contract. As there appears to be no Order in Council authorizing this latter contract, I shall be obliged if you will inform me as to your authority for awarding it. I shall be obliged if you will let me have a copy of this contract.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

The Deputy Supt.,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6215, file 470-5, part 1)
February 11, 1927

His Excellency
The Governor General in Council,

The undersigned begs to refer to an order of His Excellency in Council, P.C., 1926, October 31st, 1926, awarding the contract for the construction of the Sioux Lookout Residential Indian School at a cost of $81,755.00, chargeable to the appropriation for Indian Education to J.H. Simms, General Contractor, Winnipeg, who was the lowest of five tenders.

When the tenders were called for the exact location of the school or the chosen site was not determined and it was impossible to estimate the cost of certain necessary works and services which were consequently not provided for in the original contracts. As soon as the necessary information as to levels and elevations for the water supply was ascertained, plans and specifications were prepared on which Mr. Simms was asked to submit a price. The amount quoted by him was $12,700.00 covering elevated tank, water supply and fire service, including plant and transmission, farm building and so forth. This was reported to be fair and reasonable by the architect of the Department and the contractor was authorized to proceed with the work. It was understood that the operations should continue and as Mr. Simms had his equipment on the ground and in consideration, moreover, of the isolation of the locality, in an unsettled part of interior, it was not practicable to call in outside competition for these additions.

In the circumstances, the undersigned has the honour to recommend that authority be granted for the expenditure of the sum of $12,700.00 as aforesaid. Funds for this purpose are available from the Appropriation of Indian Education.

S.G.2.2.2.
P.C.
C.C.

Superintendent General
of Indian Affairs.

Feb.11,1927.

To authorize a further expenditure of $12,797.00 for payment of accounts of J.H.Simmons, General Contractor, Winnipeg, for work done on the Sioux Lookout Residential Indian School in addition to that provided for by P.C. 1861. The procedure in his matter was usual, but the Auditor-General for the first time, asked the Department to obtain the authority of council for the additional expenditure. This school is situated in an unsettled part of Ontario where building operations are necessarily difficult and it would not have been in the interest of the Department to have made a separate contract for these necessary adjuncts for the main building.
Certified to be a true copy of a Minute of a Meeting of the Committee of the Privy Council, approved by His Excellency the Governor General on the 21st FEBRUARY 1927.

The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a report, dated 11th February, 1927, from the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, with reference to Order in Council (P.C.1861) dated October 21st, 1925, awarding the contract for the construction of the Sioux Lookout Residential Indian School at a cost of $61,755, chargeable to the appropriation for Indian Education, to J. H. Simmons, General Contractor, Winnipeg, who was the lowest of five tenderers.

When the tenders were called for, the exact location of the school on the chosen site was not determined and it was impossible to estimate the cost of certain necessary works and services which were consequently not provided for in the original contract. As soon as the necessary information as to levels and elevations for the water supply was ascertained, plans and specifications were prepared on which Mr. Simmons was asked to submit a price. The amounts quoted by him, in all $12,799, covering elevated tank, water supply and fire service, lighting plant and transmission, farm building and so forth, were reported to be fair and reasonable by the architect of the Department and the contractor was authorized to proceed with the work. As it was urgent that the operations should continue and

The Honourable
the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs.

March 2nd, 1927.

Sir:

On the 26th ult. I inspected the Indian Residential School at Sioux Lookout, and found things in a bad way, owing to the principal's having had to go away following a mental breakdown resulting from influenza. At the time of my last visit, on January 15th, the water was not yet laid on, but the principal then expected it would be running in a few days. He was then in bed with influenza. On the 24th ult. I found there was still no water supply, and things were accordingly at a standstill.

I returned to Winnipeg on Sunday the 27th and saw Mr. Inspector Bunn, who had been visited by the principal, Mr. Marshall. They had considered the advisability of putting in temporary pipes above ground, but I questioned the wisdom of this, and on Monday the 28th I arranged for a meeting at the office of Mr. Simmons the contractor, to include Messrs. Bunn, J.H. Simmons, and Mr. Beirsto the plumbing contractor besides myself.

It was decided, in the circumstances, to send a plumber immediately to rectify the trouble. One was sent, therefore, on the 4.30 train from Winnipeg, and if water can not be promptly set running, a temporary arrangement will be made, and a report sent to this office. These instructions were issued without the authority of the Department, owing to the urgency, but with the approval and advice of Mr. Inspector Bunn.

As soon as the water is running it will be possible to proceed with a vigorous recruiting campaign.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

The Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6215, file 470-5, part 1)
Winnipeg, 4th March, 1927.

The Asst. Deputy & Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Sir:

Re Water Supply at Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School.

On the 24th, the Rev'd Principal, Mr. Marshall, called at my office; he is still a sick man, and he has been sick since the beginning of January, 1927; he has been a victim of the prevailing epidemic of "Flu."

He called to discuss the matter of water supply. After he explained the situation, he submitted a suggestion to put in a temporary water main. He got prices and other details of the expense in this reference; these he handed me on Saturday the 26th, and it was my intention to place his scheme before you for consideration. I held over until Monday, which was fortunate, as on the evening of the 26th Mr. Agent Edwards arrived in Winnipeg from Sioux Lookout. He phoned to me about 7:30 in the evening and by appointment I met him at 4 p.m. on the 27th, and this matter of the "water Supply" came up. We agreed to meet at the office of the contractor, Mr. J.H. Simmons at 10 a.m. on Monday the 28th, so that the situation could be intelligently discussed.

The conclusion arrived at was that it would be best to have a man who knew the layout, visit and examine to locate the cause of the trouble. This has been done, and this morning the man was at Mr. Simmons' office. I met him, and he has pretty definitely located the difficulty in the water main that prevents water flowing as it should, but he cannot say if it is frozen or some other obstruction. As it is imperative to get the water main to operate with the least possible delay, I consented to have this man, who can do the work well, go down with the least possible delay and to dig down to the place where the obstruction is and to remove same. Failing this, a temporary intake is to be installed so that the institution will be furnished with a sufficient supply of water. The conditions that obtain demand this immediate action, as any delay might cause serious harm and damage.

I have sent a copy of this letter to Mr. Agent Edwards as it was.
was promised to so that he would be closely in touch with the action that was decided upon.

The protracted illness of the Principal has been very unfortunate; if his attention to this detail had been available it is my opinion that the situation would have been relieved in a satisfactory manner in good time.

The Principal has gone away for a short rest; he was a victim of a severe attack of the "Flu", and physically unfit to be on the job.

I submit this explanation to you and trust that you will approve of the action taken; it was the only way to get a supply of water in the shortest time, at the least expense, for the school.

I have the honor to be,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Sir,

Referring to my letter of the 2nd instant, re Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School.

I have today received a letter from Mr J. H. Simmons the Contractor, and he informs me that the Plumber has returned from the School, and reports that the pipe line to the lake is stopped up, plugged, or frozen. In making his test he put in about 40 gal of water in the main pipe, at the pump, the water would not go approximately beyond the front of the main building. The plumber proposed putting down a temporary pipe to the lake, but this is not his idea, he has suggested to set the pipe into the ground for about 40 ft (2' to 3') otherwise the pipe would be too high for the pump to draw water. As the pipe will only draw a certain height.

Mr Simmons proposes that the plumber return to Pelican and digs down to the 4" pipe line near the front of the school, bore a hole in the pipe and see if it is frozen, if so try and thaw it out if possible. If this cannot be done the pipe can be rushed to Hudson by first freight.

The plumber states the building is in an awful state, the water, water, water. The toilets, urinals, &c are all full up. He also states they are liable to block up the sewer system if they cannot properly flush the toilets after using. The return steam line in the laundry is frozen up. They are not using the radiator in this part of the building. I believe the plumber had better fix this up whilst he is on the job.

Mr Simmons also says that if something is not done in a hurry to give them water the staff are liable to quit.

Under the circumstances, the only thing to do was to agree to the suggestions of Mr Simmons, and give him authority to go ahead as he suggested, I was on the phone with Mr Simmons this morning and told him I would approve providing he got in touch with Inspector Bunn and he also agreed, I believe this is the cheapest and best solution, but in a case like this it had to take the initiative, there being no time to get the necessary authority from the Department.

I trust you will approve what I have done and send me the necessary authority for the vouchers.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

P.S. The whole trouble is caused, in my opinion, by the Church authorities not giving the principal authority to go ahead as he requested.

Pursuant to our conversation concerning the water supply in connection with the Sioux Lookout School, I beg to say:

CANADA
As instructed, I proceeded to Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School and examined it on the 19th and 20th inst. I beg to report as follows:

Due to a temporary operation of the pump, water lying in the pipes of the suction line from the lake had frozen. The radiators and pipes in the laundry had also frozen up and broken. These things are now attended to, being in good shape, and water is pumped to the tank, which leaks somewhat from disuse, but this is expected to correct itself.

All this work was done by Messrs Beaird Ltd., who had done the work for the contractor Mr. J. H. Simmons, and their charges, while high, appear reasonable and just. The entire trouble arose from the severe illness and absence from duty of the principal and staff. The former is now convalescing from a mental breakdown, and Mr. Campbell is acting pro tem. The principal's return is expected.

A list of required tools and spare fittings has been sent to Rev. Dr. Westgate for reference to Mr. Inspector Bunn, who has authority to purchase some tools, and can get these in this way.

There is sufficient clothing for about a dozen each of boys and girls, and shorter in quilts and bedspreads. Blanket and sheet materials await the arrival of seamstress and laundress, which is being arranged.

Mr. Inspector Bunn has instructions to ship linoleum, carpets etc., but is holding this until the principal returns. The chapel seats and furniture have not yet arrived.

Rev. Dr. Westgate has authorized employment of two Indians and their wives for wood-cutting and scrubbing, the building being in filthy condition from previous lack of water.

Enclosed herewith please find requisition for drugs required at the school.

The Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs.
Ottawa.

E/A
The school also requires three classroom clocks, a kitchen clock, and a few cheap alarm clocks.

It appears to me that the Department can take no blame for the delay in the opening of the school, the principal's illness being the main reason. He seems to be a splendid, capable man, in whose absence difficulties accumulated.

I do not know what arrangements have been made for payment for equipment, bedding and clothing, but I gathered from Dr. Westgate that everything is being charged to the Department, including salaries and expenses of the staff. I do not know whether I am misinformed in this matter, but draw your attention to it. I believe the church authorities should be persuaded to rush matters and receive pupils so as to get on a grant-earning basis and reduce the present heavy expenses with their inadequate returns.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

P.S. Since writing the above I have received a telegram from the acting principal saying the water system is again out of commission, and as I only returned to Regina late last night, and as Mr. Emmott or Dunn knows our difficulties I have wired him to see Dr. Westgate and the plumbers and take what action he may think advisable.

If the water supply is put right and the necessary clothing and equipment arrives the school should be able to take pupils by May first.
Ottawa, March 28, 1927.

Dear Sir:

I have gone into this matter with the principal and with the General Superintendent of Can. National Telegraphs, and am informed that for $500 the company would erect two iron wires, to give a telephone line from the school to Sioux Lookout. For $325 it would be possible to run an additional iron wire beside the present Michel Chemical Co.'s line, but this has many disadvantages and receives no recommendation from either the principal or the telegraph company. In either case a wire would have to be laid from Mile 5 on the railway to the school, a distance of approximately 3,200 feet. The greater part of this would skirt the lake and be free from danger from falling trees. The line could be attached to the trees with sling insulators to allow for sway.

I would suggest that the line from the track to the school be constructed by the staff, with casual help, for which I presume we would have to pay. The cost of this part I would estimate at $150 including instruments.

I believe we would have to pay a rental of about $70 per annum plus $25 for upkeep to the telegraph company, but I would recommend immediate installation of the line as an economical way of ensuring communication with the school, with many consequent savings.

I should be glad to receive instructions in this regard.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

Re:- Water Supply at Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School.

Sir:

I have the honour to submit the following report on the water system as installed at Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School.

On or about December 5th, 1926, J. H. Simmons, Contractor, completed the laying of the water main from the school to the lake. Part of this water main was put down when the thermometer registered 40 below zero, and was encased in ice. It will, therefore, be understood that the water system could not be put to test, until the weather moderated sufficiently to prevent different parts of the water main from freezing.

During a mild spell on or about February 22nd, the pump was put into operation and sufficient water to reach the taps in the basement was had, but no more. On examination of the foot-valve, in the well, several rather large chips of wood and twigs were found. This debris was taken from the above mentioned valve and is now held in the office at the school. The pump was again put into operation, when the next mild spell permitted, and no water was obtained; but, as there was considerable suction noticeable it was evident that there was a complete blockage somewhere in the line.

I left for Winnipeg on February 23rd, on sick-leave, and as a result of my complaint to Mr. Inspector Bunn, Mr. Cooper, of the Beristo Plumbing Co., was sent to the school in order to ascertain the cause of the failure of the water supply. Mr. Cooper arrived at the school on March 2nd, and returned to Winnipeg the same date, stating that he intended to return to the school as soon as possible, with men and pipe.

On March 7th, Mr. Cooper and two men, with equipment, arrived from Winnipeg, and immediately commenced excavating to reach the water main. On March 9th the water main was reached, stoppage...
located and released. The pump was again put into operation, but a tremendous suction indicated further stoppage. Excavations were again made in two places and it was found that the water line had been frozen. On March 12th all stoppages were released and water was running through all connections in the school.

Before going any further in this report, it would be well to state, that upon excavation a considerable portion of the water main was found encased in ice, resulting, no doubt, in the water gradually freezing as it came in contact with the cold pipe.

On March 14th, the water main to the overhead tank was clear, and although considerable water was discharged into the tank the leakage was so great that it was found impossible to keep a fire in the stove below. On this date the pump drew considerable air and was not functioning properly. On March 16th Mr. Cooper and his men left for Wpg., and although there was a considerable supply of water available it was noticed that the pump drew a considerable amount of air, this Mr. Cooper suggested as being due to air locks. Here I may say that the engine ran almost continuously from this date until 4 A.M. of March 21st, when the Engineer reported that no water was being received into the building. Everything possible was done to ascertain the cause of the trouble, but without success, and Dr. Westgate was advised accordingly.

On March 26th a Plumber arrived from Wpg. and in the afternoon of the same date the water system was again in full operation, the plumber having stated that the pump was at fault. This plumber remained at the school until April 8th, during which time the water supply again failed, and has not since been in operation.

The general consensus of opinion is that the lake level has dropped to a point beyond the capacity of the pump at present installed in Sioux Lookout Residential School, which pump is known as a 5x5 Typhoon Pump. To arrive at this conclusion several experiments were carried out, the most notable and convincing being the shutting off of the in-take gate-valve and raising the level of the water, within the well, to 2' 3" above the lake level. On starting the pump—without raising—it was found that it immediately took hold of the water and lost it again when the lake level was reached. Other experiments have been carried out and all point to the trouble being found either in the...
I may state for your information that there is evidence to show that the lake level has dropped during the past winter 2' 6". I should also like to state that the water levels are, at times, controlled by the winds and it has been noted that the water supply was at its best when a S.E. wind was blowing, and at its worst when a W. wind was blowing.

I trust that is is not necessary to bring to your notice the disagreeable, and almost unbearable conditions arising from a non-supply of water to an Institution such as the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School, and I fear that unless we are again given the necessary water supply an epidemic of typhoid fever will result.

I have suggested to Inspector Bunn the advisability of having an Evernude Double Cycle Forest Fire Pump on hand, as fire protection, owing to the fact that the C.N.R. track runs through school property which is thickly wooded. This pump could be used as an auxiliary pump until such time as a capable pump is installed at the school. It would then serve a two-fold purpose, and I cannot too strongly recommend this purchase.

I would ask that you give this matter your favorable consideration.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

J. F. J. Marshall, Principal.

[Signature]

ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Winnipeg, 11th April, 1927.

The Asst. Deputy & Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Sir:

This evening I sent the following telegram with reference to the water supply for Indian Residential School at the Sioux Lookout School.

"Water difficulties Sioux Lookout remain unsolved.
"Pump installed fails to deliver water into the tank at present lake level.
"Agent, Principal and myself suggest temporary immediate solution by providing fire pump capacity equal to pump now installed to raise water in well six feet and therewith three hundred feet of hose. Reply urgent."

After a thorough investigation in expense and time required to do this in a careful manner, the Principal has definitely come to the conclusion that the pump that is now installed cannot operate with the present lake level, the lift is more than the capacity of the pump can handle.

The problem was fully discussed today in my office between the Agent, the Principal and myself and as a result the fact was established that the pump installed will work effectively and well with the water in the well at a six foot level, and this was proven by raising the water in the well by baling to a level of six feet and it was found that the pump installed now took hold every time without priming and delivered water into the tank under these conditions.

Now to keep the water at a level of six feet in the well we came to the conclusion that by providing a fire pump such as has been suggested this can be maintained and the flow of water to the tank would be assured.

I held the above over pending a reply to my wire, this has just come to hand. Principal Marshall was in the office when it arrived, and he was very glad to receive the good news.
We will take immediate steps to secure the fire pump and the hose and have them placed for operation and I feel that we can be reasonably assured of a favorable outcome.

I might also add that the fire pump will be a very useful unit to have on the premises for fire protection of the buildings and from any possible bush fires. In the summer of 1926 there were two bush fires that caused a good deal of worry and trouble.

I am enclosing herewith a report received from the Principal wherein he fully details the troubles and difficulties that have occurred in connection with the water main and the water supply arrangements, and unfortunately during a great part of the period the Principal was absent on account of a very serious attack of the prevailing "Flu", so that his experience and good judgement was unavailable. He returned from sick leave on the 28th March, he went down to Sioux Lookout the next day and by his careful examinations we have had a very full measure of intelligent light on the situation that I feel has resulted in a good solution of the trouble. He will be on hand and see that the fire pump is placed in with the least possible delay.

I have the honor to be,

Your obedient servant

Inspector of Indian Agencies.

May 7th, 1927.

Sir:

As requested in your letter of April 13th I have made a number of inquiries with reference to the water works system at the Sioux Lookout Indian School. In taking the matter up with Mr. Simmons he referred me to Mr. Cooper, foreman in charge of the plumbing and installation of the water works system. The evidence submitted is most convincing and satisfactory and shows what was actually done and how the suction end of the system was actually installed. The pipe from the well to the school was supposed to be laid in a direct line, but if one can believe some of the statements made it would appear that in order to avoid some really high points in the rock that the pipe line was laid indirectly to the school and contains a number of 45 and 90 degree bends and also that possibly there is a considerable hump in the line.

I sent one of my engineers, who was going to Sioux Lookout on other work, over to the Indian School to check the elevation of the water level and observe the same that with the present water level the suction lift is only 14 feet, so that at extreme low water the maximum lift would only be 18 feet. The pump should handle this quite easily. Under the circumstances I am inclined to think that the trouble is either directly in the pump or in the improper laying of the suction line. It would then become necessary that the pump should be to uncover the suction line and if the fault is found there to re-lay it in the correct manner. It is possible that the uncovering and relaying of the pipe will cost in the neighborhood of $400.00. If you will authorise this expenditure I will have one of my engineers take the matter in hand and have the pipe laid over again and take a good pump-man to Sioux Lookout to check the pump and pipe line.

I have heard that the Rev. Mr. Marshall was in the city this week, though I did not see him. I understand he has returned to Sioux Lookout with the intention of lowering the setting of the pump several feet. I have taken liberty to write to Mr. Marshall advising him that in my opinion the setting of the pump is not the fault and that I am writing you regarding the matter and have suggested to Mr. Marshall that he leave the pump setting alone until I have received your reply, or he has received instructions from you.

Yours truly,

C. H. Attwood,
District Chief Engineer.

R. Gurney Orr, Esq.,
Chief Architect,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

May 4, 1927.

MEMORANDUM: The Honourable Charles Stewart.

A suitable motor boat is required for the use of the new Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School, which is situated on Pelican Lake. This boat is required in order that the school can communicate with Sioux Lookout, the nearest point for supplies, and a distance of approximately eight miles across the lake.

Last fall the following firms were asked to quote:

J. & J., Stone, Kenora, Ont.
The Casey Boat Works, Kenora, Ont.
The Parrott Boat Co., Kenora, Ont.
Betchum Boats Ltd., Gravenhurst, Ont.
Gidley Boat Co., Penetanguishene, Ont.

From the boats offered and the prices submitted the Architect of the Department has recommended the purchase of a Gidley Boat, equipped with a Ford Marine engine. The price for a 26 foot boat is £2,350.00, and I would recommend for your consideration the purchase of this boat.

[Signature]

Deputy Superintendent General.

Dear Sir:

Enclosed you will please find plan and profile of the 4" suction main for the water supply system at the Sioux Lookout Indian School. This information was obtained by Mr. Mooney of this office, after you had uncovered the suction pipe.

The Plan "A" shows the suction pipe as laid and Plan "B" the suction pipe as I consider it should be laid, eliminating a number of the 45° and 90° bends. The portion of the suction pipe it is necessary to re-lay is shown on the profile in red. This, as you will note, will entail a fairly large amount of excavation, running to about three feet at the deepest part.

Will you please arrange to have this work done as expeditiously as possible, in order that the water supply for the school may be put into satisfactory condition.

In view of the fact that the trouble is entirely due to the suction main not being properly laid, I do not consider that the Department of Indian Affairs should be put to any expense in connection with this work. The pipe line when laid and before being covered will be inspected and must meet with my approval.

MEMORANDUM

To - Mr. J. D. McLean, Assistant Deputy & Secretary, Dept. of Indian Affairs.

Re - Water Supply - Sioux Lookout School.

Complying with the request stated in your letter of May 11th, I have taken up the matter of water supply of the Sioux Lookout School with Mr. J. H. Simmons, the contractor, and with Mr. Beairsto, the sub-contractor for the plumbing. From the information obtained from these gentlemen it was apparent that the trouble was either in the pump itself or in the suction line to the pump. Further information obtained from Mr. Beairsto's foreman was that the pipe to the intake pump had been overhauled and found to be in perfect condition. Accordingly it was arranged with Mr. Simmons that he write to the Rev. J. F. Marshall, Principal of the school, asking Mr. Marshall to have the suction between the pump and intake well uncovered at Mr. Simmons' expense. While this was done an engineer from this office secured a profile of the line and noted the condition of the pipe as laid.

From the survey made by our engineer the attached plan has been prepared showing the line from the intake pump together with a profile of the line. The profile shows that a hump of about feet existed in the line between the well and the pump which caused an air trap in the line and prevented the pump from operating. In addition to the hump it is also noted that a number of unnecessary 45 and 90° angles had been placed in the line and these in themselves, even if the line had been properly laid to grade, would reduce the efficiency of the suction line.

To correct the present faulty installation it is the intention to have the suction main re-laid from about Station 70 to a point about Station 275 to the proposed grade shown in the attached plan. With this grade there should be no trouble from air traps, etc. It is also the intention to have a number of the bends omitted, as a number that were used originally are unnecessary. A plan of the present suction main, together with fittings used, is shown on Plan "A" while Fig. 1 is a plan of that proposed together with the fittings considered necessary.

In the first instance the suction line was improperly laid and I consider that any expense in connection with the correcting of this line to put it in proper condition should be borne by the contractor. I have accordingly advised Mr. Simmons to make effort and have instructed him to re-lay the pipe, at the same time informing him that I consider the work should be done at his own expense.

W. H. FORD
District Chief Engineer.

Dear Sir:

On July 1st when I visited Ottawa, I made a verbal report to the Superintendent of Indian Education, on conditions as I found them at the new Sioux Lookout School a few days previously, and was advised to address a separate letter to you in connection with the following items:

1. Cement foundations are required under the tool house and under the ice house, if these buildings are to be kept in good repair. The stock barn and the poultry house have cement foundations, and I recommend that the two buildings I have mentioned be provided with the same.

2. As the walls of all the out buildings have been painted, but not the shingled roofs, I beg to recommend that these be painted as a help to preservation. The Principal recommends that they be painted green.

3. In the process of clearing the land, the Principal found considerable timber which he considered might advantageously be cut into lumber and stored for future use such as repairs, fencing, erection of woodshed or other buildings, bridges, etc. He informed me that he could have this cut at the rate of $15 per thousand, whereas the price of the same if purchased would cost $35 per thousand. As the timber may not be exchanged for lumber, and it does not seem quite wise to have the better logs converted into fuel, the Principal would like an authorization to have approximately 20,000 feet of lumber cut and stored for future use.

4. The verandah at the west end of the main school building, and the verandah attached to the Principal's residence have not been screened in, and I beg to request that this be done. The flies and mosquitoes at this time of year in
that part of the country are troublesome beyond description.

5. The question of providing some sort of store room at the Pelican railway siding is one which has not yet been definitely settled. That it is very necessary, I am well assured. As the Railway Company would expect, I believe, an annual rental if such building were erected on their property, it seems to me that the building should have to be erected on the School land nearest the railway siding to escape the rental charges, or else an effort should be made to have the Railway Company provide a sufficiently large unloading platform where supplies could be kept under cover of a tarpaulin until removed. I shall be very grateful if your Department will do your best to meet this School's need in this respect.

Believe me, Sir,

Yours very truly,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.
Ottawa, July 18, 1927.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 7th instant, with reference to buildings at the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School. You might have the Rev. Principal secure an estimate of the cost of placing cement foundations under the tool house and ice house. This should be forwarded to the Department for further consideration. I regret that I cannot authorize the painting of the shingled roofs of the outbuildings.

You may authorize the Principal to send sufficient timber for twelve or fifteen thousand feet, which would be cut into lumber and stored for future use, at a cost of $15 per thousand. You may also authorize the Rev. Principal to screen in the veranda at the west end of the main building. The materials only will be provided by the Department. The labour should be done by the school.

I regret there are no funds for the purpose of erecting a ware house at Pelican Siding.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Dear Sir:

Reference your letter of August 11th, file 129-6-5.

I regret very much to have to advise that completion of the work with regard to the telephone circuit between Sioux Lookout and Pelican Lake will have to be delayed a matter of about one month from this date.

An inspection of our line in that section shows that there are more side blocks than will permit of satisfactory operation of wires and we have accordingly arranged to build a new six-pin crossarm to take care of these extra wires. The delay is caused through our inability to secure extra gangmen at this time, either for ourselves or from the other Telegraph Company and our own gangs are tied up in work which will not permit them to be available until a time approximately as above stated.

The work, however, is being kept constantly before us and will be completed at the earliest possible moment.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

RWB/G
General Superintendent.

Dear Sir,

Re: Sioux Lookout School.

On July 1st when I visited Ottawa, I made a verbal report to the Superintendent of Indian Education on conditions as I found them at the new Sioux Lookout School a few days previously, and was advised to address a separate communication to you in connection with the following items:

1. The metal roof of the engine room, and part of the roof of the hall-way, have become seriously impaired through the large pieces of ice which have fallen upon them from the roof of the chapel above. One hand rail of a fire escape has also been seriously damaged by a large piece of ice which fell from the roof of the main school building, and one hand rail and part of the steps forming the outside entrance to the chapel have been broken in the same way. The Principal informed me that one piece of ice which fell from the roof of the main school building was 8 feet long, 14 inches thick, and must have weighed about 400 lbs. The accumulation of ice along the eaves of the main school building and chapel is probably due to the fact that the temperature of the roof within the walls is raised by the heat from the central heating plant, while that part which extends beyond the walls remains unaffected, and causes the melted snow to freeze as fast as it runs down and accumulate. The best remedy is not very apparent, but I feel it my duty to submit the matter to you for your careful consideration. The joints of the roof of the engine room, and that of the hall-way should be soldered, but this will not prevent the accumulation of ice referred to above.

2. Rain water soaked through the basement walls throughout practically the whole of the building, and for a time flooded the floors. The Principal informed me that he dug down in three places to see if the walls had been tarred on the outside, and in each case found that this had been done. He
suggests, (1) that the whole of the main school building be surrounded by a platform of cement not less than 10 feet wide, (2) that the spaces on either side of the front entrance to the main school building be completely covered with cement, and (3) that the spaces on either side of the chapel be likewise covered with cement, the surface throughout to slope gradually away from the building. I recommend this suggestion to your careful consideration.

3. The elevated water tank has not been supplied with any gauge, and this should be done. Any gauge which would indicate the amount of water in the tank would be sufficient.

4. A lever should be installed in the laundry room which would enable all the laundry machinery to be thrown out of action at once, should necessity arise. At present this can only be done by the operator going some distance along one corridor, then back through another to the engine room.

Two shaft brackets should also be added in the engine room for the purpose of strength and security.

The pulley on the shaft in the laundry room for operating the extractor is considered by the Principal to be too large, and one of smaller dimensions should be supplied.

5. The Typhoon pump installed in the engine room is one of a class which is no longer manufactured, and repairs or new parts will soon be unobtainable. The Principal informed me that the firm who supplied it will exchange it for their latest model at a small additional cost, and I beg to recommend that the exchange be made.

6. The Principal was informed by Mr. Mooney of the Dominion Water Powers Department when he visited the School to report on the water system at the request of your Department, that a building having so much metal on the roof should be provided with lightning conductors. I beg to submit this information for your consideration.

Believe me, Sir,

Yours very truly,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

Indian Residential School,
Sioux Lookout, Ont.
Replying to your letter #129-6-5 of 28th June last re account for $196.70 Bearstoe Ltd repairs to Indian School at Sioux Lookout School.

This account was originally received by me, and handed over to Contractor J. H. Simmons at Inspector Bunns office in Winnipeg, as the Rev Principal Marshall informed us the account included time of men spent in rectifying their own mistake, and he did not think it should be paid. Mr Simmons promised to look into the account and have it amended, as regards the materials used this was put into the by-pass connecting the intake to the pressure pipe, and was used by the contractors for priming the intake pipe. At the present time the Principal says the system fixed is only a decoration, and if they wish to take it out they are at liberty to do so. Mr Cooper, Bearstoe's man admitted taking away two lengths of the pipe.

However I was in Winnipeg last Friday and saw Contractor Simmons, he promised to go into the matter with Mr Bearstoe and have him submit a corrected account.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

"COPI"

SIOUX LOOKOUT INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

Sioux Lookout, Ont.,
August 27th, 1927.

Dear Mr. Craig,

In reply to your letter of August 25th regarding the finishing up of our water troubles I may say that we are now working under very pleasant circumstances and the credit of the pleasure we put at your door.

I purposely deferred the filling in of the water line until we had filled and emptied the tank a number of times so as to be positive that we had no leaks. When none showed up I had the men commence the refilling on Monday August 15th. They finished on Wednesday August 17th.

I am enclosing a copy of my letter to Mr. Simmons and also a copy of his reply for your information.

I am indeed pleased to report that this water system is at last satisfactory and wish to thank you for your very valuable assistance in securing this satisfaction for us.

I intend to be in the city next week and will call at your office.

Yours faithfully,

(Sgd.) John P.J. Marshall,
Principal.

Mr. J. Craig,
706 Commercial Building,
Winnipeg, Man.

Form No. 101.
Dear Sir,

In replying to your letter of Sept. 6th No. 129-8-5 regarding the root house needed for this school I may say that I realize that nothing definite can be done towards the type of root house suitable for the conditions prevailing here this fall as its utterly impossible to obtain the gravel until freeze up to put in the foundation. No barge is to be had for this purpose as it ruins a barge and it would kill horses to have to haul gravel over the roads in their present condition.

However if we were assured of the Department under taking to build one for next year we could commence to excavate in the proposed location and use the excavation for a pit for this winter as no other solution seems feasible. This of course is going to be very inconvenient but there seems to be no alternative.

I would like the root house to have a basement cemented 24ft x 40ft. with a house on top to be used as a work shop and at one end partitioned off for two rooms where we could accommodate any extra help we happened to have. These men would naturally keep the place sufficiently warm to insure against freezing.

I figured roughly that the approximate cost would be about two thousand dollars.

I intend going east for the Wycliffe Jubilee Convention Sept. 21st to 26th and I was anticipating returning by Ottawa and if it would be convenient I would like to talk this matter over so that together we could come to a satisfactory decision.

Yours faithfully,

Rev. John F.J. Marshall,
Principal.

Ottawa, September 15, 1927.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 10th instant, relative to the providing of a root house for the use of the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School.

In reply I beg to say that you may arrange for the excavation of a pit which would be suitable for the storage of roots this coming winter and could later be used for the proposed new root house. It is expected that the school staff will perform the labour. Any other expense will be paid upon receipt of a properly certified voucher, in duplicate, in the usual manner.

We note that you anticipate visiting Ottawa in the near future, and you should, at that time, bring your proposal for the erection of a new root house next year to the attention of the Department.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Indian Residential School,
Sioux Lookout, Ont.
Sir:

In reply to your letter 129-6-15 of the 18th ult., regarding Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School, I beg to deal with the various paragraphs as follows:

The principal requests the building of a root-house and store-house about 24' x 40', consisting of a cement cellar about 7' high for vegetables, with a room adjoining for a man, so that a stove could be put in. The store house built above this would be for stores, tools etc. This could not be built now, but if authority were given, the principal could put men on excavation, and gravel could be taken to the site in winter for construction next spring.

The railway spur is now put in by the Company, and I would suggest supplying lumber for a small shed to be built there by the school authorities.

Telephone poles are in position, but wires and instruments not yet installed.

In reply to your 129-6-5 of the 1st inst., I enclose herewith voucher for $452.00 payable to Mr. Simmons for repairs to the pipe-line. I presume we are liable for this, but am not sure, as this was done to rectify what appears to have been a contractor's mistake. As regards Messrs. Beakisto's accounts, I am sending them to Mr. Simmons as I have my doubts as to whether the Department should pay them.

Your obedient servant,

Frank Edwards,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, September 24, 1927.

Sir:

With reference to that portion of your letter of the 7th instant, regarding the building of a root house and store house at the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School, I now beg to inform you that we have instructed the Principal to arrange for the excavation of a pit which would be suitable for the storage of roots this coming winter and could later be used for the proposed new root house. It is expected that the school staff will perform the labour, but any other expense will be paid upon receipt of a properly certified voucher.

Relative to the erection of a small shed on the railway spur, I beg to inform you that Rev. Dr. Westgate was requested to consult you regarding the taking up of this matter with the railway company in an endeavour to secure from them an old box car that would be suitable for the purpose required. I shall be pleased if you will take this matter up with the railway company and endeavour to obtain an old box car, which could be placed in a suitable location on the spur line. I shall be pleased to hear later as to whether you have been able to have this arrangement carried out.

With reference to the completion of the telephone line and the installation of the instrument, I beg to say that the Canadian National Telegraphs informed the Department that it would be near the end of September before they could complete this work.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Frank Edwards, 284.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.
