Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6215, file 470-5, part 1)
Sir,

In reply to your letter 129-6-15 of the 16th ult regarding Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School I beg to deal with the various paragraphs as follows:

Par.1. Dr. Westgate's information is correct. A report as to the fire-escape and roof has already been sent to the Department. We have asked the contractor, Mr. Simmons who does not think we shall have ice slides again, as he considers this was due in some measure to new material, but I would suggest that authority be given for repairs to the fire-escape etc. and also that a cheap post and rail fence be put around the main building, to protect children from any possibility of injury from sliding ice and snow.

The contractor thinks, with reference to the soldering of joints, that this should be done, but will make a further report.

Par.2. The contractor informs me that water seeps through the basement walls because no weeping drains were put in. To do this now would cost about $1.00 per foot. He would not recommend a cement platform, as this would cost about $3.00 per foot, and there would still be seepage. The cement work in any case could not be done until next spring, as the gravel, being at some distance from the school, can only be taken there in winter by team.

Par.3. I would suggest that the principal receive authority to purchase pulleys and necessary materials, and he could put in a suitable gauge himself at a cost of a few dollars.

Par.4. A lever, two shaft brackets and pulley are required. The principal will send me prices for these at an early date.

Par.5. The typhoon pump should be exchanged. I believe this can be done for $100 or less, and parts can then be obtained at all times.

The Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

R/A
at all times.

Par.6. I interviewed Mr. Darby of Winnipeg, an expert on lightning conductors, and he suggests we should have them installed on the barn, and that six points and ground wires be placed on the main school building. Would you like me to get prices on this?

The principal wishes us to purchase a sectional ladder, so that the roof can be reached. He also wishes construction of a small porch over the chapel entrance, to avoid danger from sliding snow.

The height of the bottom of the water tank is sixty feet. The height of the school building is seventy feet, so that there is not sufficient water pressure for fire-protection on the upper stories. Mr. Craig of the Water Power Branch suggests that a cut-off be installed between the pump and the tank, so that in case of fire the pump could be kept going and make a direct supply to the fire hydrants. This would not be expensive.

The principal also wishes to purchase a stove for heating laundry irons at a cost of about $30.00. Mr. Bunn suggested that the school purchase electric irons and that we should pay for the necessary wiring, but Rev. Dr. Westgate referred me to your letter 116-1-12 of May 11th last informing him such appliances may not be used in Indian schools supplying their own power.

With reference to your letter 129-6-9 of July 15th to Rev. Dr. Westgate regarding employment of men on the road, I may say the Rev. Principal would be glad to receive an accountable cheque for $500.00 to pay wages, as he has no available cash. In this way he could hire men when required.

The principal requests the building of a root-house and store-house, about 24' x 40', consisting of a cement cellar about 7' high for vegetables, with a room adjoining for a man, so that a stove could be put in. The store house built above this would be for stores, tools etc. This could not be built now, but if authority were given, the principal could put men on excavation, and gravel could be taken to the site in winter for construction next spring.

The railway spur is now put in by the company, and I would suggest supplying lumber for a small shed to be built there by the school authorities.

Telephone poles are in position, but wires and instruments not yet installed.

In reply to your 129-6-5 of the 1st inst I enclose herewith voucher for $62.00 payable to Mr. Simmons for repairs to the pavilion. I imagine we are liable for this, but am not sure, as this was done to rectify what appears to have been a contractor's mistake. As regards Messrs. Beairsto's accounts, I am sending them to Mr. Simmons, as I have my doubts as to whether the Department should pay them.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

CANADA
Kenora, Ontario,
October 22nd, 1927.

Sir:

I wired you from Winnipeg yesterday Re. the intake of the water supply pipe at Sioux Lookout school.

The first information I got of any trouble was a telegram from the school at the beginning of the month, and as I was unable to visit them I wired Inspector Bunn of Winnipeg to send a man down from the water power Branch. Mr. Mooney went down, and Mr. Atwood reported fully to you in his memorandum of October 19th. Apparently the pipe was not taken out far enough into the lake as per instructions from the water power branch by Mr. Simmons. This work was done last fall in extremely cold weather and presumably Mr. Simmons' men did not carry out instructions, thinking no doubt that the pipe was far enough out. I do not think Mr. Simmons himself knew about this, I certainly did not. The principal of the school had arrived and I was not able to visit the school much at that time. The work was done on force account. I suggest that temporary measures be used for this winter and that a coffer dam and pipe be carried out further next spring. I would also respectfully suggest that the water power branch be asked to superintend the work owing to the distance from Kenora it is impossible for me to visit there very often.

Immediate instructions are necessary to enable the school to get water for the winter. I believe temporary arrangements can be made by the water power branch for the sum not more than a couple of hundred dollars. And I should be glad if you would wire Inspector Bunn, The Water Power Branch or myself, if you have not already done so.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

The Assistant Deputy & Secretary
Dept. Of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Referring to your letter of the 28th, Re. shelter at Pelican. I think you must have misunderstood my letter, as at the present time I am not trying to arrange stops for trains at Pelican spur. All I wish to know is, if you could supply me with two old box cars to be put off at the spur for the benefit of the school, so that they could store perishable goods in same. The new spur was put in, not for carloading, as we do not ship much from Pelican, but as a receiving spur. Kindly let me know if you could supply the cars as previously requested.

Dear Sir;-

Further in connection with your request for freight shelter at Pelican passing track,

The last full line of my letter to you should have read car load proposition and not car loading proposition.

I took this matter up with Mr. Moodie before replying to you, and he suggested that we could not consistently establish another point for handling of L.C.L. freight, but I am taking no action to stop the occasional load of freight at this point for the Indian school, but you will readily understand the placing of a shelter would be the Railways admission of this being a regular unloading point.

CDG/EB.

Dear Sir,

Referring to your 108-22 of October 15th, re shelter for local freight at Pelican, beg to advise that we now already have two stops between Sioux Lookout and Kenora, viz: Pelican and North Pines, and could not consistently establish another at the point you suggest, although, of course, I am aware that considerable local freight for the Indian School is unloaded at or near the new spur at the east end of the passing track. However, the new spur was put in as a car loading proposition entirely.

Yours truly,

[Signature]
Asst. Superintendent.

The Superintendent,

Sieux Lookout, Ontario.

Dear Mr. Glass:

As your company have put in a spur at Pelican for the Indian School, I have been requested by my department to obtain if possible one or two old box cars which could be dumped at the spur and used as a shelter for freight for the school.

Could you assist us in any way? With kind regards.

Very truly yours,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.
Sir,

Enclosed please find correspondence between this office and the Assistant Superintendent of the C. N. Ry at Sioux Lookout, re obtaining old box cars for a shelter for freight at the east switch at Pelican spur for the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School.

Mr Glass says there are two stops between Hudson and Sioux Lookout at North Pines and at Pelican, I may say there is very little business at North Pines only an old disused mine and some fishermen, who no doubt ship a quantity of fish, but at Pelican there is no one living there except the Section men, all the business at Pelican except for the Section men is for the Indian School.

It appears unreasonable for Mr Glass to state that he does not wish to have a shelter at the Switch, as we have had the spur put in, and the shelter is required for goods from the cars, so that they can be unloaded promptly and goods taken to the school as opportunity permits.

I shall be glad if you will take up this matter direct with the "ational "ailways, as the lakes will soon be frozen over, and it is impossible to bring freight from Sioux Lookout over the ice owing to the current and rapids.

I will interview Mr Glass again on the 12th instant when I shall be in Sioux Lookout.

Kindly return the correspondence for my files.

Yours obedient servant,

[Signature]

Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Ottawa, November 14, 1927.

Sir:

I have your 108-22 of the 7th instant, with reference to the refusal of the Assistant Superintendent of the C. N. R. at Sioux Lookout to place a box car at the Department's siding near Pelican, for the use of the Indian residential school there. I do not consider it advisable to deal with this matter direct with the Montreal office, as this might make the local officers of the railway less sympathetic to our requests at this point. You might see if you can secure permission to erect at the spur a small inexpensive shelter, that could be properly locked. If this can be done, let me have an estimate of the cost. Such storehouse should be built on sills, so that it could be moved later, if advisable.

Your obedient servant,

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF PUBLIC SCHOOL INSPECTOR
S. SHANNON, dated Oct. 20, 1927, on the
Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School.

CLASSROOM.

In the large Classroom now being used the lighting is quite inadequate. This room is lighted from the north side and has only four small windows.

This condition can be somewhat remedied by a better colour scheme in the interior decoration. If the ceiling were painted white, or a very light Silver Grey, and the walls, including the folding doors, painted a light Cream colour, the Lighting would be much better. The whole wall of folding doors, in natural fir, contributes greatly to the darkness of the room.

All the Blackboards in the School are too high from the floor for the use of the ordinary pupils. This condition can be remedied by dropping the Slates down Ten Inches or a Foot and filling in the space at top by a strip of Hyloplate. This latter is a convenient device for holding the Decorations which many teachers delight to have at the top of the Blackboard. I have recommended this to Mr. Marshall and he would very much like to have this improvement made.

In future you should advise your Architect to have ceilings of Classrooms supported by steel beams, as supporting pillars in the middle of a classroom is a very serious defect.
Ottawa, November 18, 1927.

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School, states that lighting conditions in the large classroom could be improved by a better colour scheme in the interior decoration. He states that if the ceiling were painted white, or a very light silver grey, and the walls, including the folding doors, painted a light cream colour, the lighting would be much better. He also states that the whole wall of folding doors, in natural fir, contributes greatly to the darkness of the room. He further states that all the blackboards in the school are too high from the floor for the use of the smaller pupils.

I have to request that you will take up with the Principal the matter of carrying out the recommendations of the Inspector regarding the improving of the lighting and the changing of the interior decoration. You should furnish a report as to whether you would recommend that the classroom be repainted in the colour scheme as recommended by the Inspector, and, if so, you should state the approximate cost of having the work done.

Relative to the blackboard, I beg to say that it will hardly be possible to have these boards lowered. It is considered that if a platform of the required height were erected along the blackboards, this would be satisfactory. Please enquire into this matter, and furnish a report as to the cost of a platform of the required height and width.

These matters should receive your attention on the occasion of your next visit to the school.

Your obedient servant,

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Form No. 101.
Sir:

Enclosed you will please find Mr. R. N. Wyatt's account for $998.00 for extending and repairing the water supply intake at the Indian Residential School. The account is in triplicate with the necessary vouchers attached and recommended for payment. Will you please have these forwarded at the earliest date possible in order that payment may not be held up more than necessary.

This work was carried out under the authority of Mr. Frank Edwards, Indian Agent at Kenora, from whom a telegram was received on October 24th instructing me to take whatever action was necessary to put the intake pipe into proper working condition. A copy of this telegram is enclosed for your files.

The necessity of overhauling and extending the intake was due to the contractor, Mr. J. H. Simmons, not carrying out his work a year ago according to his instructions and the plans furnished. Upon examination it was found that the condenser and intake pipe were not carried out a sufficient distance from the bank. After the pipe was uncovered it was also found that the flanged wrought iron pipe was irregularly laid and in fact was simply laid with the ends butting against each other, with here and there a hole without nuts put in the flanges. The outer end of the intake pipe landed among a large boulder and later when the high water washed the excavated earth into the stream it completely covered the end of the pipe and boulder, thus shutting off the water supply.

This bad workmanship and not carrying out the work according to instructions required quite extensive work to be done, which being carried on under adverse weather conditions resulted in the cost being fairly high.

Your obedient servant,

C. H. Atwood,
District Chief Engineer.

Enc.

J. R. Bunn, Esq.,
Inspector, Department of Indian Affairs,
4th Floor Commercial Bldg.,
Winnipeg, Man.
Kenora, Ont.
January 3rd, 1928.

Sir:

Enclosed herewith please find voucher No.4075 for $998.06 in favour of N.R.Wyatt, Contractor, Winnipeg, Man., for work done in extending and repairing the water intake at Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School, along with a letter sent to Mr. Inspector Bunn in the same regard by Mr.C.H.Attwood District Chief Engineer, Dominion Water Power Service and Reclamation Branch, Winnipeg, Man.

This has been sent to us by Mr. Inspector Bunn, who asks us to note that Mr. Attwood has certified the account and recommends payment, as his Department supervised the work to a proper finish.

Everything is now satisfactory, but I would draw your attention to the last two paragraphs of Mr. Attwood's letter.

I have certified the vouchers, but leave it for you to decide whether the amount should be charged to the original contractor, Mr. J.H.Birks.

N.R.Wyatt's rates for labour appear excessive.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

The Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir:

During my last visit to Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School the reverend principal asked for authority to purchase immediately 2000 feet of rough lumber for partitions in the school basement to facilitate storing of vegetables in winter, the school to be responsible for erection, and the lumber to be used in spring for new outbuildings, root-house etc.

As this requirement was urgent and a lot of vegetables getting spoiled, I gave the necessary authority, and would accordingly appreciate your approval.

The lumber will be procured at the least possible expense.

Your obedient servant,

Frank Edwards

CANADIAN NATIONAL RAILWAYS

LICENSE TO STRING TELEPHONE WIRES ON COMPANY'S POLES.

PERMISSION is hereby given by the Canadian National Railway Company in its capacity as Manager of the Canadian Government Railways under Directing Order No. 126, dated December 31, 1918, to the Canadian National Railway Company (hereinafter jointly called the "Company") for their respective rights and interests, to His Majesty the King in right of the Dominion of Canada, herein represented by the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs (hereinafter called the "Licensee") to string a metallic telephone circuit on the Company's poles between Sioux Lookout and Falcon Lake, in the Province of Ontario, a distance of approximately 5.17 miles, according to plans approved herewith and being part of this License, and

ON THE FOLLOWING TERMS, which the Licensee hereby accepts and agrees to perform and abide by:

1. STRINGING WIRES - The stringing and placing of wires shall be in accordance with specifications or instructions to be given by the Company's District Plant Superintendent and shall conform throughout with the requirements of the Board of Railway Commissioners for Canada from time to time in force governing the stringing of wires upon or across the property of the Railway Company.

2. MOVING WIRES - The Licensee shall at any time, or from time to time, on notice from the said District Plant Superintendent forthwith at the cost of the Licensee move the same wires, either temporarily or permanently, to other poles of the Company wherever erected between the points aforementioned or to other places on any poles in exact accordance with the instructions of the said District Plant Superintendent and in default the Company may move the same at the cost of the Licensee.

3. COST - The whole of the work to be done at the expense of the Licensee.

4. RENTAL - The Licensee shall pay to the Company for the privileges hereby given the sum of $25.00 per annum. Said rental shall be due and payable in advance on the first day of October in each year during the continuance hereof.

5. LICENSEE'S RISK - The said wires while on the Company's premises shall at all times be entirely at the risk of the Licensee in respect of loss, damage or injury from whatsoever cause arising, whether due to the negligence of the Company, its agents or employees or otherwise.

6. EMPLOYEES OF LICENSEE WORKING ON COMPANY'S PREMISES AT THEIR OWN RISK.

All persons entering upon the lands of the Company for the purpose of construction, inspection, maintenance, use or repair of the works of the Licensee, herein contemplated, shall assume all risk of and the Company shall not be liable for any injury, loss or damage, howsoever caused, to any such person while on the lands of the Company, and the Licensee hereby undertakes to indemnify the Company against any claims for such injury, loss or damage.

7. REPAIRS AND MAINTENANCE - Any work required to be done in connection with the construction, repair or maintenance of the Licensee's wires or instruments on the Company's premises, may at the option of the said District Plant Superintendent be done by the Company at reasonable rates fixed by the Company, which shall be paid by the Licensee on demand.

8. TAXES - The Licensee shall pay all taxes and assessments of every description that may at any time be imposed by reason of the privileges granted hereunder.

9. COMPANY NOT RESPONSIBLE FOR ACTS OF EMPLOYEES - The Company shall not be responsible for any interruption or defect in the service given by the Licensee over the said wires nor for default or failure of the

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6215, file 470-5, part 2)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Company's agents or any of its employees to repair or keep in repair the said wires, it being understood that in making any repairs to the said wires the agents or employees of the Company shall be deemed to act as the agents or employees of the Licensee.

10. CANCELLATION OF LICENSE.

(a) This license may be cancelled at any time upon thirty days' notice in writing signed by any Superintending Officer of the Company. Upon the expiration of the notice period the Licensee shall remove at his own expense all his wires, connections and material from the premises of the Company and in default the Company may remove same at the cost of the Licensee. The Company will in such case, if equitable, refund to the Licensee any part of rental paid for the unexpired portion of the year.

(b) Should, however, the Licensee desire to cancel this agreement at any time, the Licensee may do so on giving to the Company thirty days written notice of his intention so to do and within such period shall, at the Licensee's expense, remove his wires, connections and materials from the Company's premises.

11. LICENSEE NOT ASSIGNABLE - Neither this License nor any right or interest hereunder is subject to any assignment or sub-lease without the consent in writing of the Company.

12. PENALTIES ON DEFAULT - Should default be made by the Licensee in the payment of any money or the performance of any work or the fulfillment of any condition due hereunder the Company may cancel this Agreement forthwith without notice and may remove all wires, connections and materials belonging to the Licensee from the premises of the Company and may collect from the Licensee the cost of such removal.

13. INDEMNITY - The Licensee shall indemnify and save harmless the Company from all claims, demands, actions, suits or other proceedings by whomsoever made, brought or prosecuted in any manner based upon, arising out of or connected with this License or anything done or maintained in any manner hereunder.

Dated this first day of October 1927.

SIOUX LOOKOUT INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

Sioux Lookout, Ont.
March 15th, 1928.

Re: Painting Class Room Letter No. 108-22

Dear Sir:

I have been in communication with the Christie School Supply Co. Ltd. Brandon, also the E.N. Moyer Co. of Winnipeg re blackboards. Both quote the same prices F.O.B. Sioux Lookout. Hylolite 37½ per sq.ft. and Sterling at 65¢ per sq.ft.

Re paint. J.H. Ashdown and T. Eaton Co. Winnipeg both quote $4.50 per gallon for No.1 paint.

Figuring this matter as economically as possible our result is as follows:

| Item                        | Quantity | Unit Price | Total |
|-----------------------------|----------|------------|-------|
| 4 pieces of 4x5 Hylolite    |          | 37½        | $30.00|
| 25 gallons of paint         |          | 4.50       | $112.50|
|                            |          |            | $142.50|
| Plus freight on paint, approximately |          |            | $7.50 |

The most feasible solution regarding the blackboards is to leave the top moulding where it is, lower the blackboard about 12 inches, filling in the intervening spaces with a strip of Hylolite B.B. using a piece of moulding to join the two B.B's together. This, I think, can be done easier and at less expense than building platforms, and be much more satisfactory in the end.

Hoping that this will meet with your approval I am,

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]
John F.J. Marshall,
Principal

Captain F. Edwards,
Indian Agent.
Kenora, Ont.

Sir:

Dear Sir;-

With reference to your letter of Oct. 9th 1926 No. 129-6-15 re wiring of the barn and out buildings of the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School. I asked for prices from the different firms that had worked on the school and am submitting their various prices.

The contract was let to Roy MacDonald of Sioux Lookout for the amount of $375.00. This work was not completed nor passed by the Electrical Inspector until March the first of this year. Mr MacDonald wired the barn so that we had the use of it but owing to him having considerable building work in town I did not press for the wiring of the other buildings until after he had finished the wiring on the Imperial Bank this winter. So that with all buildings completed it made it worth while for the Inspector to come and inspect the work which he passed on March 1st.

We are therefore submitting the account for payment and consider that the work has been done faithfully and well.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

(Rev.) J.F.J. Marshall,
Principal.

Reverend Sir:

I am pleased to inform you that funds are available for the erection of a workshop and a root-house at the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School. I should be glad if you would let me have a proposal, with estimate of the cost, in this connection. The Department would prefer to have this activity done on a day labour basis, under your direction. Could you get out a list of material required and would you be prepared to look after the erection of the two outbuildings, if the Department allowed wages for a carpenter - the members of the staff and the older boys to assist.

CANADA
Dear Sir;-

Re Cement for the Ice House and Tool Shed

Pursuant to our conversation with Mr. Ferrier regarding cement foundations under the ice house and tool shed, I am of the opinion that we can save both time and material by running these cement foundations at the same time as that of the root house, as we can use the same lumber for forms for both jobs, and then use the lumber some place in the building.

I have estimated that it will take 70 bags to do the foundation under the ice house and tool shed.

If permission is granted for this work we are in a position to carry it on at the same time that we would be building the root house.

Kindly give this matter your consideration and let us know your decision at your earliest convenience, and oblige,

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

(Rev.) J.F.J. Marshall,
Principal.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Dear Sir;-

With reference to our conversation with Mr. Ferrier re a suitable shed at the track I may say that I have made inquiries and have secured prices on lumber and etc as requested and find that by utilizing our own labor the shed, which is to serve as a store house at the track for supplies coming into the school in the winter time, would cost approximately $250.00. This shed is very necessary in winter time and I would suggest that that if possible sanction be given for the erection so that all lumber and etc could be purchased at the same time the material is purchased for the roothouse.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

(Rev.) J.F.J. Marshall,
Principal.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School

Sioux Lookout, Ont.,
Sept. 18th 1928.

Dear Sir:

Attention Mr. Ferrier

As agreed during your recent visit we have done all the labor possible in preparation for the erection of the new root house and workshop which is to be built as instructed in your letter No. 129 - 6 - 5 May 31st 1928.

I have made enquiries as to material and find that I can obtain same in Sioux Lookout for the following prices:

- Cement $1.10 per bag
- Lime $1.00 "
- Lumber $40.00 "

At the above rates including the wages for one carpenter I have estimated the cost of proposed building at approximately $2500.00.

If you would kindly sanction the purchasing of this material and the hiring of a carpenter we are in a position to commence immediately upon receipt of same.

It would save considerable annoyance and embarrassment if you would forward a cheque for the payment of the carpenters wages. The accounts for material and etc could be submitted in the usual way but as a rule laborers desire prompt payment and do not care to work unless they can see the cash.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

October 2, 1928.

Memorandum:

There is available $2,500 for the erection of a combined workshop and roothouse at the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School. On May 31st, the Reverend Principal was asked to submit a proposal with estimate of the cost. The Department stated, at that time, that we would prefer to have the activity on a day labour basis - the principal to purchase the materials. The members of the staff and the older boys were to assist and one carpenter engaged.

The Rev. Principal has now submitted a proposal and is willing to proceed now with the building activity, making the arrangements the Department suggested. Mr. Marshall is quite competent to supervise this activity, as he is a good carpenter, himself. I wish to recommend that he be authorized to purchase the materials in Sioux Lookout, engage a carpenter and proceed with the work.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6215, file 470-5, part 2)
Ottawa, October 5, 1928.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 18th ultimo, with reference to the erection of a combined workshop and roothouse at the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School. I wish to confirm my answering night letter, as follows:

"Reference your letter eighteenth instant, you may erect combined workshop and roothouse on day labour basis - cost not to exceed $3500. Purchase lumber from George Parlinger, Sioux Lookout, at his best price to government school. You may engage one carpenter. Writing."

The Department will rely on you to purchase the cement, lime and hardware necessary in Sioux Lookout, to the best advantage. Under separate cover, there is being directed to you a supply of labour return forms, which should be kept in duplicate and which should be forwarded to the Department, showing the receipt of the carpenter engaged. If a labourer is engaged for the cement and other heavy work, you may also engage such a worker. His time and receipts should also be shown on the labour returns. To pay the labour, an accountable cheque for $300 is being directed to you under separate cover. The accounts for materials should be forwarded to the Department, properly certified, in duplicate, when payment will be made direct to the firm in question. At your earliest convenience, you might let me have a rough sketch, showing the nature of the building you propose to erect.

I have also your letter of the 18th instant, with reference to a storehouse at the railway track. You may arrange for the erection of a suitable building, at an estimated cost of $650. Mr. Ferrier reports that this is necessary to the satisfactory conduct of the school in the winter time.

I have also your letter of the 20th instant, with reference to cement for the foundations of the icehouse and "school" building. You may purchase 50 bags of cement and ring the foundations at the same time as you are doing that for the new workshop and roothouse.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN
J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Rev. J. F. J. Marshall,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Sioux Lookout, Ont.

Note: This letter dictated by Mr. Ferrier.

November 26th./28.

Sir:

I have received a letter from the Chief Inspector of Steam Boilers, Toronto, in reference to the boiler inspection at the Sioux Lookout school this fall.

He reports that these boilers were designed for the use of coal fuel, but are burning wood, and under the circumstances would advise that hinged doors of full height be fitted, doing away with the top door that has to be lifted off.

In discussing the matter with the Principal on Sunday last, he said that the cost would be about $80.00. He also spoke about this matter with Mr. Ferrier, and would be glad to have the necessary approval for these alterations, which are recommended by me.

The Principal also asked if he could purchase a new Quebec Heater 16"X 39" fitted with grate for coal, at a cost of $24.00. This is required to keep the water from freezing in the tank. The old stove was purchased two years ago, and is now worn out.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

R/S

The Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, December 4, 1928.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 26th ultimo, with reference to the communication which you received from the Chief Inspector of Steam Boilers, Toronto, regarding the boilers at the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School.

In reply I beg to say that the Department will approve of an expenditure of approximately $50 in making the change as recommended by the Inspector of Boilers in order that wood fuel can be used satisfactorily instead of coal. The Principal should see that all costs are kept as low as possible.

Approval is also granted for the purchase of a McClary Quebec heater, fitted with grate for coal, at a cost of approximately $24. It is noted that this heater is required to keep the water from freezing in the tank.

When the Principal arranges for the purchase of the above equipment, he should obtain accounts, in duplicate, covering the cost. These he should certify and hand to you for transmission to the Department in the usual manner.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Winnipeg, Man.
January 18th 1929.

The Rev. J.F.J. Marshall,
Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School,
Sioux Lookout, Ont.,

Dear Sir;-

We have received the following report from our expert Mr. Atkinson in connection with his visit to your lighting and transmission equipment, during the present week. He made a complete overhaul of the engine and found a few parts necessary for replacement, which are being forwarded from our warehouse in Winnipeg, and when these are installed the engine will be in absolutely the best of conditions.

The same applies to the transmission equipment, the generator was overhauled and repaired. Mr Atkinson states however that the batteries were in a very bad condition, and nothing can be done with these, he advises that they should be replaced immediately, otherwise we cannot guarantee a continuance of satisfactory working condition of the lighting and transmission equipment.

With regard to your enquiry in connection with the date of shipment of the lighting equipment, this was forwarded from Winnipeg complete with batteries on July 16th 1926 and is undoubtedly the cause of the present battery condition.

Yours truly,

R. A. Lister & Company (Canada) Ltd.,
Credit Manager.
Dear Sir;-

Following up a suggestion made by Mr. Ferrier during his visit to the school in August 1926 I wrote to the R.A. Lister Co. asking them if they had a travel ing repair man. They replied that they had no such man but that they could send one of their expert mechanics down to over look the plant in the quiet season so they sent a Mr. Atkinson down here in January to go over the lighting and water system. He made a thorough overhauling of the engine and made several minor repairs as shown on the enclosed accounts. He also spent considerable time trying to adjust the batteries but found that he was unable to fix them at all. His explanation is that these batteries were sent to the school in July of 1926 and were not charged nor kept up in any way until the plant was put in operation on January 15th 1927. This evidently was no ones fault but just circumstances owing to many setbacks at the time.

I am enclosing a copy of the report made on these batteries by Mr. Atkinson for your information.

Trusting that this work meets with your approval I am,

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

(Rev.) J.F.J. Marshall,
Principal.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Dear Sir:-

Enclosed please find accounts as submitted to us from the J.H.Ashdown's Co. Winnipeg for repairs to the water system and sewerage equipment.

In November we had trouble with our water line and had to dig up a great deal of pipe only to find that three flanges had broken. The only explanation we are able to offer is that it was due to contraction of the pipe. We had no flanges on hand nor could we wait for them to come so we borrowed from the B&B shops of the town with the understanding that we would replace them. We took it upon ourselves to do so when it was necessary to order a sewer rod and fittings to overcome trouble in the sewer pipe leading from the hospital just after the trouble in the pipe line. We tried wire but without results and so we ordered the rod to see if it would remove the obstruction. As you know this pipe from the hospital has always given trouble but we found that even the rod would not touch the obstruction so the only thing left was to dig up the pipe. This we did and found a piece of oak flooring 16in long had got lodged in the elbow of the pipe. There is no other way of this wood getting in the pipe except by being there before the pipe was put in.

This account was sent to the office of Indian Affairs in Winnipeg and was given to me when I was in the city last week. I trust that the action taken was not overstepping as it seemed to be the only course to follow, at the time owing to imperative haste being necessary,

Yours faithfully,

(Rev.) J.F.J.McClelland,
Principal.

Ottawa, April 2nd., 1929.

Rev. Sir,

Referring to your letter of the 22nd ultimo, enclosing a letter from the Accountant, Imperial Bank, Sioux Lookout, together with three cancelled cheques in connection with the advance of $500.00 made to you in October last for the erection of a combined workshop and root-house, I beg to state that you have omitted to account for this advance in the proper manner as instructed in Department's letter of the 3rd October last, and I have to request that you will prepare a credit voucher in your favor showing the advance received and the payments made and attach to this voucher the labor returns for the wages paid and receipted detailed account from Mr. Wm. Seroggie for freighting lumber and cement. As the financial year expired on the 31st ultimo, you cannot use during the current year any portion of the unexpended balance of this advance, and you should send your cheque at once in favor of the Department for the sum of $579.98 to refund the unexpended balance. As soon as you are ready to continue the work in connection with this building, you may apply for another advance from the current year's appropriation, and the same will be sent you. Kindly attend to this matter without delay.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. J.F.J. Marshall,
Principal, Indian Residential School,
Sioux Lookout, Ont.

Dear Sir:-

Ottawa, June 11, 1929.

Reverend Sir:

I am pleased to inform you that funds are available for painting the main building at the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School, and I should be pleased if you would let the Department have a proposal as to how this work should be undertaken. Could you purchase the material and arrange to have the painting done on a day labour basis? In your reply, you might indicate if any further outbuildings are absolutely necessary this year.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy Secretary.

Rev. J. P. Marshall,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Sioux Lookout,
Ont.
Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School

Sioux Lookout, Ont.,
July 12th., 1929.

Dear Sir;-

I have been making enquiries around Sioux Lookout regarding the possibility of securing labor to have the main building of the school painted as requested in your letter of June 11th., No. 129-6-5 and beg to report that the best figures I have been able to secure would be approximately $300.00 for day labor and $500.00 for material such as paint, brushes and etc.

If these figures meet with your approval I would suggest that we purchase the paint in Winnipeg as the Sioux Lookout prices are very high and I am sure much better material could be obtained at a good saving from Winnipeg. The accounts for paint and etc. could be certified to and forwarded to you for payment but having the painting done on a day labor basis would necessitate having an accountable cheque forwarded to us for this purpose. We would then return the cancelled cheques to you along with the necessary forms.

The boat house is the only other outside building that is in real need of paint. If you think it advisable to have this done at the same time arrangements could be made whereby it was included in the order for supplies.

Trusting that this is the desired information and that our efforts are satisfactory, I am,

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

(Rev.) J. F. J. Marshall,
Principal.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6215, file 470-5, part 2)
Ottawa, July 18th, 1929.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 12th instant, relative to the painting of the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School building.

In this connection I have to say that you should arrange for the purchase of the paint and other materials required in Winnipeg. You should see that a good grade of paint is obtained, and you should forward an itemised account, in duplicate, covering the cost. This account you should certify in the usual manner and forward to the Department, when a cheque in payment will be sent direct to the merchant from whom you purchased the material.

Regarding the labour in having the painting carried out, I have to say that this should be performed on a day labour basis. Proper time sheets, in duplicate, should be kept of the labour employed. Full particulars should be filled in as requested on the forms, and the individual labourers should sign same in duplicate, and they should also be certified by you and forwarded to the Department in accounting for the expenditure of the cheque for $300 which will be sent you under separate cover. A supply of labour returns forms is enclosed herewith.

You may also arrange to have the boat house painted at the same time as the work on the school building is being carried out.

You should see that the work is satisfactorily completed before the cold weather sets in next Fall.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. J. F. J. Marshall,
Principal, Indian Res. School,
Sioux Lookout, Ont.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6215, file 470-5, part 2)
Dear Sir;-

I regret the necessity of drawing your attention to our report of Feb. 20th., 1929 accompanied by a report of the R. A. Lister expert of January 18th., 1929 re our batteries, but they are in such a condition at the present time that I do not think it advisable to commence the winter with all its complications and not have our machinery in good running order as our building is full of children and light is so essential.

The batteries are so low that we have to start the engine by hand. It is necessary to keep the engine running every minute we have the lights on which is most inconvenient and expensive. During the night we have no lights and it is a big worry realizing all the night calls and the danger of lamps.

Kindly give this your earliest consideration and oblige,

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

(Rev.) J. F. J. Marshall,
Principal.

WINNIPEG, MAN., Oct. 23rd, 1929.

The Secretary,
The Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

During my recent visit to the Sioux Lookout School, (Oct. 19th and 20th) the Principal directed my attention to the serious trouble he had experienced in keeping the grounds around the main school building from being dug up by the water shed from the roof of this building, and strongly recommended that your Department be asked to give further consideration to the possibility of having eave-troughs installed. My recollection is that the objection raised by your Department to the installation of eave-troughs was based on the danger which had to be faced of having all the troughing torn off by sliding ice from the roof in time of thaw. I placed this consideration before the Principal and he informed me that this danger would be avoided by having the eave-troughs placed at a slightly lower level. Should your Department still consider it inadvisable to provide the eave-troughs, then the Principal strongly recommended that a cement platform be placed about the whole school to prevent a recurrence of the difficulties he has had to face during the past summer.

After a careful survey of the situation I was strongly convinced that either one or other of the above improvements is absolutely necessary to protect the foundations and to help to keep the ground in shape, and I commend it once more to your careful and sympathetic consideration. It is not expected that either improvement should be undertaken this year, but that provision should be made in your estimate for supplying either one or both of these next year.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

Dear Sir:-

The lighting in both the staff sitting rooms and the staff dining room is very poor as it consists of a single drop light and it was suggested by Dr. Stone that we apply for new fixtures for these rooms similar to the ones used by the Public Health Department in Ottawa. We would be most grateful if you could see your way to purchase these for us for these rooms. It would add greatly to the comfort of the staff.

SIOUX LOOKOUT INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

N.B. Just to remind you about the cement gutter around the building. It rained all day yesterday and we were almost flooded out in the basement and regretted the fact that some of our official guests were not with us to join in the swim. Shall we commence hauling gravel this winter?

J. M.
SIOUX LOOKOUT INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

Sioux Lookout, Ont.
October 30th., 1929.

Dear Sir;-

The stairs, halls, and many of the rooms that have been in constant use need attention and to make them look as they should and while we have the painter here I would like to have these things attended to. The painter will be finished with the outside work next week and as they commence their winter rates on the first of November I thought it would be an opportune time to engage him and get things in to first class shape.

If you should think kindly of the suggestion I would suggest that a cheque of one hundred and fifty dollars be forwarded for labor and that we have sanction to purchase the necessary paint, varnish and etc and submit the accounts as usual. This would give us a good start for the spring and also have it done much more economically than we could hope to do it later as well as being sure of having a first class job done.

We hope to be able to have our own boys and girls do this as time goes on but as yet we have due respect for the building.

Yours faithfully,

(Rev.) J. F. J. Marshall,
Principal.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Dear Sir;-

Ever since we moved into the residence of this school in October 1926 we have had to put up with a great deal of discomfort in the winter time owing to the fact that we can not keep the place warm. The residence is at the extreme end of the building and is not built on the same level as the school which necessitates a drop of 18in in the steam pipe and unless we have a full head of steam on, thereby roasting out the centre of the building, we cannot force heat into the residence at all. We have tried to accomplish this in every way we know of and it only results in the same way. It is usually well after 10 in the morning when the heat reaches us and very seldom do we get a bit of heat after seven at night. Besides being unbearably uncomfortable it is far from healthy to be living in such conditions and I feel that such should be brought to your attention.

I discussed this matter with Dr. Stone during his last visit and suggested to him that a small furnace, wood burning, be put in the basement of the residence to overcome this condition. If you think favorably of the suggestion I could make arrangements with the local man in Sioux Lookout to install a suitable furnace and I am sure it would be economy in the end as far as fuel is concerned.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

(Rev.) J. F. J. Marshall,
Principal.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Dec. 6, 1929.

Dear Mr. Simmons,

I have today received a letter from Mr. Marshall advising me that he has never been able to properly heat the residence portion of the Sioux Lookout School. There must be some obstruction in the pipes leading to that portion of the building. If you will remember the floor level of the residence was about two feet lower than the ground floor of the other portion of the building.

Will you please arrange to have the contractor who installed this plant send a competent man to Sioux Lookout and see if the present unsatisfactory condition can be remedied. I will be glad to hear from you after the steam fitter has been to Sioux Lookout.

Your obedient servant,

R. SUMMERS ORR,
Architect for the Department.

J. H. Simmons, Esq.,
Winnipeg, Man.
Dec. 6, 1929.

Rev. Sir,

Replying to your letter of the 30th with reference to the heating of the residence portion of the Sioux Lookout School. If the heating system in that portion of the building is not working satisfactorily the same will have to be put in proper condition, and I am today writing to Mr. Simmons of Winnipeg, contractor for the building, asking him to have the steam fitter who installed this plant come to Sioux Lookout and make the necessary adjustments. If the system is properly installed according to the plans and specifications you should have no difficulty in heating the residence portion of the building.

With reference to your request for some interior decorating you may arrange to have this work done as suggested and an accountable cheque for $150.00 for the payment of labour is being sent to you.

Regarding your request for lighting fixtures for the staff sitting rooms and staff dining room you may purchase suitable fixtures the first time you are in Winnipeg. Kindly select as economical a fixture as possible.

You may also arrange for the hauling of the necessary gravel during the winter that will be required to build a concrete gutter around the outside of the building.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. J. E. Marshall,
Principal,
Sioux Lookout School,
Sioux Lookout, Ont.

January 29th, 1930

Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

The Principal of the Sioux Lookout Residential School wishes to have authority to purchase burlap and strips for the halls and stairways as has been put in other Indian schools. This is a big help in keeping the walls, etc., clean and also preventing the plaster from falling. I do not know the amount required for this but the same could be taken from the plans. Whilst at the school I authorized the Principal to make cabinets on the walls for the fire hose. This will be done at no cost to the Department.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.
Ottawa, February 6, 1930.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 29th ultimo relative to the request of the Principal of the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School to be granted authority to purchase burlap and strips for the halls and stairways.

In reply I have to say that the Department has no funds available to provide for the cost of purchasing these materials.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Renora, Ont.

MAR 22 1930  
SIOUX LOOKOUT, ONT.
Ottawa, April 15th., 1930.

Rev. Sir,

With reference to vouchers received with your statement headed "Contents of envelope" dated March 22nd, 1930, I beg to call your attention to the following:

(No. 2). The return of labour accounting for the advance of $150.00 made by cheque No. 5510 states that the work was done "as per agreement made with the painter". The written agreement referred to should be forwarded to the Department.

(No. 3). Brandram-Henderson Limited. There was an error of $10.00 in the addition of the statement which accompanied the invoices of this firm. The correct addition according to the figures given in the statement is $372.61. In invoice No. 29 dated January 22nd, 1930, the item for 40 gals. Everlastic varnish at $2.40, extends to $96.00, instead of $168.00, which makes an overcharge of $72.00. When these corrections are made, the amount due this firm is $300.61. I herewith return the vouchers for correction.

(No. 12). This item is misleading, as the sum of $6.65, which you claim to be due you for expenditure over the advance of $375.00 for the root house is included in the labour return amounting to $381.65, and should not have appeared in your statement as a separate voucher.

The other accounts mentioned in your statement appear to be satisfactory and will be paid, with the exception of Dr. Jefferies' accounts (No. 7) for dentistry, which were returned to you under cover of Department's letter of the 2nd instant, File No. 129-6-13. As soon as they are returned with the particulars asked for in that letter, they will receive consideration.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Rev. J.F.J. Marshall,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Sioux Lookout, Ont.

A.F. MacKenzie
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary

CANADA
Ottawa, April 17, 1930.

Reverend Sir:

With further reference to vouchers received with your statement "Contents of Envelope", dated the 22nd ultimo, I wish to state that the Department's filing system is such that there is considerable difficulty when accounts of various natures are forwarded in the form of one letter. The present rule is one subject per letter, with any vouchers that are relative thereto attached. Several subjects may be grouped in one letter and vouchers, if any, attached, provided that all pertain to one or other of the following main questions:-

1. General policy at the Institution, appointments, etc.
2. The quarterly returns.
3. Per capita payments and current expenses.
4. Classroom equipment, texts, athletic equipment, etc.
5. Buildings, repairs, painting, improvements.
6. Indian agent's inspections and reports.
7. Public school inspector's inspections and reports.
8. Farm and building site, fencing, clearing, etc.
9. Correspondence re pupils, applications, discharges, etc.
10. Vocational training.
11. Furnishings.
12. Medical, dental and hospital.
13. Livestock and agricultural implements.
14. New main building under construction or recently constructed.
15. Water power development, if any.
16. Students' organizations, Boy scouts, etc.

You will note that there is no 8 subject. The reason for this is that I have given you the numbers that

Rev. J.F.J. Marshall,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Sioux Lookout, Ont.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6215, file 470-5, part 2)
correspond with the Department's filing system. The agency in which the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School is situated is No. 129, the school is No. 6 and practically all letters which you will receive from the Department will commence with 129-6 and will end with one or other of the sub-numbers listed above. When you are replying to a communication or indication enquiry, you should quote file number and date and, as a general rule, keep one subject to one covering letter.

When authority has been given to you for some improvement or expenditure and this authority has been executed as directed, a covering letter is really not necessary, as you can forward the account in duplicate, properly certified, referring to the Department's letter on the face of the account; but where there is any comment to be made or explanation or a request for an answer, a covering letter should be prepared.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy Secretary.
Ottawa, May 20, 1930.

Reverend Sir:

I have to inform you that funds are available for a cement apron, or concrete gutter, around the foundation of the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School. You may proceed with this work, on a day labour basis, keeping in mind that no unnecessary expense should be incurred. You might let the Department have an interim letter, stating what arrangements you are making and indicating the approximate cost. Before purchasing the cement, please be sure that you are securing the best possible price.

Your obedient servant,

A. S. Williams,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Rev. J.F.J. Marshall,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Sioux Lookout, Ont.

Attention Mr. Marshall

Dear Sir:

Answering your letter of May 1st, regarding our invoice of Jan 22nd, we have looked this up and find that the amount of the invoice is correct. The price of $2.40 for the Everlastic Varnish was a typographical error and should have been $4.20, which makes the extension of $168.00 correct. We are attaching a corrected invoice in triplicate, and hope you will find this in order.

We regret any inconvenience we have caused you, and remain,

Yours very truly,

Form No. 101
Ottawa, June 21, 1930.

Reverend Sir:

Pursuant to conversation when you were in Ottawa yesterday, I have to authorize you to expend up to $100 on lumber required for repairs and replacements at the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School. A properly certified voucher, in duplicate, should be forwarded in due course.

You may engage a good carpenter, to be available for a few days' labour when you repair the elevated water tank.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Rev. J. F. J. Marshall,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Sioux Lookout, Ont.
SIOUX LOOKOUT INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

Sioux Lookout, Ont.,
August 15th., 1930

Dear Sir,

We are now in a position to commence on the cement gutter around the school as sanctioned in your letter of May 20th., 1930 No. 129-6-5. We will engage a man on the day labour basis and will purchase the cement from A.A.J. McDonald in Sioux Lookout. The cement for the root house was purchased through him and I was able to get a good price on same.

Would you kindly forward an accountable cheque for this work. It may be necessary to have a couple of good men on the job but I figure that a very satisfactory job can be made and cost in labor no more than $500.00 by using the boys and superintending the work myself.

The rains have been quite bad this summer and as a result the play rooms have been almost a swimming tank. It will be such a relief to have it fixed so that the play rooms and wash rooms can be used at all times.

Yours faithfully,

(Rev.) J. F. J. Marshall,
Principal.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa, August 20, 1930.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 15th instant, relative to the repairs to the cement gutter around the foundation at the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School building, and requesting to be forwarded an accountable cheque for the labour. In this connection I have to say that a cheque to the amount of $500 to pay the labour is being sent you under separate cover.

Time sheets, in duplicate, for the labour employed should be kept. A supply of forms for this purpose is enclosed herewith. These returns should be prepared in duplicate, all particulars filled in and signed by the individual labourers employed and certified by yourself, in accounting for the above advance. The accounts covering the cost of the cement should be certified by yourself and forwarded to the Department for payment. You should see that a satisfactory job is completed and that all expense is kept as low as possible.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
For Secretary.

Rev. J. F. J. Marshall,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Sioux Lookout, Ont.

Form No. 101
EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF MR. INSPECTOR SHANNON,
DATED NOVEMBER 14, 1930, ON HIS INSPECTION OF
THE SIUX LOOKOUT INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

Original on File 129-6-6.

The ventilation could be greatly improved if shields of framed Celloglass or ordinary glass about nine inches high be provided for two or three windows in each classroom, so that the windows could be opened an in or two at bottom all the time without causing direct draft on pupils' heads.

As suggested above, a marked improvement in each classroom would be obtained by having the desks fastened to slats in groups of three or four. The alignment in rows could then be secured with little difficulty as well as the proper spacing of the desks in the row. With loose desks the classroom always has the appearance of disorder and causes considerable trouble to teacher.
Ottawa, January 15, 1931.

Rev. Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his inspection of the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School in November, last, states that the ventilation in each of the classrooms could be greatly improved if deflectors of Celloglass or ordinary glass about nine inches high were installed on two or three of the windows in each classroom, in order that these windows could be kept open a few inches at the bottom without causing a direct draft on the pupils. The Inspector also states that a marked improvement in each classroom could be obtained by having the desks fastened to slats in groups of three or four. The alignment in rows could then be secured, as well as the proper spacing of the desks in the row. He states that with loose desks the classroom has the appearance of disorder and causes trouble to the teacher.

It is thought that, if material for the making of window deflectors and the lumber for the slats were provided, the staff of the school could do the work. I shall be pleased to hear from you regarding the above matters, giving an estimate of the cost of the materials required and stating whether, if same are supplied, the staff could make the deflectors and fasten the desks to the slats.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Rev. J. F. J. Marshall,
Principal, Indian Res. School,
Sioux Lookout, Ont.
With respect to the Indian Residential School, Anglican, at Pelican, I would beg to draw your attention to a condition examined by me on the occasion of a survey made some time ago.

The sewage disposal at this point is effected by means of a septic tank, the effluent from which is conducted directly into the lake without any further treatment. At the time of my inspection there was a considerable amount of the sewage mixture with effluvia. This was due to the fact that there was low water and the end of the original effluent is now exposed some 15 ft. above the normal water line. Wastes from the laundry and kitchen are on a separate system and do not pass through the tank. The sewage mentioned above is located on the west side of the bay around the point and about 700 ft. from the water intake. The direction of the current is downstream from the intake. I should say at the present time that I do not think there is any danger of pollution of the water supply.

As the soil at this point appears to be gravel with clay overburden, I think that there would be a suitable location for a filtration bed. This would be very desirable in view of the fact that the present contamination affects the water shed which may at some future time supply the town of Sioux Lookout and which at present supplies the Canadian National Railways at Sioux Lookout.

MR. INDIAN AGENT EDWARDS REPLIED IN PART AS FOLLOWS:

We were not aware of the fact owing to the low water, the end of the original effluent is now exposed some 15 feet above the normal water line. As this outlet is below the rapids, there is no danger, now or at any other time, of pollution at the intake of the water supply, or for the water supply for the town of Sioux Lookout or the National Railways.

You may rest assured that the Department's first consideration is for the health of the people, and we don't consider there is any danger to health at any of the schools.

Before installation of the sewage disposal plant at schools is made, great care is taken that the health situation is being cared for.
Ottawa, March 20, 1931.

The matter should receive prompt attention as the fiscal year 1930-31 is about to close and the cheque was drawn against the appropriation for the said year.

Yours truly,

F.H. Paget

Dear Sir,

In reference to Department letters Nos. 129/6/5 May 20th. and Aug. 20th., I am enclosing the accounts of A.A.J. MacDonald for $100.00, for cement, and Wm. Scraggie, $9.00, for freighting same to the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School. I regret that this account has been overlooked. As Miss Ross, whom you knew as Vice-Principal, has left us to start up a home of her own, there were a few things that took me some little time to get on to, and especially what I call "cached" filings.

On this work I only purchased a very limited amount of cement and did a large amount of the preparation work. As you know, we were unable to haul a sufficient amount of gravel last spring on account of one of our horses getting killed by a train; we have just finished up today with one team hauling gravel straight the last month and we expect to be able to complete the cement work early this coming summer and will have to ask later on for permission to buy sufficient cement to complete the work.

CANADA
Dear Captain Edwards:

Enclosed is an account for repairs to the boat engine. This breakage happened when you were away on the treaty trip, otherwise I would have wired you regarding the repair. The crank shaft broke when we were returning from town, opposite to Potts camp. The engine had a full supply of oil and it has been a puzzle to me as to what caused the break, other than the heavy strain on this type of motor.

I had taken the engine out thinking I might have been able to have made the necessary repairs but when I saw the main centre bearing broken I knew it was beyond our capacity. I had the boat towed into town by the Forestry and the mechanic from the Sioux Motors came down to examine it. He said from what he could judge the engine would have to go into Winnipeg as the main crank shaft was broken and part of the babbitt had scored the inside of the cylinder block; so being hard pushed for time I gave him instructions to go ahead and put the engine in running shape and to keep the price as low as possible, which I think he has. He installed the engine in the boat and gave it a good looking over after it had been running for three or four trips, but he warned me that with these converted automobile engines, and this style particularly, when the blocks have been re-bored and fitted with oversized pistons to make them into marine engines, it would be impossible if anything happened the cylinder blocks again to re-bore them and have them run with safety. This will mean condemning the engine and having to buy a new one.

I would strongly recommend to the Department that when they do consider buying a new engine that it would be one built for marine purposes only.

During the time that this boat was out of commission I had to walk in to town four times in the one
week and it is very awkward at the present time to get in by train as the local has cut off two trips a week; the other times they are very late, sometimes around seven and eight o'clock. This means it is useless to us if we have any business to be done in town.

I hope that you and the Treaty Party arrived home safely and that the Doctor isn't any the worse for the wear of his sixteenth annual treaty trip. I am sure that you are all glad to be back home once more.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

(Rev.) J. F. J. MARSHALL
Principal

Dear Sir,

On Sept. 16th, 1930, we submitted, by your request, through Indian Agent Edwards, a list of our needs. The third item on the program was sufficient paint to finish painting the rest of the interior of the school, the sewing room, dormitories, Chapel, classrooms, basement halls and laundry. We figured that about $450.00 would complete the job allowing about $150.00 for the painter, the balance for material.

The dormitories and classrooms could be done at the present time while the children are away from school. We have the old painter I spoke of before still with us and I have him going over part of these with sizing preparation awaiting your reply to purchase paint. We hope you may see your way clear to allow us to finish the painting of the interior. I may say that the outside has been finished and is a great improvement to the appearance as well a protection to the buildings.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Captain Edwards,

In reply to your letter asking for estimates for 1932-1933, we gladly submit the following, which are all urgently needed.

One Engine for gasoline boat, approximate cost $700.00

125 Mattresses, approximate cost $600.00

An allowance of $500.00 to purchase paint and cover the cost of wages for painter, to complete the interior of the school. Namely, sewing room, dormitories, Chapel, basement halls, laundry and staff sitting rooms.

Farm implements, approximate cost $125.00. Double mould-board plow and cultivator.

Replacing shafting in engine room, approximate cost $125.00. The present shafting is rather light for the work in hand and has at the present time been repaired twice. Heavier shafting was recommended by the engine inspector. This would necessitate new bushings in the pulleys. I would like if this work could be done this winter as any break in the shaft again might cause damage to the engine or dynamo and as the amount is not very exorbitant I would deem it on the part of safety to have it replaced.

Material for Indian house, approximate cost $2,000.00. This is much needed. When the Indians come to visit their children we have to put them to sleep in the classrooms. The labour can be done by the school management.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Captain Edwards,

On fixing up our tank, preparing for the winter season, we find that the pipes from the heater to the chimney need replacing. Also the pipes from the top of the hot air flue up the chute to the bottom of the tank, will nearly all need to be replaced.

Would you kindly give us permission to order these pipes made up out of heavy galvanized iron, as the ones we had before stood about three seasons. Last year I used some ordinary stove pipes but with so much dampness around they hardly stand one season. The cost not to exceed $50.00.

November, 27th, 1931.

Dear Sir:

Enclosed please find a letter received from the Principal, Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School asking authority to replace pipes from the Heater to the Chimney and from the top of the hot air flue up the chute to the bottom of the water tank, as these pipes are worn out.

As the cost does not exceed $25.00 and as this is a very urgent matter and absolutely necessary, we have given him the necessary authority, and will be glad to have the approval of the Department.

Mr. Marshall understands the economic situation and has asked for very little as he is trying to help and this should be taken into consideration.

He was here yesterday and asks if it will be possible for him to get the 100 Mattresses which he has already asked for and which are also necessary, as he now has a large number of pupils at the School.

The engine of his Launch is now completely played out and he would like the Department to purchase a new one to install in the Spring. Dr. Stone knows the necessity for this, as the School cannot be run in winter without a boat, there is no team road, and the only way to get to town is by walking the Railway track or taking the local, which only runs each way twice a week.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, December 1, 1931.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 27th ultimo, enclosing a communication which you received from the Principal of the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School requesting authority to replace pipes from the heater to the chimney and from the top of the hot air flue to the bottom of the water tank. It is noted that, as this matter was urgent, you have granted the necessary authority. Your action is approved, and when the work is completed, you should forward an account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred, which it is noted you state will not exceed $25.

Regarding the Principal's request to be supplied with 100 mattresses, I have to say that consideration is being given to providing an item in our Estimates to cover the cost of this equipment.

Regarding the request for a new engine for the launch, to be installed in the coming Spring, I shall be pleased if you will furnish an estimate of the cost of supplying an engine of the type required. Please furnish this information at an early date, in order that consideration can be given to providing the cost in the Estimates for the coming fiscal year.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

Dear Captain Edwards,

I have just received the enclosed from the Kermath people. These people quoted us prices on heavy engines, of $1,000 and over, so we wrote them again, asking for lighter engines and more suitable for our Gidley-Ford boat, and this is the best prices obtainable.

This FARR Marine motor is something new to me, I have never heard of them before. We might term it a Kermath Jr. and I would judge it would cost in the neighbourhood of $750, including freight and installing same. Or if the Department do not see their way clear to sanction such an amount, the rebuilt on Page One of the letter, seems a very good buy, but then again it is only a second hand engine.

We would appreciate it if you would kindly make inquiries from Stones regarding the FARR engine. I think we would be safe in putting our figure in around $750, even if we have to find out more regarding the qualifications of this engine that they recommend. We might need a new propeller of different pitch. You might let me have these letters back as we haven't had time to copy them. We are writing to the Kermath people for more information regarding this FARR engine.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

(Rev.) J. F. W. MARSHALL
Principal

We believe the Farr engine at the price quoted $685.00 F.O.B. Toronto, would be the best he could get for his purpose.
