Dear Sir,

We received your letter regarding fire escapes and fire drill No. 1-1-5, dated Feb. 1932, and wish to take advantage of your suggestion in the last paragraph - "Any Principal who is not satisfied with the fire escape and fire prevention facilities should report immediately to the Department."

We would like to place before the Department several things regarding the fire escapes in this school.

Both fire escapes are at the back of the building, the one on the boys side coming right down on the roof of the boiler room, with a seven foot drop, and the one on the girls side emptying into a cove made by the kitchen wall and the children's dining room wall. Both these places are very dangerous.

Our fire escapes are the iron stair type with very little protection for the small children at the sides. The exits on the girls side on the top floor are from the small dormitory and from a window, hinged door style, opening out against the wall, 41 inches from the floor. Immediately in front of this window is a toilet. It is the only fire escape for the big dormitory and intermediate on the top floor. On the next floor, still on the girls side, there is no fire escape out of the little girls dormitory, and the exit on this floor is from two windows half way down, opening with windows 31 inches from the floor. Then another exit from the girls hospital which necessitates going from the dormitory through three doors and two hallways, a very complicated exit and landing one into a maze of doors, then climb over a radiator and through a window 34½ inches from the floor.

The stairways in this school are exceptionally well planned out and are in my estimation safer by far than the outside fire escapes and should anything happen whereby the stairway was to give way, there would be mighty little chance of anyone being able to gain the fire escapes where they are placed. We also have put an extra hand rail on the wall side of the stairs. Safety first!

The same may be said of the boys side with the exception that there is a door going through the dispensary and into the sunroom which opens on to the fire escape letting down on to the boiler room roof. The two dormitories have their exits similar to those of the girls side; they would necessitate a drop of six feet onto the roof of the porch. The two top dormitories have their exits similar to those of the girls, from the smaller dormitory through a window 41 inches from the floor, also climbing over a toilet.

On the boys side the stairway is similar to that of the girls, splendidly planned, with a rest and fair sized landing halfway down each set of stairs.

On the main hall we have good exits; the main door, the residence door and a door leading on to the verandah from our sewing room, together with the two doors opening out on to the playground halfway between the main floor and the basement.
Having a personal dread of fire possibly born in one, and very well emphasized, I may say that I almost lost my life in the big Toronto fire of 1904, the following year having one in our own school building with it, with two others, until we put it out, two of us being severely burned, and spending 16 years in the north where in the summer one lives in dread of bush fires and in the winter from over heated stove pipes, or lamps, it means that I have made a study of possible fires and the best way to escape. Then the experience of the last fire in this school a year ago, still bears out the necessity of ever being on the watch. I may say that the fire extinguishers and hose in this building are the best that money can buy, and the fire extinguishers are adequate and kept up to date. Systematic patrols are made through the school in the day time as well as in the evening, the fire warder going through on his last trip from 10.30 P.M. to 2.00 A.M., and I personally go through the school from attic to basement about midnight. Our fireman is up at 2.30 A.M. leaving the time between 12.30 and 3.30 the only time in the 24 hours that no one is on patrol, and believe me the dormitories are locked.

What I wish to point out is the inadequacy of the present fire escapes on this school and the place where they empty out. As we are all alone on a point we realise that we have to depend wholly on ourselves in case of emergency and I have strongly recommended before, the advisability of purchasing the bank fire escape as built, I believe, by the Chicago Bridge & Iron Works, similar to the type that are on the majority of Winnipeg schools. I have visited the Winnipeg schools on more than one occasion to examine these fire escapes before I recommended them to the Department and am told do not provide a back stair to the dormitories on the second floor, at ease regarding the exits. Think what this type of fire escape go in effect, down the floors, the same as walking into a hall, and you will suddenly find yourself on the slide and in a few seconds land outside. On taking the matter up with some of the principals in Winnipeg, I asked them if there was any possibility of them obtaining and they claim there is not, that very few of them get away while on the way out. I strongly recommend this type to our Commission Authorities when in their office last April and also to the Department. I know they do not tend to add beauty from an architectural standpoint, as they look like two silos one on each end of the building, but when one knows what they are for, they add efficiency in the equipment line and considerable peace of mind to persons who have them in their schools.

If I may offer the suggestion, I do think it would be well worth the Department's while to look into this type of fire escape as they are long past the experimental stage.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

(Rev.) J. F. J. MARSHALL
Principal

Reverend Sir,

I have your letter of the 17th instant, with reference to fire prevention at the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School. The Department is glad to have your report in this connection and to note that you are treating this very important matter quite seriously. I may say that the Department does not supply the tube fire escapes as used in some public schools as our Architect believes the steel stair type is quite adequate as long as they are properly placed and the exits are satisfactory. The Department has pictures of your school taken from the rear, showing the location of the fire escapes and any comment you make will be quite understandable to our Architect. Can you recommend any other placing of these escapes to make them really efficient? Would it be possible to change the function of some of the rooms which lead to the escapes to assist in making the problem easier?

Your obedient servant,

Secretary.

STOIX LOOKOUT INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

Sioux Lookout, Ont.
March 7, 1932

Dear Sir,

We are submitting herewith account for 100 bags cement and freight, used on the work of the cement gutter, Department letter No. 129-6-b, August 5th, 1930.

Describing the work that we have done, in constructing this gutter around the main building we used up the labour appropriation on the heavier work of stone and digging. I was able to obtain the services of a man who had built stone drains in Scotland for the railway. He laid stone in around the main building 36 inches wide and 14 inches deep. To draw the water off from the cement we constructed two stone drains leading down to the river. This part of the work was completed a year ago and as the appropriation for labour had been used up we carried on with the cement work under the school management. Our cement ran out before we were around to the girls side so I got 100 bags to carry on and hope this amount will be sufficient to complete the work.

We also had trouble with our main drain from the school from time to time. This trouble was always in the same place so during the summer holidays when the drain was not so greatly used we built a cement manhole at the place where the trouble used to occur. Since then we have had very little difficulty with blockage. At the outlet to the drain, which was constructed during high water, we also put in another cement box to take the drop from the height, and also to act as a catch basin before the water ran on to the playroom floor. On raising the cement box to within about five feet of the river level, part with tile pipe, the balance with a wooden box. The outlet to this drain had caused considerable comment from the Medical Health Inspector. This work was done at the actual cost of material, with most of the material being on the place.

On looking over our letter to you of March 30th, 1931, I regret that I have overlooked the last sentence. I purchased this cement in good faith for the work but did not carry out as I had said and - "asked for permission to buy sufficient cement to complete the work."

I may say that the cement gutter is proving up very satisfactory as far as we have carried it around and we think will prevent the continual wetting of the play room floors in the spring time and after rain.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

(Rev.) J. P. J. MARSHALL
Principal

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, Canada

Indian Affairs. (RC 10, Volume 6215, file 470-5, part 2)
Dear Sir,

Our letter of today's date covering cement work, gives you notice of part of the work we have been carrying on this last summer. The floor in the barn, which is only of wood laid on 2x4 scantlings on top of a fill in, was very badly in need of repair, and knowing the shortage of funds we did not want to trouble you for any appropriation, as we considered it will only be a short time before we will have put in a good cement floor in the entire barn. So we ripped out the floor in the cattle stalls and also in part of the horse stable. We used what parts of the planks we could and if you remember we had a two plank road around the school; we lifted each end of it so as we needed to replace the floor of the stalls in the cattle and the horse stable. This is the third time we have replaced the floors in the horse stalls and we raised the floor in the cow stalls in some places six inches, filling in under with stone and gravel.

We also overhauled the water tank and practically rebuilt the little house holding the heater and the pipes, as the ice almost demolished it. The entire wooden casing around the pipes dropped clean through the roof of the taking room and all with it. We jacked up the wooden casing that is around the pipe, which is about a 3' box by 50' long, putting in new supports under it made of 6x6. The old ones were only 2x4. When we overhauled the tank we noted that a number of the iron rods will be needing replacing in the near future but we hope we will be able to carry on for another year.

The latter part of the summer of 1930 being a dry season we took advantage of the dryness and put through a fairly deep ditch, draining the muskeg back of the school out to the lake. Then we built in a crib work of lumber and poles as a pipe before we filled it in. This proved very satisfactory in the second fall although the ground in the low lying areas is sour, we were able to plow and seed it with some clover. The balance of the part immediately behind the school is cleared back to where you saw the first tree line and with that and the small garden we have planted there, we took in 600 bushels of potatoes. We had a fair amount of other vegetables seeded but in June we had a sand storm come through from Saskatchewan that settled all over this district. I think some of the people in the surrounding country thought that the plagues of Egypt had come upon them. We had cut worms and caterpillars immeasurably and the grasshoppers were a burden, so that our vegetable stuff was cleaned out completely, even cleaning off the rhubarb leaves, but we were very grateful for the abundant crop of potatoes which helped materially in the food question of the school. We always have a little job that keeps us busy in spare time, which is pulling out stumps.
Regarding the children this year, the health of the little ones has been very good, with two serious cases, one of appendicitis which we had to rush in to the hospital. Otherwise, they seem to have become acclimatized to their surroundings and also have a good appetite for the white man's food, which is sure enough to go very hard on the little ones and on their stomachs, and it takes considerable watching to guard against upsetting them. Some will not even drink milk who have been here for over a year but they get it in various other forms.

We had some difficulty in maintaining the number that we have as during the holidays an epidemic of smallpox broke out in the Pagwa River, in the settlement to the south of the bridge. A number of our people lived to the north of the bridge and on the opposite side of the river. When they heard that the doctor pronounced it smallpox, a number of them were missing the next morning, and they had not returned back to the settlement at the time when I visited them about August 25th. Nor had they returned to the settlement even for Christmas. This epidemic meant that five of our boys had not returned to school. It came too far to go after them so I immediately filled their places with other children, from this, or other reserves.

We have twelve names on our register of children not returned this term who are out for various causes; some through sickness, some through death, and three through absolute indifference on the part of the parents. This number was greater than I had expected and together with the number who had left owing to age or graduation, left a greater number to hunt up as new pupils. We are very fortunate in being able to recruit the number that we did in such a short time. We are carrying now as many as we have beds for and have applications on hand for several that are coming in in the spring.

This is just a little insight into the work that does not appear on general reports and I know you like to hear from time to time how we are getting along. Thanking you for past considerations of our needs and assuring you that we will do our very best to keep things up to the mark and the requirements as low as possible, I remain,

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

(Rev.) J. F. J. MARSHALL
Principal

The Secretary,

Rev. Sir:

I have your letters of the 7th instant, with reference to the account which you submit covering the cost of 100 bags of cement and freight, used on the cement gutter at the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School. The work that was carried out in this connection has been noted, and it is hoped, as a result, that this will prevent the continual wetting of the playroom floors in the Spring and after rains. The account for the cement and freight will be paid in due course.

I have also noted the work that was carried out in repairing the floor in the barn, overhauling the old water tank and wooden casings around the water pipes; also the draining of the muskeg back of the school.

Your remarks regarding the health of the pupils and the difficulty in having several of them returned after the summer holidays have also been noted.

I wish to thank you for the report regarding the work carried out during the past year.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,

On our inspection trip to the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School, a few days ago, when we were returning from the north treaty trip, the Principal informs us that he had received no information re the new engine for his boat. In this connection we would refer you to our letter of February 23rd last. Would you kindly look into this matter, as there are no roads to Sioux Lookout from the School, and they have to depend mostly on water travel.

Sir:

Reverend Sir:

Boiler Inspector J.M. Kelly reports on the boilers at your School as follows:

"Vertical boiler for laundry purposes has improved internal appearance. Boilers 1142 and 1143, Soda has also improved the internal appearance of these boilers and advise this treatment be continued. Uptakes between boiler smoke boxes and chimney to be cleaned out."

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6215, file 470-5, part 2)
Ottawa, November 21, 1932.

Sir:

The Reverend Principal of the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School, who recently visited the Department, drew attention to the need of replacing the present shafting in the engine room. This shafting is rather light for the work, and heavier shafting has been recommended by the engine inspector. We understand this work would necessitate new bushings, and that the estimated cost of installing the heavier shafting would be approximately $125.

I have to request that you will take this matter up with the Principal and ascertain from him definitely what is required, and you should then arrange for the purchase of the equipment required and for the installation of same. The school authorities would, no doubt, be able to provide the greater amount of the labour in carrying out the work. The total cost of this improvement should not exceed the amount stated above. After the heavier shafting has been installed, please forward an account, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred.

Attention was also drawn to the need of replacement of the metal fittings on the toilet seats, at an estimated cost of $50. I have also to request that you will take up this matter with the Principal and arrange for the purchase of the fittings required and have same installed on the toilet seats. If possible, the cost should be kept within the estimate. Accounts, in triplicate, properly certified, should be forwarded covering this expenditure.

Your obedient servant,

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

Dear Captain Edwards,

We are enclosing invoices for steam pipe and fittings which we had to wire to Ashdowns for as the pipes in the hot water tank had become corroded and the water was leaking into the boilers. We got Ashdowns to send these things down rush and we worked all night to rip the old ones out. We plugged the intake and outlet of the hot water tank so we could keep the boilers working and when Ashdowns rushed the pipe through it was not a question of the same thing the night after. We carry no steam pipe on hand, therefore the rush order. We hope you will not think it is presumption on our part, getting these repairs first and then asking afterwards, but it meant maintaining our fires pretty well at all costs.

I was surprised at the pipes we had taken out. They were in good condition on the part where the steam ran through but on the part exposed to the hot water tank itself they were eaten away to such an extent that I pushed a 2½ inch nail through them in some places. I must take this matter up with Inspector Kelly and see if he can recommend something that might be painted on the pipes that have to go in to the boiler and are exposed to the water. As the water is used for bathing, dish washing and general use, one cannot use any strong solution that would become detrimental to its use in other parts of the building. However, I find it in good shape before I left for Toronto, but on return found that the invoices were not made out properly. I had to return them to Ashdowns and they have just been returned to us.

The 12 machine bolts also belong to the same piece of work as we had to saw the bolts off the brackets erected on the inside of the tank to hold the pipes, to get the pipes out.

We are also enclosing an account for gasoline fuel tank, duly certified. We had to write three times to get the receipted freight bill, they seemed to think the ordinary shipping bill would do, but it does not.

Hoping all this will meet with your approval, we remain,

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

(Rev.) J. F. J. MARSHALL

Ottawa, February 21, 1933.

Rev. Sir:

I have your telegram of the 20th instant directed to Dr. Stone, of this Department, stating that the connecting shaft of the engine used for lighting and pumping purposes at the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School broke down and that it was necessary to have the engine shipped to Winnipeg for repairs, and, in the meantime, obtain the loan of an engine to carry on.

In this connection I have to confirm my telegram of today's date, sent you in care of the R. A. Lister Company, Winnipeg:

"Have necessary repairs made to engine. Keep costs low as possible."

The breakage of the shaft of the engine and consequent inconvenience to the school is regretted. It is presumed you are having the R. A. Lister Company undertake the repairs and furnish the loan of an engine. As instructed in telegram, you should keep all costs in the carrying out of the repairs and for transportation as low as possible. Please arrange to have the repairs completed and the engine returned and functioning at the school at the earliest possible date.

After the work has been completed, you should obtain an itemized account, in triplicate, showing in detail the repair work carried out, also receipts covering all transportation charges for forwarding broken engine to Winnipeg and returning same to the school, and for the charges in the transportation of the engine loaned. If the Lister Company pay the transportation charges, the amount should be included in their account. You should certify the accounts in the usual manner and forward same for payment, with receipt for all transportation charges attached. If possible, these accounts should reach the Department before the end of March, next, in order that payment can be made from current Appropriation before our books close for the present fiscal year.

I shall be pleased to hear further from you when the repairs have been effected and the engine has been returned and put to use at the school.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary

Rev. J. F. J. Marshall,
Principal, Indian Residential School,
Sioux Lookout, Ont.

The Secretary,

OTTAWA, Canada
Dear Sir,

In compliance with your letter No. 129-5-5 dated Feb. 21st, 1933, I am pleased to submit the following report on the breakdown of the engine of the lighting plant at the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School.

Our lighting plant is an R.A. Lister 10-12 H.P., which runs the dynamo direct drive. This engine supplies us with power for our lighting, pumping our water, running our laundry and our bread mixer.

On the evening of Feb. 20th, the engineer had just left the engine room to go on his rounds to see that the water in the automatic flush toilets and the toilets were turned off for the night. He had just made his round up as far as the first floor when the buzzer from the water tank gauge sounded, meaning that the water tank was full. He immediately went down to stop the pump and on entering the engine room noticed something wrong with the engine and immediately shut it down. He came up to the office for me, it was about ten minutes after nine. I went down with him to the engine room, we examined the engine and found that the connecting rod had come loose and had broken through the side of the base on which the engine is built. Upon further examination we found that the piston and the cylinder head were badly damaged. I then looked around for the cause of the break and found in the bottom of the base a broken connecting rod bolt, one nut and a broken cotter pin. I showed same to the mechanic from the garage who came out to do the welding. He gave it some technical name but it simply means that the steel in the bolt had sort of become crystallized and broke. On overhauling our engine, we have used new cotter pins wherever possible there was likely to be a strain. The engine carries sufficient oil at all times to keep the bearings lubricated as it pumps from the base to the bearings and there were nearly two gallons of oil in the base at the time.

I then realised the necessity of quick action and on sizing up as far as possible the damage done to the engine, I gave instructions that no water was to be used from the pressure tank for general use and that the boys could go on the bucket brigade to supply the necessary water to satisfy their thirst. I also left instructions with the engineer to adjust the line shaft the next day so that we could use the tractor for pumping water. (This he had almost completed on my return Wednesday.) I then left for Sioux Lookout to catch No. 1, which passes through at 1.30 A.M. for Winnipeg.

On arrival I proceeded direct to the firm of R.A. Lister and consulted with their manager, Mr. Munford, and his chief mechanic, as to the best thing to do under the circumstances. As they had no engine of our type in stock at the time, I looked over several of their other engines to see if they could be hooked up with our engine plant as a substitute. There was one they had which made a very complete unit and could have been attached to

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6215, file 470-5, part 2)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
our dynamo with an extended shaft and pulley being put on the engine of the dynamo and the dynamo to be driven by a belt. This outfit would have weighed crated close on to a ton. It would have also necessitated the mechanic coming down with tools to adjust the dynamo to the dynamo. The mechanic's transportation from the time of travelling would have amounted to about $10.00 freight would have amounted to about 10. or $12. on the engine. At the end of the discussion, we came to the conclusion to give the old Fordson a trial the way I had previously instructed the engineer.

I then collected some of the parts that I knew were so badly damaged as to be beyond repair and took the flight train back to Sioux Lookout, and it had to be late that night. Wednesday morning I was out early and routed out the owner of the garage and his mechanic to see if they could come out to the school to weld the broken parts. On examining their gas gauge they found they had not sufficient gas or air in their tanks to do an extended job. They promised they would borrow one from the C.N.R. shops or some place, and asked me to make arrangements to have it transported from Sioux Lookout to the school, as they were unable to get things in time to have them come on the local which leaves Sioux Lookout at 4:30 A.M. Upon arrival at the school I sent six boys with the Boy's Master, in to town to haul the mechanics outfit out on a large hand sleigh. This outfit weighed, with the tanks and all complete, nearly 500 lbs.

The engineer and myself completed the work of adjusting the shaft and getting the tractor driving with a belt through the window to work pumping water and we adjusted one of the pulleys from the laundry on to the engine of our dynamo and were able to keep our batteries charged, but were not able to drive it fast enough to give them a continuous light in the school, so they reverted to a supply of lanterns that I keep in stock.

We worked through dismantling the engine and had it ready for the mechanic to start his part of the work in preparation for welding. He and his helper started about 10 o'clock and I was to waken them at 6 A.M., when we went to work on the welding itself. This was completed by 7 o'clock in the morning and they walked back into town.

As soon as the engine base was cool enough to handle the engineer and myself started in to reassemble the engine and when the other parts which we had sent to Winnipeg for arrived on the passenger train, we completed the work and had the engine running again smoothly and were able to get back to our regular routine the following Tuesday.

Personally, I do not think that the breakage was caused by neglect. I still retain the parts which were broken, which I found in the base of the base. No one regrets more than the engineer and myself the engine breaking loose, as we have taken an emotional pride in our lighting plant as well as the rest of the whole plant. The engineer particularly, being an Englishman, and coming not far from where the diesel oil firms works are, has that English pride in the British made goods. I don't know of any other way, other than replacing bolts from time to time, to guard against such breakdowns, but we can assure you that we are taking the best
of care of these things to the best of our ability and when not knowing enough of certain parts of the plant we call in an inspector, or ask for advice from the manufacturers of such.

I hope this will give you a full, if lengthy, report on our recent expenditure, and wish to thank you for so quickly coming to our aid when in distress.

I addressed this wire to Dr. Stone, knowing that he had visited the school and personally knew the plant, and hope it was not conflicting Department business in any way.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

(Rev.) J. F. J. MARSHALL
Principal

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, Canada
Dear Captain Edwards,

This is in reference to your note on "How about the $75.00 for transportation." Really, we have been so rushed the last couple of months it was hard to get time to think. I have had this transportation on the go off and on since before Christmas and now we have got it to the stage where it is now coming in the envelope. We have picked out the nearest to the $75.00 we possibly could, which is $75.15. Our transportation this year has run to about $345.00 and we are very glad indeed to have the $75.00 grant from the Department to assist towards bringing the children back to school again.

To ease your mind, our lighting plant is in running order again. I haven't received any accounts yet but expect them in on the next mail. Therefore, I am unable to say what the actual cost will be, but did not fail to ship the engine down to Winnipeg at a substantial saving. We plugged old Henry on to the line shaft and kept the water supply up to regular height, also turning the dynamo over to keep the batteries charged, but as Henry Fordson was outside, and the line shaft, pump and dynamo inside, we used very little electric light.

We had to get a man out from Sioux Lookout to do the welding for us. Mr. Mayo, Jack and myself re-fitted the engine into running order again. The welders were the proverbial plumbers, leaving the connection pipe from the building like a ditch through the middle of the building. Jack walked into town and came out on the midnight with the parts that fitted and I wakened them up at 4 o'clock A.M. so they had their work over before eight, and were able to walk into town.

The other accounts I am chasing up so as to have them all in next week.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]
(Rev.) J. F. J. MARSHALL
Principal

Captain Frank Edwards,
Indian Agent,
KENORA, Ontario

A short time ago we received a wire from the Principal, informing us that the engine that supplies Water and Light had gone wrong and that he had gone to Winnipeg to see about the necessary repairs. He also informed us that he had communicated with Ottawa by telegraph, so we did not notify you.

We inclose a letter we have now received from the Principal explaining what he has done to repair the engine and presume that the Department will authorize the payment of the accounts. We do not know what they will amount to, but we know that the Principal will keep them as low as possible.

We would like to take this opportunity of mentioning the splendid co-operation and endeavour the Principal is using, to keep down expenditure at the School.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 4th instant, enclosing a communication which you received from the Principal of the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School with reference to the repairs to the engine that supplies water and light.

In this connection I have to say that the Principal has also written the Department in the matter. We are pleased that he was able to have repairs effected, and at a minimum of cost. Ottawa, March 14, 1933.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 9th instant, reporting on the breakdown of the engine that supplies water and light to the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School, and stating, in detail, the action taken in having the repairs required carried out.

In this connection I have to say that the Department is pleased to learn that you have succeeded in placing this engine in a satisfactory condition, and it is hoped that it will give good service for a considerable time. The inconvenience occasioned by the damage to the pump is regretted, and the engineer and yourself are commended for the prompt action taken in making the repairs. The Department is also pleased with the splendid co-operation of yourself and the staff in keeping all expenses at this school to the minimum cost.

The accounts which you forwarded covering the cost of repairs, to the amount of $132.59, will be paid in due course. Cheques will be directed to the various firms for the amount of their accounts submitted by you.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,

Dear Captain Edwards,

Am enclosing the invoices for lumber purchased from Brown & Rutherford, your letter dated Oct. 19th, 1932, Department letter #129-6-5 of Oct. 15th, 1932, the amount not to exceed $100.00. We did not exceed the $100.00 but came pretty close to it. The work of repair, making these benches and other things is being done under school management, and I may say we have turned the staff living room into a carpenter shop.

I had to hold these sanctions over until I had an opportunity of going to Winnipeg, which was presented when I took Lizzie Thompson and Mary Chisel to Dynever Hospital. A lot of this had to be described other than could be done by letter.

I had a letter from Mary Chisel and she seems to be doing well, but Lizzie is not too good. I am sending Mary's letter over to you so you can read it yourself and let Mr. Meikle read it.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]
(Rev.) J. F. J. MARSHALL

Dear Captain Edwards,

In reference to your letter of Nov. 24th. and copy of Department letter No. 129-6-5 of Nov. 21st. re. the replacing of the metal fittings for toilet seats, I have at last got trace of and procured these by having the Winnipeg Brass make these special fittings for our toilet seats, as they were of an obsolete type.

You will find enclosed the account, plus receipts for express and C.O.D. charges, to the amount of $38.51. I don't know why they sent these things C.O.D. but I dare say they are not even depending on schools paying their legitimate debts. However, I paid for them and now have some of them on doing duty. Dear Captain Edwards,

Am enclosing the invoices for shafting and equipment authorized in your letter of Nov. 24th. and Department letter #129-6-5 of Nov. 21, 1932, the amount not to exceed $125.00. We have here the invoices of the Beaver Laundry Machinery Co. for $21.87, replacing the shafting and pulley on the extractor, which was badly needed. Also the Canadian Fairbanks-Morse Co. Ltd. for $57.75 and $7.50. We have another one from Ashdowns, they had to procure the goods from the East and as they have been some time getting them we did not deem it wise to hold these invoices up any longer. The Ashdown invoice will be around $30. or $31.00, making a total of about $117.00.

I may say that there are no labour charges to be taken into consideration as we did the work ourselves and we appreciate the kindness of the Department in supplying us the necessary things to work with. I count it as certainly up to us, where we have the knowledge and the tools, to save in matters like this and do the work ourselves.

Dear Captain Edwards,-

In our covering letter to you of March 9th. re. the invoices of Fairbanks-Morse and Beaver Laundry Machinery Co. for shafting, we stated the Ashdown invoices were late in coming. They have since arrived and am enclosing the same. If perchance the invoice covering the express charges is on the mail when I arrive in town, I will enclose it. I am also getting the express receipt from Len Graham, and if the charges come along later, will take care of them in petty cash, so this will enable the Department to close up the account for shafting - their letter of Nov. 21st. 1932, No. 129-6-5.

The set of dies I had to purchase, as on replacing the shafting, there were a number of bolts which we had to re-thread and I got tired of carrying them into town, so decided to include this small outfit, which will come in very useful for other things, on the shafting order. The Cement also comes in under that heading.

Hoping this will enable the Department to clear this account before the end of the month,

Yours faithfully,

Dear Sir,

The enclosed cheque, No. 3596, March 27th, 1933, for $225.37, was received on our mail yesterday. I note on checking over these amounts that the amount that should be coming to me is $88.51, an account from the Winnipeg Brass, who sent them good C.O.D. and I redeemed them, forwarding the receipted C.O.D. railway voucher.

The amount of $99.74 is for Brown & Rutherford of Winnipeg, Department letter #129/6/5, dated 15th October 1932, lumber material purchased, not to exceed $100.00.

The amount of $87.12 is sanctioned in Department letter #129/6/5, Nov. 21st, 1932, and the amount is made up - Ist. Beavco Laundry Machinery Co. Toronto $21.85 End. Fairbanks-Morse of Winnipeg $65.25

If by returning this cheque and having the other new cheques made out would involve a total of $225.37 being brought in under 1933 appropriation I would willingly have the return of the cheque and me depositing the cheques and issue cheques covering various accounts, obtaining receipted invoices, and forward same to you. As I know this year you will need every cent that you possibly can save. I had thought over this way of doing it, then again I considered it might lead to some difficulty in the Finance Department if I deposited the cheque and paid the accounts, as they might require cancelled cheques.

However, I am willing to help out in the best way you see fit, therefore I am placing it in your hands so it may not cause any inconvenience to your 1933 appropriation. As I stated before, $88.51, is the only amount of this cheque that is due me.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

(Rev.) J. F. J. MARSHALL
Principal

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada

CANADA
Ottawa, April 10, 1933.

Dear Mr. Marshall:

I have your letter of the 6th instant, regarding the cheque which was sent you to the amount of $225.37.

It would simplify things here if you would deposit this cheque to your credit and forward your personal cheque in payment of the accounts of Brown & Rutherford, $99.74; Beaver Laundry Machinery Co., $21.87, and Fairbanks-Morse, $65.25, and obtain receipts from these firms, which please forward to the Department. I shall be pleased if you will send these receipts addressed to me. By doing this, it will save depositing the cheque here and issuing new cheques. Our books for the fiscal year, which ended March 31st, last, are now being closed, and the receipts will be required by the Auditor General.

I return herewith the cheque for $225.37, and shall be pleased if you will make payment to the firms mentioned, obtaining their receipts and forwarding same as soon as possible.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. Sutherland,
For Supt. of Indian Education.

Rev. J. F. J. Marshall,
Principal, Indian Res. School,

**Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6215, file 470-5, part 2)**
Ottawa, August 12, 1933.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 8th instant, regarding the inspection of the boilers at the Indian Residential Schools in your agency. It is noted that the suggestions made by the Inspector at each of the Cecilia Jeffrey, McIntosh and Kenora Schools are being carried out and that all dangerously exposed parts of equipment will be guarded.

With reference to the Sioux Lookout Residential School, the Principal should arrange to have the gears on the mangle guarded. As the cost will be small, it is considered the school authorities should carry out the work without expense to the Department. I would request that you advise the Principal to arrange for having proper guards placed on the gears of the mangle as soon as possible.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

EXTRACT FROM LETTER FROM MR. J. D. SUTHERLAND,
Acting Superintendent of Indian Education, reporting
on his visit to the SIoux LOOKOUT RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL,
date of letter, September 6, 1933.

xxxxxxxxxxxxxx

The Agent and I got a plane and flew
part of the way to Sioux Lookout. We have a well
managed school at this point. As you will see, there
is $1,000.00 available for this school. Agent Edwards
is forwarding accounts to the amount of $200.00
covering cost of repairs to a tractor. Later, the
Principal and the Agent will forward prices for a
new engine for the school launch.
DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

WINNIPEG, MAN...September 7th, 1933.

Sir:-

I visited the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School on the 2nd instant. This school is beautifully situated and is in splendid condition. The Principal is busy clearing land, using a tractor for the purpose. It was necessary for him to incur an expense of approximately $200.00 for this purpose. There is $1,000.00 available in our appropriation for this school this year and Agent Edwards will submit accounts covering the cost of repairs.

The only means of reaching this school in summer is by motor boat. A new engine is badly needed. I told the Principal that the Department would likely be able to provide the funds this year, and he and Agent Edwards will obtain prices from a firm on the approved list for a motor of a type that would be satisfactory and submit same to the Department.

When the accounts covering the cost of repairs to the tractor are received, I would recommend that they be paid.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, October 19, 1933.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 6th instant, relative to the request of the Principal of the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School for authority to purchase an engine for the school boat and also to pay the cost of the repairs to the tractor at the school - the total expenditure for both purposes not to exceed $800.

In reply I have to say that the Department will pay the cost of having the repairs carried out to the tractor, to an amount not exceeding $200. You should therefore obtain itemized accounts covering the cost of materials and labour. These you should attach proper voucher forms, certify in the usual manner and forward for payment. Please state on each copy of your voucher that the expenditure was incurred under authority of E. R. No. 1053.

With reference to the purchase of an engine for the school boat, I have to say that the Department will approve of the Principal and yourself arranging to obtain an engine, of a type that would be of sufficient capacity to operate the boat. You should obtain prices for the supplying of this equipment from firms on the list to receive tenders. The cost, if possible, the cost of the engine delivered at Sioux Lookout, should not exceed the sum of $600. It would be advisable for you to consult the Principal regarding the type and manufacture of the engine considered by him to be satisfactory. An account, in triplicate, stating full particulars regarding the engine supplied and the cost obtained, etc., you should attach proper voucher forms, certify in the usual manner and forward for payment after the engine has been delivered to the satisfaction of the Principal. Please state on each copy of the voucher that the expenditure was incurred under authority of E. R. No. 1053, a copy of which is enclosed.

It is hoped that it will be possible to secure the engine at a price not exceeding the above authorized amount. When forwarding the account, please attach the quotations received. The purchase of this engine should receive your early attention.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Form No. 101
Dear Sir,

On our mail this morning we received the enclosed letter from the Kermath Manufacturing Co. through their Toronto agent. The prices of this would come in under Mr. Sutherland's amount quoted to us, and to keep it in under the $700, the school would take over the freight and the cost of installing the engine into the boat.

The Kermath seems to me to be the most reliable and well built power plant for marine work in all the engines that I have known, and I have been around water places most of my life. I have been in boats since I was 8 years old. I have looked into and inquired into other makes, but on the majority of them they have sacrificed durability for speed and lightness, therefore they are not to be classed with the Kermath.

I think if we carry out Mr. Sutherland's instructions in sending him these letters direct addressed to him personally, they will receive better attention than going through the ordinary channel, and I do hope that we succeed in getting this Kermath as quoted in their letter of October 20th. Here's the best of luck for it.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]
(Rev.) J. F. J. MARSHALL
Principal

Indian Agent,

Form No. 101
Dear Captain Edwards,

On your recent visit to our school, February 26th, we were taking up the matter of washing the milk cans, pails, etc. This you noted had to be done in the sink in the scullery, the same sink as used for washing all children's dishes. I remarked then that I did not consider it very sanitary or satisfactory to wash milk pails, etc., in the same sink as the children's dishes, against it as there was no other place where we could wash them. The sinks in the kitchen, dairy and bakery are of the shallow type ordinary kitchen sink; so I thought it advisable to bring to your attention the necessity of having a wash sink for the milking utensils alone.

I have also been in communication with the Alberta Dairy Supply Co. of Winnipeg, and have found out they have a two compartment sink which they supply to the dairies, butchers, bakers and farms for washing their pails and pans. This is made up of heavy galvanized iron, with four iron legs. The total length of the sink is 72 inches by 27 inches wide, depth 16 inches. The price quoted was $25.00 F.O.B. Winnipeg.

If the Department would supply us with the sink, we would do the necessary fittings, that is, connecting up the water pipes and the drainage from the sink.

I may say that I dread the summer time coming on when hot water is not as plentiful as it is in the winter, making it necessary for the extra washing of the children's sink both before and after the washing of the milk pans.

I do hope you had a few minutes to spare to call around at the Alberta Dairy Supply Co., who handle these various wash sinks and tanks. Or if there was anything else they may have shown you while you were there that might be more suitable for our purpose, we would be very glad indeed to have the information.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

(Rev.) J. F. J. MARSHALL
Principal

Captain Frank Edwards,
Indian Agent,
KENORA, Ontario
Dear Sir:

Enclosed please find a letter from the Reverend Principal of the Sioux Lookout Residential School. He requests us to purchase a double compartment sink for washing milk cans, pails etc., as at the present time they have to be washed in the same sink as the children's dishes, not a very sanitary arrangement. While in Winnipeg the other day, I called on the Alberta Dairy Co. and discussed the matter with them. The sink mentioned by the Principal at a cost of $25.00 is very reasonable and we would like, if possible, to get authority to purchase this for the school, as we consider it very necessary for sanitary reasons.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6215, file 470-5, part 3)
I had the pleasure of visiting this school today and was pleased to meet the Principal, Mr. Marshall and many of the staff. I was shown around the buildings and also the farm. I was particularly interested in the large herd of beautiful cows, which have been tested and the milk that has been used by the children.

I was pleased with the appearance of the children and the cleanliness of the rooms. However, I observed one serious drawback—there is no proper fire escape. Should a fire occur, I am afraid the result will be most serious. It seems to me that something should be done to avoid this danger.

I also noticed that the floors were rather damp. Marshall said he would be quite willing to put in cement floors if the Department would.
Sir,

I beg to enclose the application of Daniel Masakeyosh, the son of David Masakeyosh, No. 195 Osnabugh Band for admission into the Pelican Lake Residential School.

As this boy has been pronounced medically fit, I have advised the father that he may send the boy to the school when it reopens about the first of September.

Sincerely,

[Signature]

SIOUX LOOKOUT INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

Sioux Lookout, Ont.,
July 27, 1934.

Dear Captain Edwards:

I just returned yesterday from the trip east, bringing Mrs. Marshall with me, whom I am glad to say is much improved after her holiday. Now I am getting down to clearing the basket, if it is possible for once in a while to see the bottom.

I am somewhat puzzled over your letter of July 14th regarding letter #189-6-5 of the 10th instant. We had Mr. Arey here on a visit while staying over in Sioux Lookout together with Dr. Mitchell and two other Doctors. As we discussed the matter they said he visited the broken planks in part of it and I told him we had made application for a new cement floor and had hoped that the Department would have seen their way clear to have granted us the amount and permission to put it in. This you will readily have been able to see for the last few years and when Mr. Sutherland was up here last year he realized the conditions under which we were working; I suppose that due to his illness the matter has been overlooked. I do hope this isn't another way they have of putting it off for another indefinite period.

I think, with your permission, I will delay the purchase of the suitable planks to replace the broken ones, which practically will mean delaying the barn until after we have seen the Health of Animals Inspector there to see the cattle on the block tested for contagious abortion, as personally I think that the condition under the planks may be the breeding place of this germ which has evidently got into our herd. I would not want to have the extra cost of planks and the work of laying them if the Health of Animals Inspector was to condemn the floor that was already in the barn. I may say that we expect the Veterinary Doctor at any time, as this is the months they like to test the herds for this and T.B., and will write you as soon as possible after the visit of this Health of Animals Branch Inspector.

Yours faithfully,

(Sgd.) John F.J. Marshall,
Principal.

Capt. Frank Edwards,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

SIOUX LOOKOUT INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

Sioux Lookout, Ont.,
July 27, 1934.

Dear Captain Edwards:

Re. the last paragraph of your letter of July 14th were Mr. Awrey states the serious lack of fire escapes. This matter has been under investigation at different times both with the late Mr. Russell Ferrier and at the time Mr. Sutherland and yourself were over here a year ago, but to alter the present fire escapes would involve a considerable amount of money.

As Mr. Awrey was going through the school he noted the outlets, but as I stated to him, all these outlets were on and around stairways and if your stairway was endangered your fire escapes were practically useless. So true to the word of continual supervision, carefulness in smoking all fires, and I myself personally patrolling the building from top to bottom every night between eleven and twelve. I have gone into the fire escape question not only on this but on other schools and buildings and made a study of it; and after considering various types I have come to the conclusion that the tank system seems to be very best where schools or institutions have a number of people depending on open stairways for safe exit. I also looked into the costs of these at the time and reported the same to the Department in our letter of February 14th, 1933 and haven't had any reason to change my opinion regarding them rather in other ways I have seen this type of fire escape on the increase even taken up by hospitals, but as I stated above, at the present time the cost of them is prohibitive.

When Mr. Awrey and the company of Doctors were here, I had not understood that they were on an inspection tour and I think these things have all been carefully noted by yourself and that you have done all that can be done, without any further inspection.

Yours faithfully,

(Sgd.) J. F. J. Marshall
Principal.

Capt. Frank Edwards,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6215, file 470-5, part 3)
Ottawa, September 14, 1934.

Sir:

I beg to refer you to official letter dated May 9th, 1934, in reply to yours of April 30th, regarding the request that a quantity of wire fencing material be supplied for use at the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School.

It is now found that there will be funds to the amount of approximately $125.00, to purchase the 300 rods of wire field fencing requested by the Principal. It is understood this wire is required for the east and west line fences of the school property. You may, therefore, arrange for the purchase and forwarding to the school of approximately 300 rods of No. 5400/9 wire field fencing. Purchase should be made from a firm on the approved list and the total cost should not exceed the amount stated above. After the purchase has been made, please forward an account, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred. It might be well for you to discuss with the Principal the quantity and type of fencing required, before placing the order. It is understood that the labour in erecting the fence will be performed by the school, without expense to this Department.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

CANADA
Dear Sir,

The following is copy of letter received from the Principal of the Sioux Leoscut Indian Residential School, Sioux Leoscut, Ont.

October 12, 1934.

Dear Captain Edwards,

In reply to your letter asking for estimates for the year 1935, we are submitting the following in order as to their greatest need.

1. Cement floor and steel fittings for Barn.
   Estimated cost
   Cement $300.00
   Steel fittings $200.00
   Lumber $100.00
   Total $600.00

When our Barn was built in 1926, it was built on the side of a hill with considerable fill in on one side and the end. It was therefore economical to put in a wooden floor with wooden partitions for cattle. Since then, the floor has settled and plank floors have filled up with gravel three times to make up for the settling of the ground, doing the necessary repairs with whatever plank we happened to have around the place, but the floor is very unsanitary and impossible to keep clean.

The Veterinary Inspector states same to be the cause of infection in the case of sickness and abortions. The necessary work for this work can be handled in the winter time, if you let us know in time.

2. One new set of batteries for lighting plant.
   Approximately $500.00

3. Farm Implements:
   1 Double Mouldboard Plow
   1 Hay Rake
   1 Seed Drill
   Approximately $500.00

4. Paint. An allowance for paint to complete the interior of the school, namely: Sleeping dormitories, Chapel, Basement Hall, Laundry and Sitting rooms.
   Approximate cost $500.00

Yours faithfully,

(Sgd) John F. J. Marshall,
Principal.

As the estimates for this Agency were sent to the Inspector in Winnipeg this year for the first time, I am sending a copy of this letter to him for his files.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Dear Sir,

On Nov. 7th, 1934, I wrote you regarding the breakdown of our generator, stating that I had shipped the coil in by express to R.A. Listers agents, Mumford, Medland, Ltd. The firm wired back stating they wanted the other part of the generator, the same was shipped to them without delay.

A broken wire causing the short circuit, according to the statement of the electrician of Mumford Medland, burnt out considerable of the inside wiring of the commutator. This made it necessary to rewind and rebuild the commutator. It took some considerable time to do this.

When we received the generator back we could not get satisfactory lighting and looking for further trouble we found it in the control box; that certain plates which hold each grill plates had also been burned out. The control box is such a mixed up mass of coils, brushes etc., that we took the thing off complete and shipped it in to the Lister people. Then when it returned our troubles were not at an end. Our voltage would run exceedingly high and our amperage next to nothing. Our re-wiring back from the plant to the control box, from the control box to the generator was O.K., as we had tagged every wire. Other than run any chances of blowing out the brushes, I wired Mumford Medland and they came down this way we would be very glad to have him set the machine in proper order. When he arrived it didn't take him long to detect what was the matter. He stated when the generator is re-wound it also has to be rewound the plant with which it works. This was what was causing our difficulty. It certainly was a job for an expert, as he had to loosen up the brush carrier and hold them in his hand until he got the correct reading on the board.

The generator broke down on the night of Nov. 8th, and we did not have electric light until Dec. 4th. During the intervening time we used four lamps and twelve lanterns. The children were exceptionally good under the trying circumstances, but some of the staff had their first experience of seeing what it was like to work with lamp light. Needless to say, we all appreciated the return to order of our electric light plant.

I am therefore enclosing the invoices for the generator, the control box and the man's time and expenses, together with the necessary prepaid freight accounts.

Very sorry you were not able to stay overnight with us on your last visit to the school; when the winter sets in it means walking one way.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

(Rev.) J. F. J. MARSHALL
Principal

Captain Frank Edwards,
Indian Agent, KENORA, Ont.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6215, file 470-5, part 3)
Ottawa, June 5, 1935.

Sir:

As you were informed in official letter dated April first, last, the following items are provided in our Estimates for the current fiscal year, to carry out certain work at the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School:

New floor in barn and steel fittings for stable - $1,150.
Painting interior of school building - $500.

There is also an item - if the expenditure of same should be absolutely necessary - to supply new batteries for the electric light system.

I have to request that you will consult the principal of the School and forward a report regarding the work and materials required in putting a new floor in the barn and stables and any steel fittings that may be required for the stable. You should also state, in detail, what painting you would recommend be done in the interior of the school building. Please give full information concerning materials required, how they could be had and the work be carried out, what part - if any - could be done by the staff of the school and the outside labour that would be necessary. Any information you can give, regarding the best means of having the work performed and the approximate cost of materials, etc., will be appreciated. Your early reply is requested.

I may add, for your information, that Reverend J.F.J. Marshall, Principal of the School, has been authorized to incur an expenditure to an amount not exceeding $500 in the purchase of a number of purebred Appaloosa young cows in place of some of the old which it was necessary to dispose of, on account of the outbreak of infectious abortion. Mr. Marshall will visit probable sources of supply. However, he has been informed that the Department considers it advisable to have the new floor installed in the barn before the cattle are delivered at the school.

Your obedient servant,

T.R.L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora,
Ont.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6215, file 470-5, part 3)
Dear Sir:

In reference to our conversation over letter No. 129/6/5 dated June 5th, 1935.

Regarding new floor in barn, steel fittings etc. Since our company has been delayed in getting prices for bricks on the material required and I have just received in on last mail prices from Betty Bros. Ltd. who supply the necessary steel fittings for barns. As I noted that the amount asked for in my letter of Oct. 12th, 1934 was $1300.00 and the amount set aside by the Department for this work $1180.00 therefore it was necessary to get new quotations. The lowest price that I can obtain on cement is $1.20 per sack from A.A. McDonald, providing he has a carload lot.

We require 250 bags - $1.20 per bag $300.00
The steel fittings for barn, recent price obtained $682.70.

These two items alone come to $1182.70 which does not allow for any lumber to build the forms or for any labour.

In a former letter regarding the same matter, I stated that we would be willing if the Department supplied the materials, to do the necessary work in putting the barn into good sanitary shape, but I do not feel that the school management should be called upon to supply extra material out of the per capita grant to complete the work. We have already hauled a quantity of stone and gravel, and will continue to haul sufficient quantity of sand so that we may be able, when instructions come to purchase the necessary equipment, to go right ahead with the work. This I have already stated I allow absolutely nothing for engaging an extra man to help mix cement, which will have to be taken out of school funds, as I do not feel that any article we have included in our list should be left out. Should the Department wish us to carry on with the work we will endeavour to keep it within the amount stated, that is $1300.00 allowing $100.00 for lumber, this to cover all necessary equipment and freight charges.

Painting - As the Department have allowed $500.00 for completing the painting of the interior of the school, namely - the five dormitories, two stair sitting rooms, children's dining room, office sitting room, kitchen and laundry. $400.00 of this amount could be placed into material and freight, allowing the $50.00 grant for labour. As you know, our old painter is with us yet but not on any salary. I also wish to draw your attention to the fact that the chapel is not taken into consideration on this as we already have it in hand and are painting it out of the collection box money. For the purpose of this work of painting could be done at different times through the term with a certain amount of assistance rendered the painter by some of the staff members.

New batteries for the electric lighting system - As you no doubt noticed when the engine was shut down the light was very dim. In fact, there is not sufficient current in our batteries at this present time to start the automatic switch on the engine, and the engine when needed has to be started by hand. I have again taken this matter up with R.A. Lister, the firm in Winnipeg who are the manufacturers.
of our present lighting system, and they state in their reply of June 25th, 1935, the following -

"We have consulted Mr. Montgomery in connection with your requirements, and he suggests that we quote you on what is known as -

W-13 Lighting Plant Battery having 13 plates,
with a capacity of 252 amp. hours,
Weight 870 lbs.,
Size of plates 5-1/4" X 7"
PRICE .......................................................... $598.50

I may state there is some refund for the old batteries and jars which would bring the amount down to approximately $565.00. They do not make any set price on the old batteries and jars as it depends on the condition and size of the plates and tops. The Mr. Montgomery referred to is Listers head electrician and expert, whom they sent down here last November to put our lighting plant into shape after we had the dynamo re-wound, so the advice given is the best that can be obtained.

It is needless for me to say that we are ready at all times to co-operate in such work whatever that may be being done around the school plant so as to allow the Department to keep the already reduced funds spread out as far as possible and as you know our own two boys Edward and George are already on the job hauling sand, stone and gravel and will do considerable amount of the cement work on the barn during the holidays under my personal direction, and some little remuneration to them would not come amiss.

We have at the present time two of our men at work erecting a log barn, so as to provide shelter for the milk cows that are on the infected list. After these various animals are disposed of, I consider this building can be used as an implement shed, to put our wagons in in the winter time, and our sleighs in the summer; plows and other farm machinery.

Hoping this will give you the information you require,

Yours faithfully,

Signed John F. J. Marshall,
(Rev) J.F.J. Marshall,
Principal.

Captain Frank Edwards,
Indian Agent,
KENORA, ONTARIO.

Sioux Lookout, Ont.
July 31st, 1935.

Dear Sir:

I was just wondering if there has been any reply from the Department with instructions to go ahead with the barn floor, as the holidays are almost half over and I myself will have to be leaving again to pick up children returning to school. We have gathered up a large amount of sand and gravel and we should get the order through to Beatty Bros., so as to give them time to make up the different things for the staunchions, as a lot of the piping has to be cut to size.

Then if you are writing the Department, our batteries are that low that we have to start the engine by hand and prop up the automatic control as there is not sufficient juice in the batteries to hold it up. I would like these things in before school starts again. I do hope they will let us get the barn completed before the bad weather begins. Then we have considerable crop to harvest and the present time is the slackest time we will have in the next two months. So kindly let us know the circumstances under which we are working if you have any information on the subject at all.

Yours faithfully,

Signed John F. J. Marshall,
(Rev.) J.F.J. Marshall,
Principal,

Captain Frank Edwards,
Indian Agent,

PUBLIC ARCHIVES

ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES

CANADA
September 5, 1936.

MEMORANDUM:

The Honorable the Superintendent General,

The Appropriation for Indian Education for the current fiscal year provides for the following repairs, painting and the supplying of batteries at the Indian Residential School, Sioux Lookout, Ont., Kenora Agency (Electoral District of Port Arthur-Thunder Bay):

New floor in barn and stable fittings - $1,160.
Painting interior, main building - $500.
New batteries for electric lighting system - $200.

R.F. Agent Edwards, Kenora, was requested to consult the Principal regarding the work and to furnish an estimate of the cost. It will require 250 bags of cement, at a cost of $500, for the floor in the stable, and the price of the steel fittings for the stable would be $200. The work in laying the new floor and installing the fittings will be performed by the staff of the school, without expense to the Department. Regarding the painting of the interior of the school, they estimate the paint, oils, etc., required will be $450 and request that the balance of the grant available, viz.: $50, be allowed for extra labour in carrying out the work.

A quotation was received from the R. A. Lister Company, Winnipeg, who are the manufacturers of the present lighting system at the school, for the supplying of the batteries. Their quotation was $585 50, less a refund for the old batteries and jacks which would bring the amount down to approximately, $565.

I would request your authority to incur the above expenditure, and I should be pleased to have the names of the firms who should be asked to quote on the supplying of 250 bags of cement and also the firms who should be requested to quote on the steel fittings for the stable. In this connection, Nearby Brothers Ltd., are the manufacturers of steel stable fittings. The Principal obtained a quotation from this firm, to the amount of $295.

Regarding the painting, please advise the names of the firms from whom prices should be obtained for supplying the materials required.

With reference to the new batteries for the lighting system, would it be satisfactory to place the order with the R. A. Lister Company, Winnipeg, or what other firms should be asked to quote.

Deputy Superintendent General.
Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

Referring to your file 129-6-5 re Estimates for the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School, and my last letter of the 6th ultimo.

I have now received another letter from the Principal of the School in which he asks when he is likely to get authority to go ahead with the work.

He is quite worried as the School assembles today and he does not like to carry on without night lights, he also says "if the work on the cement floor in the barn is not commenced very soon the frost will be coming in and it will be too late for cement work."

He mentions he has written to Ottawa twice and has received no reply, and I may also state I have received no reply to my last letter, would you be kind enough to rush instructions through as soon as possible.

Your obedient servant,

Frank Edwards
Indian Agent.

Ottawa, Sept. 30, 1935.

Sir:

I have to refer to your letter dated July 18th, last, enclosing copy of a communication from the Principal of the Sioux Lockout Indian Residential School, in which he gives an estimate of the cost of the materials required in reflooring the barn and supplying fittings and also in painting the interior of the main building and supplying new batteries for the electric lighting system.

I now have to inform you that the Honourable the Minister has directed as follows:

The offer of the R. A. Lister Company, of Winnipeg, for the supplying of W-13 Lighting Plant battery, having 13 plates, with a capacity of 262 amp. hours, is to be accepted, at the price quoted in their letter of June, last, to the Principal, viz.: $598.50, less a refund for the old batteries and jars, which would bring the amount down to approximately $565.00.

Regarding the purchase of 250 bags of cement, this material may be obtained from Allan A. J. MacDonald, of Sioux Lockout, and the paint and oils required for painting the interior of the school building may be purchased from B. H. Rands, Sioux Lockout.

With reference to the stable fittings, I have to say that, besides the quotation received by the Principal from Beatty Brothers, Limited, Fergus, Ont.,

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

the Minister
The Minister has directed that prices be obtained, also, from the following:

The Gilson Manufacturing Company, Guelph,
The Ontario Wind Engine & Pump Co., Ltd., Toronto,
The Pedlar People, Limited, Oshawa.

Purchase of the fittings should be made from the firm quoting the lowest prices.

Itemized accounts, in triplicate, should be obtained, covering all the above authorized purchases. These, you should attach to proper voucher forms, certify in the usual manner and forward for payment.

It is understood that the work in laying the new floor in the barn and installing the fittings will be performed by the staff of the school, without expense to the Department.

You should arrange with the Principal to have the above work carried out at an early date and have the new batteries purchased and installed. The entire cost of the materials and any outside labour employed should not exceed the amount available for each of the purposes mentioned above, as stated in official letter of June 5th, last.

Your obedient servant,

CANADA
Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter asking for estimates for the year 1936, we are submitting the following, in order as to their greatest need -

1st. **FARM IMPLEMENTS:** $500.00

- One double mouldboard plow
- One hay rake
- One hay mower
- One seed drill No. 16

2nd. **LUMBER:** $500.00

- Fir V joing for putting ceiling in barn
- Plain spruce for repairs to hay loft floor, and for use in root house.

3rd. **SILO**, complete with foundation and other material $617.00

- Steve Silo, 3-J. Fir, complete with iron fittings $429.00
- Cement foundation 45.00
- Material for roof, sheet and scaffolding 68.00
- Foreman, carpenter for erecting same 75.00

4th. **ENSILAGE CUTTER** #7, $364.60

- Ball bearing solid boiler plate steel wheels, complete with trucks and thirty feet of pipe, f.o.b. Pelican.

Regarding Silo and Ensilage Cutter. These items would enable us to save our corn and green feed crop, and make it possible for us to store grain feed for the winter; thereby saving a considerable amount in hay and other feeds. I may say I have gone into this in detail, having both written and interviewed different manufacturers on both these lines. The figures quoted for silo are from the North American Lumber Co., Winnipeg, and are the only people at the present time handling the complete silos and fittings. The prices quoted on ensilage cutter were obtained from Massey-Harris. I also visited the Allis-Chambers and Rumo Limited - Their price is about the same. Other places have been visited but they purchase most of their supply from the United States.

Yours faithfully,

(Sgd) John F. J. Marshall

(Rev.) J. F. J. MARSHALL
Principal

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Dear Sir,

On your recent visit to the school we took up the matter of certain places in the basement halls where it will be necessary to have something on the walls other than plaster as we have plastered in some places three times already and every spring the frost heaves it off. This is in places below the main level. Therefore I would respectfully suggest put in a material like ten test which is painted on both sides should resist the dampness and last considerably than plaster. Would it be possible for us to try out at least about 2000 square feet of ten test. This costs $55.00 a thousand at Sioux Lookout but I believe it might be obtained for about $80.00 a thousand from Winnipeg.

Then on the new building that we have erected to act as an isolation barn. As you noted, we had the log walls up and the rafters all in place but we have no lumber to put on the roof. I may say that the school management have offered the barn up to the present time as a loan whatever to the Department, therefore I do not think it is asking too much to ask them to supply us materials to roof this building with ship lap roofing. The building is a good permanent building, we have built it substantial and set it up on 12x20 fir blocks which we got from the Canadian National when they were repairing the bridge at mileage 4.4.

I have figured on the material only which I count will cost $200.00 landed, freight included. There will be no extra cost for labour. For your information I may say that the building is 24'x20' and stands clear with a 9' wall width and 6' depth. This building will be used as an isolation barn for our cattle in times of sickness and afterwards will give us a place where we can store our various farm implements, as at the present time we have no building whatever to cover these different things. The roofing of this building is very urgent as we would like to get it on before the extremely cold weather.

Hoping the Department may see their way clear to grant us this very important item in our present emergency, I remain,

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]
(Rev.) J. F. J. MARSHALL
Principal

Captain Frank Edwards,
Indian Agent
KENORA, Ontario
Ottawa, November 7, 1935.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 2nd instant, enclosing a communication from the Principal of the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School, in which he requests that a quantity of ten feet be supplied for the basement halls and also that materials be supplied to roof the new building that has been erected for use as an isolation barn.

In reply I have to say the Department will approve an expenditure, not exceeding the sum of $110, in the purchase of approximately 2,000 sq. ft. of ten feet, and also an expenditure not exceeding the sum of $200 in the purchase of the material for the isolation barn. Yourself or the Principal may arrange for the purchase, from the best available source of supply. Please obtain itemized accounts, in triplicate, covering the cost. These accounts, you should attach to proper voucher forms, certify in the usual manner and forward for payment. It is understood that all work will be carried out by the school authorities, without expense to the Department. I would request that the purchase of the above materials be made and accounts forwarded at an early date.

It is hoped that the work in flooring the barn and installing the fittings is now well under way or has been completed.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

The Principal at the Cecilia Jeffrey School called my attention to the condition of the toilets and urinal in the basement. There was a very decided odor from these, which I think could be improved by proper ventilation.

Ottawa, January 17, 1936.

Dear Sir:

I have to refer you to official letters dated September 30th and November 7th, last, authorizing the expenditure required in the carrying out of the following work at the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School:

- New floor in barn and supplying stable fittings,
- New batteries for electric light plant,
- Supplying 250 bags of cement,
- Supplying paint and oils to paint interior of school,
- Supplying quantity ten tons for the basement halls, and also materials to roof the new building that has been erected for use as an isolation barn.

The Department would be pleased to be advised if purchase of the above supplies has been made and if the work in installing the floor in the barn, painting interior, etc., has been completed. If so, itemized accounts, in triplicate, covering the cost of materials, etc., properly certified by yourself, should be forwarded for payment.

It is expected that the accounts covering all expenditure authorized at this school will reach the Department before the end of March, next, when our books for the current year will be closed. In connection therewith, the Principal was authorized to expend $500 in the purchase of purebred Ayrshire young cows. Purchase should be made and accounts forwarded to reach the Department before the time mentioned above, as, after that date, the funds authorized to purchase the cows will lapse.

I would request that you give the above matters your prompt attention.

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.
