Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter of Jan. 21st, 1936, re. inquiry of Department letter #129-6-5 of Jan. 17th, 1936, I will give you information regarding each item as they are all somewhat different.

Regarding the new floor and fittings in the barn, I may say that by the time the authority for these various things reached me and we got in touch with the different firms, we were in the midst of getting in our crops from the fields and garden, and the weather, as you know, was rain three or four days a week. At the time we had between 60 and 70 tons of feed in the loft which made it nearly impossible to tackle the remodelling of the barn with that amount of weight above. We were looking for material for various reasons and came from the different firms that we were to obtain prices from also caused us further delay and no firm carries this equipment in stock as it is all made to order to fit the size of barn.

With these circumstances confronting us, I thought it good policy to take advantage of the offer made by Heatty Bros., that if our order was not in a rush they would include it in a car of their own equipment shipped to Port Arthur, free of charge. The only freight that we would have to pay would be from Port Arthur to Pelican, a distance of 507 miles as against nearly a thousand miles of freight charges.

Then being caught by the wet season, it left us with no place to house our cattle while the work would be going on; and one cannot do a satisfactory job in cement in cold and freezing weather. Also at the time there was a shortage of cement in the market, consequently it would not have been by local freight, which would have cost us nearly $2.00 a bag FOR Pelican. I have the cement order placed with A.A.J. McDonald of Sioux Lookout, for delivery as soon as he can get sufficient to bring in a carload. The steel fittings I expect will be delivered to us sometime about the 10th. of February, as I had word from the firm that their car had been shipped from their factory.

Taking all these unforeseen circumstances into consideration, I judged I was saving money or otherwise, being able to obtain a little more equipment for the money allowed, and also would be able to turn out a better job in the warm weather. I hope this will meet with the approval of the Department.

Paints and oils to paint the interior of the school. This order has been placed with the Brendan-Henderson Co. of Winnipeg and they are holding it over for the next batch of paints that are due to last month. We are doing ahead with a certain amount of cleaning in preparation to painting the walls and ceilings and also patching up little holes and cracks in the plaster, which will, when the extreme cold weather passes, enable us to turn our attention to the work of painting proper, as I deem it useless painting over dirty and greasy walls and...
ceilings. It is some contract, washing the walls and ceilings, scrubbing them with Dutch Cleanser, soap and water and then clean water, but I consider we will be well repaid when we come to paint over a good clean surface. I expect the shipment of paint any day as I had a letter from Bremner-Hamilton January 30th.

The ten test has been ordered from J.H.Ashdown Hardware Co.

The material for roof of isolation barn has been purchased from Geo. E. Farlinger and is now in the barn. We are waiting for the paper and shingles to complete the roof. These are being purchased in Winnipeg. We expect to be able to complete the roof of this barn during Easter holidays. I am using it the present time the chicken house as an isolation barn and will have the other completed before the stock are turned out.

Just in passing and a little aside from the subject in hand yet relative to it; we have passed through a very hard and trying month of January. The flu struck us here immediately after New Year, coming in probably with some of the parents visiting and at one time we had 92 children in bed, besides some members of the staff. It meant long steady duty for those who were able to keep up.

So if it seems that we have been remiss in not replying to any of your correspondence, or getting things done, it is not that we have forgotten, but as you know we have no control over unforeseen circumstances and you will also know that we will try and do our best as the occasions arise.

You can rest assured that I will have the invoices covering the different outstanding accounts in just as soon as I can chase them up.

The one item that bothers me is the cement. It puts us on the horns of a dilemma, as there is practically no cement moving at this present time, although the last I heard from Allan McDonald he was trying to locate enough orders to complete a carload for delivery before the middle of March. I expect to see him this week and I will let you know what is being done in this matter.

Hope this gives you the necessary information in reply to the above mentioned letter.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

(Rev.) J. F. J. MARSHALL
Principal

EX'D.

Inclosed please find a Voucher in favour of Allan J. MacDonald in care of the Reverend J.F.J. Marshall Principal of the Residential School at Sioux Lookout, also letter of explanation from Mr. Marshall.

We are certifying and passing the account, but do not know whether the Department will agree to this arrangement or not.

[Signature]
Indian Agent,

Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.
Dear Sir,

Am enclosing account for cement purchased from Allan McDonald. This cement has been ordered by McDonald coming through in car lot, in fact two cars, but will not be shipped from the cement factory until the opening of navigation. This should bring it in here about the middle of May, which is ample time for use on our job. This enabled Mr. McDonald to quote us a very low figure of $1.05 per sack.

He wishes the cheque to be mailed to you or myself to be held over until delivery of the cement.

It would have cost us $1.40 per sack to have purchased and brought it in all rail. I hope this is satisfactory to the Department as it is the best arrangements that could be made under the circumstances. You will note that the price is F.O.B. Pelican.

Thanking you for your kind consideration in this matter, I am,

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]
(Rev.) J. F. J. MARSHALL
Principal

Captain Frank Edwards,
Indian Agent,
KENORA, Ontario

Encls.
MEMO: MR. RUTHERLAND

Indian Residential School,
Sioux Lookout,

With reference to voucher in the amount of $262.50, which you will find hereunder I wish to advise that payment may not be made until the material, to which reference is made therein, has been actually delivered.

[Signature]

Representative of the Treasury.

ADW/B
Dr. McGill,

With reference to the account in favour of Allan A. J. MacDonald, to the amount of $262.50, for the supply of cement for the floor or barn at the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School, I have been advised that the Treasury Board has refused to pay the account on the grounds that the material has not been actually delivered. You will remember, I discussed the matter with you, and you approved that the account be paid - it being understood that the cheque would be held by the Principal until the cement is delivered.

In September, last, the Minister approved the purchase of the cement from A. A. J. MacDonald, and Mr. Edwards, the Indian Agent at Kenora, was advised accordingly. In connection with the Principal, who issued the voucher, it is stated that the cement has been ordered but that it will be impossible to ship same until opening of navigation. It would have cost $1.40 per sack to have it delivered all rail. In having the cement delivered when navigation opens, in May, next, it was obtained at a price of $1.05 per sack.

I beg to point out that the funds for the purpose are provided in the Appropriation for the fiscal year just closed, and we have no money provided in the Vote for the fiscal year 1936-37 to pay this account.

I can see no reason why the cheque cannot be issued and held by the Principal or at the Department until the cement is actually delivered at the school. I would beg to recommend that you instruct the Representative of the Treasury to have the cheque in payment for the cement issued and either forwarded to be held by the Principal or retained in the Department.

[Signature]

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6215, file 470-5, part 3)
MEMORANDUM

Dr. Macdonald

Ret: Allan A.J. MacDonald account $262.50 for cement.

With reference to Mr. Sutherland's memo, hereunder regarding payment to Allan A.J. MacDonald, of Sioux Lookout, for 250 sacks of cement which have not been delivered, I regret to say that, under the provisions of the Consolidated Revenue and Audit Act, payment may not be made for materials or supplies until the goods have been delivered nor for work until the service has been performed.

Section 30 of the Act reads as follows:

"No payment authorized by Parliament shall be made in respect of work performed or material supplied whether under contract or not, in connection with any part of any public service or Contract, unless there is submitted therewith a report or certificate which is required in that behalf by the deputy minister or other officer charged with the administration of the particular service, certifies that such work has been performed, or such materials supplied, as the case may be, and that the price charged is according to contract, or if not covered by contract, is fair and just."

The account in this instance can not be properly certified that the goods have been received.

I would also refer you to Section 23 of the Act which reads:

"All estimates of expenditures submitted to Parliament shall be for the services coming in course of payment during the fiscal year."

This section is interpreted as follows:

1. To direct that all accounts be liquidated in the year in which Parliament has provided the money;
2. To prohibit payments in advance of delivery or rendering of a service when the charge belongs to a succeeding fiscal year;
3. To bring expenditures for services on a comparable basis.

It
It might also be pointed out that in both Great Britain and the United States payments are not made until goods have been delivered or the services have been rendered. I am sure the reason for taking such a stand is obvious.

This is not a unique case as there are others from time to time where funds are provided for the expenditure in one year's estimates and the goods are ordered before March 31st but not delivered until after April 1st.

The certificates executed by the Principal of the school and the Indian Agent on the account and voucher, respectively, are not in accordance with the facts.

Representative of the Treasury.

ECA/S
Ottawa, April 9, 1936.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 26th ultimo, the Department finds it necessary to return, unpaid, the account of Allan A. J. MacDonald. Owing to present regulations, it is not possible to pay for the cement until it is delivered.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

SIOUX LOOKOUT INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

May 9, 1936.

Captain Frank Edwards,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

I am just taking this opportunity to let you know how we are progressing regarding the painting of the interior. Mr. MacLaughlin is on the job and is now able to give a greater time to the painting than he did. When the winter days were on it required much of his time in the boiler room. We have the Chapel completely done and Mr. Maye is putting in a lettered border which I think that you will approve of the good work being done by him when you are around this way to see it. The two Dormitories on the girls' side are now completed and the little girls' Dormitory we expect to start on in the morning. Some of the staff rooms have been done and when you consider that the ceilings and floors and walls have all to be washed over twice, the floor sometimes often means a big job before a paint brush is put on it. However, we believe in doing the thing properly when the Department have entrusted this work to our care. We are not rushing it but expect that it will take us on into the summer before it is completed.

As regards the work in the barns, we expect to be able to move the cattle from the main barn into the isolation barn about the end of the month and start work on the cleaning out of the wooden floor, removing about a feet deep of the soil before laying the cement floor. This space will be built up out of small stones so as to secure good foundations. The stones, as you know, we hauled last year. We have about doubled the quantity of these this spring, taking a number of them from the lake shore while the water is low.

I will let you know from time to time how the work is progressing, and we are looking forward to your visit at Treaty time.

Don't forget to take lots of warm clothing when you are starting out on the Lake of the Woods Treaty Trip.

I remain,

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]
(Rev.) J. F. J. Marshall,
Principal.

JFJM/GED.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6215, file 470-5, part 3)
SIoux LOOKOUT INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

May 9, 1936.

Captain Frank Edwards,
Indian Agent,
Kensota, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

I just received your letter of May 4th when in town today, seeking information regarding estimates. Owing to the drastic cut in the Department's allowance this year I would judge that they are not going to be able to do very much towards the estimates, therefore I am giving you some idea of the things that I think are most essential to the carrying on of the work at the Sioux Lookout School.

The lumber statement in our estimates of October 16, 1935 which is to complete barn ceiling and root house ceiling. This particular part I think should be put in with fir as the local lumber is not of the very best quality and has tremendous shrinkage and if put in, in a few years would look like so many slats. Then there will be an amount required for repairs to the hay loft floor and reinforcement joists in the hay loft floor, as a number of them have tremendous sag in them as they are placed too far apart. We would require a little extra labour in putting in this ceiling in both buildings as it is too much for the boys to do. Local labour could be procured at about Eighty Dollars. ($80.)

The next items would be some of the farm implements, the hay mower and hay rake and double mouldboard plough, leaving the seed drill to another time as we can still carry on seeding by hand but it is a slow method. Then I would, if it is at all possible to surmise they might have the funds to purchase an ensilage cutter, as I would like to try out a small pit silo to see whether it would work in preference to one of the barrel type, it would save considerable money. The cutter then would be more important than the stave silo. I have gathered considerable information from various sources regarding the use of the pit silo in the northern country and I find that where there is good drainage to be had they have proven a good success. The mud walls can be used it is claimed for a couple of years and then if necessary cement walls can be put in. This would make a very permanent silo and the greatest advantage of all in favour of the pit silo is freedom from frost if carefully covered, therefore I think it would be advisable to give it a try.

Should I be assuming too much the mouldboard plough might be dropped, the other things I think are absolutely essential.
New for reasons in putting forth the request for lumber on the root house. As past winter, as you know, held below forty-five and fifty for almost a month and this played havoc with our roots and potatoes, although we had them covered even better than at other years. Today we took out three wagon loads of potatoes that had been frozen during the winter. This would be avoided if we had the lumber to finish the inside.

Hoping this will give you the information that you required in reference to the letter that you have received from the Department,

I remain,

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

(Rev.) J.F.J. Marshall,
Principal.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6215, file 470-5, part 3)
Ottawa, May 15, 1936.

Reverend Sir:

Mr. Agent Edwards has forwarded communications which he received from you, dated the 9th instant, regarding the lumber, labour, etc., required to complete the barn ceiling; repairs to hayloft floor; reinforcement of joists in hayloft; installing cement floor in barn; also stating the farm machinery required and requesting that a small pit silo be provided, at the Sioux Lookout Residential School.

In this connection I would say that our appropriation for the current fiscal year provides an amount of $625 to erect a silo and $500 to complete barn and root-house. From this amount, however, it will be necessary to deduct the sum of $250.00, the payment for expenses for the barn floor, as this amount was not paid before our books closed for the last fiscal year. In connection with the work yet to be done, as stated above, only the sum of approximately $400 would be available to cover the cost of all items at your school this year. I would request that you furnish us plans and estimates as possible of the lumber and other material required, the cost of any extra labour and also state the type of labour. We would then be in a position to advise Mr. Agent Edwards regarding the purchase of the materials and the employing of the extra labour.

I note that you intend to try out a small pit silo, in preference to one of the barrel type. If so, the building of the pit silo would save considerable expense, leaving funds from the amount available for other purposes.

You might also advise us as to the cost of supplying a hay mower and a hay rake, also an ensilage cutter. It is doubtful, however, if we will have funds to supply all this farm equipment.

It is noted that you are progressing with the painting of the interior of the school building; that the work in painting the chapel, the two dormitories on the girls' side and some staff rooms has been completed; also that you expect to have the cement for the barn flooring delivered at an early date.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Rev. J.F.J. Marshall,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Sioux Lookout, Ont.

Mrs. J. Marshall,—

I wired Ottawa and received authority for what I have done and as soon as we know what is necessary I will wire for further authority. Would you ask Mr. Sivier or Mr. Mayo if they could get someone from Sioux Lookout to estimate what it would cost to get men to do the work so that I can wire Ottawa and get authority.

I could not find a cement mixer in Sioux Lookout, but I am asking Colonel Marmigan to ship a mixer from Winnipeg.

I do not think there is much chance of building a new machine shop outside or putting compression water tanks in the school. If there is anything further you think I can do, don't hesitate to write me or wire. I am very sorry about Mr. Marshall's illness and hope everything comes along well and that he will soon be around.

Yours very sincerely,

Indian Agent.
Kenora, Ontario,
October 1, 1936.

Mrs. J. Marshall,
Indian Residential School
Sioux Lookout, Ontario.

Dear Mrs. Marshall:

As soon as I got to Winnipeg I went to see Mr. Marshall at the General Hospital, but was informed he was in the operating room. I went there again in the afternoon and saw him for a minute or two, but of course could not talk to him very much. He had heard of the fire, but I let him understand it was a very small thing and that nobody was hurt and that you were alright as was everybody else. I also interviewed Colonel Barnigen and also visited Archdeacon Matheson. I arranged with Messrs. Mumford and Medland to send a man to Sioux Lookout that night with an engine and generator. I also arranged with Mr. North of the Canadian National Railway to make sure this was put on the local and taken to Pflug next morning. This engine provides about fifty lights so that you would not be without temporary lights until something can be done. Whilst in Sioux Lookout I also arranged with the Forestry people to leave their pump there so that you could get water. Unfortunately, Mr. Montgomery of Mumford and Medland was out of town and would not be back until the end of this week. Mr. Mumford promised me that when his man returned from the school, he would send me a report as to what was necessary to put the Lister engine into commission and put everything right as regards to machinery. He would also examine the batteries and when we receive this report we will know what to do.

Dr. Westgate returned from Toronto yesterday morning and I saw him and as the doctor at the hospital had told me that Mr. Marshall would be in the hospital for a month longer and that he would not be able to do much work or any work for six weeks after that, Dr. Westgate is I believe, writing Rev. Mr. Sivier at Sioux Lookout to ask him if he would go to the school fairly often and give Mr. Mayo and yourself any assistance he could as the school could not be left without further assistance.
Canadian Pacific Hotels

Your obedient servant,

Frank Edwards
Indian Agent.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6215, file 470-5, part 3)
Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir:

I wired you on Sunday that I had received a telegram from the Sioux Lookout Indian residential school that they had had a fire and that I was leaving to investigate.

I left Kenora Sunday evening and arrived at the school 2:00 a.m. Monday morning and found that the fire had evidently started in the engine room, most likely from the exhaust of the engine. The exhaust pipe has run through the same hole since the school was erected, but for some reason the fire started at that point.

No damage was done to the main parts of the building but the interior of the engine room is badly burned, as are also some of the rafters and joists. I do not know what damage was done to the engines or the batteries. This cannot be ascertained until an expert examines them.

The fire started about 8:00 p.m. on Saturday. A message was sent to Sioux Lookout and the Canadian National Railway sent two coaches and men with equipment to Pelican. The Ontario Forestry also sent a number of men, pumps, etc., but the fire had been extinguished before they got there.

In addition to the damage to the engine room, the fire had travelled between the walls as far as the bake room, and also travelled up inside the walls around the chapel, but had not broken through. The staff managed to extinguish the fire by 9:00
o'clock, although quite a little damage was done by the fire and water and also by the holes which had to be made through the roof and building to get the water to the fire.

After the fire, there was, of course, no water or lights but the Ontario Forestry had left a pump there for a few days so as to take care of the water. I also borrowed a few lanterns and, with the ones they had at the school, they are managing, but with great inconvenience.

I came on to Winnipeg this morning to see the Principal, the Reverend J. Marshall, but found he was in the General Hospital, here, undergoing an operation and of course could not proceed. I called at the English Church Missionary Society and saw Colonel Marmigan but he had no suggestions to make. However, he rang up Archbishop Matheson and I am going to see him this afternoon. Owing to the urgency of the situation I wired you the following telegram:

Secretary of Indian Affairs, Ottawa.

Sioux Lookout school engine room badly burned borrowed pump from forestry for temporary water supply sending tonight expert Lister engine Co. with engine and generator to supply temporary light Principal operated on today Winnipeg hospital and Inspector Hamilton away writing tonight - wire authority Royal Alexandra Hotel.

As I had to make arrangements for light, I trust this meets with your approval. I am getting the engine and generator from Messrs. Munford and Medland, who are the agents for the Lister Motors, which is the engine at present in the school. They are going to find out what is the trouble and give me an estimate of the cost of repairing the engine damaged by the fire. They are also going to let
me know if the batteries are destroyed as the heat was very intense and melted the wax from the top of them and they may be spoilt.

I called to see Inspector Hamilton, but he was out of town and will not be back for some days.

It is difficult to estimate the amount of damage done, but outside of the engine and tools damaged, I imagine about $2,000 would do the necessary repairs. I should be glad if you would wire me authority to do what we think advisable up to about that amount, and when we get a full report as to what the total amount it will take to rebuild and repair, we will let you know.

Luckily, they only have about ninety children in the school at the present time, as many have not returned from vacation.

I would also like to receive authority to purchase refills for the eight 2½ gallon foamite fire extinguishers.

I am staying over in Winnipeg tonight to make sure we get the expert and the engine away tonight to Sioux Lookout, and I have arranged with the Canadian National Railway so that the man and engine can be taken to Pelican tomorrow morning, where they will be met by the school and the engine put into temporary use. I do not imagine the cost of sending the expert, and use of the engine borrowed, will be more than $150.00, but it is difficult to estimate the exact amount.

I would therefore like to receive blank authority for the expenditures suggested above so that the situation can be taken care of. I will write you further as soon as I have any more information.
Canadian Pacific Hotels

Your obedient servant,

Frank Edwards
Indian Agent.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6215, file 470-5, part 3)

October 2, 1936.

Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir:

While on my inspection trip at Sioux Lookout early this week, I found they were unable to work at laying the concrete floor in the barn owing to having no suitable cement mixer. They have borrowed one, but it was not workable and as the cold weather is coming the work had to be completed immediately. As the principal was in the General Hospital in Winnipeg and would not be back for some months I discussed the matter with Colonel Lennagan, of the Indian School Mission and asked him to purchase a cement mixer at the cost of $40.00 f.o.b. Pelican. He is purchasing this from the Eaton Company as they were the cheapest, and is having this shipped to the school. The Department had to supply material and the school undertook the labor. I therefore think this is a legitimate charge against us and should be paid to receive authority for payment of the amount.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.
Ottawa, October 6, 1936.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 2nd instant, informing the Department that it was necessary to supply a cement mixer to carry out the work of laying the concrete floor in the barn at the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School, and that same was supplied at a cost of $40.

The Department will approve of this purchase, and an account, in triplicate, properly certified, should be forwarded, covering the cost.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.
October 6, 1936.

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,

A fire occurred on the evening of the 29th ultimo in the engine room of the Indian Residential School, Sioux Lookout, a government-owned institution, (Electoral District of Fort Arthur-Thunder Bay) Ont., Kenora Indian Agency. Upon being advised, the local Indian Agent immediately proceeded from Kenora to Sioux Lookout, and, in his report, he states as follows:

"The fire started in the engine room, most likely from the exhaust of the engine. The exhaust pipe has run through the same hole since the school was erected, but, for some reason, the fire started at that point. No damage was done to the main parts of the building but the interior of the engine room is badly burned as are also some of the rafters and joists. Considerable damage was done to the engine and the batteries of the lighting system.

"In addition to the damage to the engine room, the fire travelled between the walls as far as the bake room and also travelled up inside the walls around the chapel but had not broken through. The staff managed to extinguish the fire. Considerable damage was done by the fire and water and also by the holes which had to be made through the roof and sides of the building to get the water to the fire.

"As a result of the fire, there was no water or lights in the school. Arrangements were made with

- the local
the local Ontario Forestry Service, who have supplied a pump for a few days, to take care of the water supply. Lanterns have been supplied, and the school is managing, with great inconvenience, in supplying light."

The Agent has arranged with Messrs. Humberd and Redland, agents for the Lister Motors, Winnipeg, for the loan of an engine and generator and also for them to forward an expert to examine the damage to the engine, the batteries of the lighting system and the water pumping equipment.

The Agent states, further, that it is difficult to ascertain the amount of damage, but he estimates it to be approximately $5,000.00, in making the necessary repairs to the lighting and water systems and the building. No blame appears to be attached to the staff of the school in the outbreak of the fire.

As it is necessary that immediate action be taken in restoring the lighting and water systems, the Agent requests that he be given blanket authority to incur an expenditure of, approximately, $5,000.00, in making the necessary repairs. He will arrange for the purchase of materials, from firms on the approved list. In the installing and overhauling of the lighting and water systems, the labour would be carried out by the firms supplying the equipment. The greater part of the other labour in repairs to the building could be performed by the school staff.

I would recommend, for early approval, that Mr. Agent Edwards be granted authority to overhaul the equipment, purchase any new equipment required and undertake the repairs to the building, at a cost of approximately $5,000. Funds for this purpose could be provided from the Appropriation for Indian Education. Unfortunately, the Principal of the School, Rev. J.F.J., Marshall, is in hospital in Winnipeg, where he has undergone a serious operation. Mr. Edwards wishes early instructions, and I would request that he be given the authority to undertake the repairs.

Schools.

Deputy Superintendent General.
MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,

A fire occurred on the evening of the 29th ultimo in the engine room of the Indian Residential School, Sioux Lookout, a government-owned institution, (Electoral District of Fort Arthur-Thunder Bay) Ont., Kenora Indian Agency. Upon being advised, the local Indian Agent immediately proceeded from Kenora to Sioux Lookout, and, in his report, he states as follows:

"The fire started in the engine room, most likely from the exhaust of the engine. The exhaust pipe has run through the same hole since the school was erected, but, for some reason, the fire started at that point. No damage was done to the main parts of the building but the interior of the engine room is badly burned as are also some of the rafters and joists. Considerable damage was done to the engine and the batteries of the lighting system.

In addition to the damage to the engine room, the fire travelled between the walls as far as the bake room and also travelled up inside the walls around the chapel but had not broken through. The staff managed to extinguish the fire. Considerable damage was done by the fire and water and also by the holes which had to be made through the roof and sides of the building to get the water to the fire.

As a result of the fire, there was no water or lights in the school. Arrangements were made with

- the local
the local Ontario Forestry Service, who have supplied a pump for a few days, to take care of the water supply. Lanterns have been supplied, and the school is managing, with great inconvenience, in supplying light."

The Agent has arranged with Messrs. Mumford and Medland, agents for the Lister Motors, Winnipeg, for the loan of an engine and generator and also for them to forward an expert to examine the damage to the engine, the batteries of the lighting system and the water pumping equipment.

The Agent states, further, that it is difficult to ascertain the amount of damage, but he estimates it to be approximately $2,000.00, in making the necessary repairs to the lighting and water systems and the building. No blame appears to be attached to the staff of the school in the outbreak of the fire.

As it is necessary that immediate action be taken in restoring the lighting and water systems, the Agent requests that he be given blanket authority to incur an expenditure of, approximately, $2,000.00, in making the necessary repairs. He will arrange for the purchase of materials, from firms on the approved list. In the installing and overhauling of the lighting and water systems, the labour would be carried out by the firms supplying the equipment. The greater part of the other labour in repairs to the building could be performed by the school staff.

I would recommend, for early approval, that Mr. Agent Edwards be granted authority to overhaul the equipment, purchase any new equipment required and undertake the repairs to the building, at a cost of approximately $2,000. Funds for this purpose could be provided from the Appropriation for Indian Education. Unfortunately, the Principal, of the School, Rev. J.F.J. Marshall, is in hospital in Winnipeg, where he has undergone a serious operation. Mr. Edwards wishes early instructions, and I would request that he be given the authority to undertake the repairs.

Deputy Superintendent General.
OTTAWA, OCTOBER 8, 1936.

FRANK EDWARDS,
Indian Agent,
KENORA, Ont.

Ottawa, October 8, 1936.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 29th ultimo, reporting on the damage occasioned, by fire, to the engine room, equipment and walls at the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School. It is noted that the fire started in the engine room, from the exhaust pipe.

The Department is pleased that, through prompt action of the staff and outside assistance, the building was saved and that there was no loss of life or accidents to the pupils and staff. From the facts stated by you, it would appear that the fire was accidental, although it is considered the engineer or other members of the staff should have noticed the condition of the exhaust pipe leading from the engine.

Regarding your request, that blanket authority be given you, in order that the damage incurred can be repaired and the building placed in good condition, I beg to confirm the following night lettergram to you, of today's date:

"Reference your letter, twenty-ninth, fire damage, engine room and equipment, Sioux Lookout School, may incur expenditure two thousand dollars effecting repairs. When making purchases, Winnipeg; consult Inspector Hamilton regarding firms approved list. Action already taken approved. Have equipment and building placed good condition earliest possible date."

It is noted that you borrowed a pump, for

The Department will leave in your hands the matter of effecting repairs to the plant and building, to a cost not exceeding the sum of $2,000. Oct. 6, 1936.

Captain Frank Edwards,
Kenora, Ontario.

Dear Captain Edwards:

In reply to your letter of Oct. 1st. We were sorry to hear that the improvements and extra engine room that we hoped to have could not be granted. There is nothing left but the next best.

The man from Mumford Medlands came down on Tuesday's train, spent the night at Canon Sevier's and came out on the Local in the morning with engine plant. It was installed at once. There were many cross currents which had to be rectified; therefore there was not much light that night. By Saturday night lights were on from basement to the top floor. The pump from the engine room was also set up so that it was pumping water by Saturday. Mr. Lafreniere is now taking down radiator and doing other necessary things in the old engine room and also going over the old plant, necessary for his report.

Regarding the estimate, Edward went in to see Canon Sevier to get some one for that purpose. I thought Dr. Day might also help the Canon but as he was ill the Canon secured Mr. Wright, a contractor in town who has had most of the building there to do. He came out with the Canon this morning by boat, took his notes and will let you know at once of his estimate.

The man from the Forestry Department has been most faithful in supplying us with water and has been most kind in many other ways.

Now I have come to one of the most important items of this letter, and that is that it is almost impossible to get through the winter with the present tank. Last winter towards the end we had to trust to luck that it or the pipes did not freeze when it was impossible to get into the tank house, with the danger of tons of ice hanging overhead, the ice forming higher every day covered the base of the stove. Every day around the door before one could open it, the ice was hacked away. I think you know all this. It seems the cruellest thing to ask any one to
Captain Edwards con'td. - 2 -

Attend to it. Every year it has been attended to in the summer but with all that there is the same trouble every winter and worse as the years have passed. It took the Forestry pump and the one in the School to fill it both working at the same time before it ever flowed. Lately we have had to pump once or twice daily to keep up the supply, the leakage is so great. The staves are open for about six feet down. It is a fire hazard in a sense and trust that you can get some one to listen before any more trouble befalls us.

On going over the engine room Mr. Lafreniere has suggested that a 13 x 9 x 7 (with a few inches) pressure tank 6000 gals. could be installed at one end of the room. Automatic pumping system. He has wired to Winnipeg to find the cost of such and will add it to this letter before closing. It is not what Mr. Marshall intended to do, but he will not be able to handle what he would like and this seems the next best thing. We thought while the roof is off would be a good opportunity in which to get the tank installed. Mr. Mayo has looked carefully into all this with Mr. Wright and Mr. Lafreniere. The tank and tank house is one if not the greatest chronic sore with which we have to contend. We hope you will be able to get the sanction for this extra while the roof is off the engine room.

Mr. Mayo asks if we will send the requisition for tools and equipment needed to you. We need very shortly the belts for sawing the wood and the belt for sawing odd pieces of lumber on the saw machine.

I was glad to know that you had seen Mr. Marshall and that you were able to set his mind at rest about the School and all here.

We heard from George that the cement mixer has been shipped. The office of the M. S. U. C. sent for him to explain what it really meant.

Since beginning this letter yesterday Dr. Mitchel has been down to see a number of children, 36 in all who have had to go to bed during this last week. We thought it was the result of exposure the night of the fire but it is a good dose of measles. We are now being isolated to some extent from each other.

Thank you very much for all your kindly interest,

Sincerely yours,

[Signature]

P.S. We had not heard yet the price of Water Tank. Hope to be able to wire you that tomorrow. I hope you will push this matter all you can so let us have reply as soon as you can so that we may order.

With further reference to my letter of October 7, re damage done by fire at Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School. I will endeavor to get prices on all of these things and as soon as I have something definite, I will write you further. They seem to have more trouble there as it is reported that they now have measles in the school and thirty-six have had to go to bed during last week.

MUMFORD, MEDLAND, LIMITED,
Winnipeg, Man.
October 8th, 1936.

Captain Edwards,
Indian Agent,
KENORA, ONTARIO.

Dear Sir:

Our service man has now returned from the Sioux Lookout Indian School, and reports that from a superficial examination the plant is not in very good shape.

There was a heavy radiator mounted on the ceiling over the engine, and when this dropped it fell on the flywheel and bent the crankshaft. Also, the magneto is burned and will need a new one.

The generator we cannot tell about without bringing it to Winnipeg for a test, but if it requires to be rewound this may run anywhere from $35.00 to $100.00 according to the number of coils that are defective.

The crankshaft and new bearings which would have to be fitted, also the magneto, would come to $170.00 without labour or freight on the plant backward and forward.

The instruments on the switchboard were not burned, but the glass was broken and they are full of water and are now useless, so that considering the age of the plant a complete overhaul would seem to be doubtful investment, but we will have to leave the decision on this point to you.

We attach hereto a long list of the various small items that will be needed to re-equip the powerhouse when rebuilt, but the only items required in a hurry are the ones for the Fairbanks-Morse pump, and these are only worth a few dollars.
Captain Edwards.

You will notice that they ask for a pressure tank 13 ft. long, 10 ft. high and 8 ft. wide, for 100 lbs. pressure.

There are several things wrong with this from our point of view. As we understand it you now have a wooden tank on a tower which is 67 ft. to the top, but this tank is very old and is leaking very badly, and the idea is that when the new powerhouse is built the pressure tank will replace the elevated tank.

A tank of this shape for 100 lbs. pressure would have to be very heavy indeed to avoid distortion, and would therefore be much too expensive. A round tank 8 ft. in diameter and 13 ft. long would have very nearly the same capacity, and could be provided for very much less money. A 78 ft. tower would only give 30 lbs. pressure at ground level, and as the tank is not close to the building there would be some loss in pipe friction.

We are of the opinion that a circular tank 7 ft. in diameter, 13 ft. long, for 50 lbs. pressure would be ample. This would cost you approximately $800.00, whereas the tank asked for would cost nearly $1,100.00, and should not be necessary at all.

We found that they had been using about 2-1/2 bbls. of gasoline per week and running the plant probably twelve hours per day. A great deal of this is caused by the waste of water from the leaking tank.

We also have a report that the wiring in the building is not at all in good shape, as the extension cords, drop lights and switches have been damaged by the children, and is the cause of the blowing out of a great many fuses.

In the case of the batteries, there are twenty-seven good cells, twenty-eight with the covers broken, and one complete cell broken. This could be taken care of by sending down one new cell and the necessary covers and compound to seal on the new covers.

We have had some talk with the Rev. Mr. Marshall from time to time regarding the installation of a new lighting plant, and we have one in stock of the Fully Automatic Type exactly the same as the one you have, which was included in the stock that we took over from the M.A. Lister Company when we took charge of their Prairie Branches. We did not pay them full value for the stock and therefore could give you a reduced price on this of $950.00.

Yours very truly,

MUMFORD, MEDLAND, LIMITED.
Assistant Deputy & Secretary:

They have temporary lights and water at the school and we are only waiting definite instructions from you as to what we are to do. To put everything in good shape.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6215, file 470-5, part 3)
Kenora, Ontario,
October 9, 1936.

Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your telegram of the 8th, authorizing expenditure up to $2,000.00 effecting repairs at the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School.

I had a long distance telephone call from Winnipeg yesterday morning from Mumford, Medland, Limited, who supplied the original Lister engine to the school. I also spoke to Inspector Hamilton over long distance and went to Winnipeg yesterday afternoon having arranged for Mr. Mumford and Dr. Westgate, Secretary of the Anglican Indian School Mission to meet me that night.

I enclose copy of letter received from Mumford, Medland, Limited, which reports damage done to machinery.

The generator will cost, say $100.00.
The crankshaft and magneto, about $170.00.
The switchboard could be shipped to Winnipeg and a report got as to whether it is worth repairing. A new one would cost about $300.00.

As mentioned in my last letter the school commission wishes to build a new engine room a slight distance away from the school. I presume one about 16' x 25' would answer the purpose. It is hard to get a price on this, but I think it should be able to be built for about $1,000.00 or $1,500.00, providing we do not have to pay too much for the foundations. If this was built, the present engine room could be repaired as per contractor W. E. Wright's estimate for a little over $1,000.00 and can be used for the pressure tank and so do away with the water tower which is in bad shape. The school authorities wanted a square tank so that they could have another engine in the machine shop to drive the laundry machinery, but Mr. Mumford explains that a square tank would cost considerably more than a round tank and would not be as serviceable.
Assistant Deputy & Secretary

He considers a tank costing about $1800.00 which would hold about 3200 Imperial gallons would be large enough.

The School authorities wish to get a Deisel Crude Oil Engine instead of a gasoline engine as at present. This would save the Church authorities a considerable amount on the fuel, but the original cost is pretty high.

In the case of the batteries, it is only necessary to send one new cell down and the necessary covers and compound to seal on the new covers. This would cost in the neighbourhood of $25.00. You will note the school wish to get a Deisel Engine, but the Mumford Company could ship down a new lighting plant for $950.00 second hand, but in excellent condition. A Deisel Engine would cost in the neighbourhood of $2500.00. I would suggest that if we can finance it, we build a new engine room, supply them a Deisel Engine for lighting, and also allow them to keep the engine we shipped down on loan. It would cost about $260.00, but if this cannot be afforded we could send them down the $950.00 lighting plant and also allow them to keep the $250.00 engine. Mr. Mumford also sends the list of tools, belting, etc., required, which has been spoiled by the fire. The cost of this is about $250.00.

I have already ordered the piston Leathers and also the Self-Seating Check Valves for the Fairbanks-Morse as this would only cost about $10.00 or $12.00. I should be glad to know your wishes as soon as possible, so that we can go ahead with the work as Dr. Westgate fully agrees with what we are doing. Of course the cheapest way out of it would be to fix up the old engine room, put in the $950.00 lighting plant, allow them to keep the $250.00 engine and do the necessary repairs asked for, but if they get the new engine house, the Deisel Engine, etc., it would put the school in better shape than it was before.

I also note Mr. Mumford reports that the extension cords, drop lights and switches have been damaged by the children, causing blow outs of a great many fuses. Estimates for the repairs of this would be a little over $200.00. I spoke to Inspector Hamilton over the phone, but he was apparently busy and could not see me last night. However I have a list of Winnipeg firms and the approved list of Mumford, Medland, Limited which must be one of them as Inspector Hamilton is making other purchases from them for other parts of his inspectorate.

INSTRUCTIONS

FRANK EDWARDS
The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Sir:

I have the honour to report that under instructions from the Commission, I visited the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School on Friday the 9th October.

On arrival, I learned that in addition to their other worries measles had broken out and of the forty-six girls in residence forty were affected. Of the boys six of the thirty-eight had contracted the disease. In spite of this Mr. F. A. Mayo, the Acting Principal, and his staff were carrying on the administration of the School in a most efficient manner.

That the building did not become a total loss is due to the mercy of God and the wonderful devotion to duty of the entire staff. The children were all out in three minutes and the fire extinguished by the efforts of the staff before aid arrived. The Canadian National Railways and the Forestry Department at Sioux Lookout were most generous and helpful in placing both men and material at the disposal of the School authorities.

As the entire stock of fire extinguishers was used, may I urge the immediate supplying of a new quantity and also the favourable consideration of the installation of the 6000 gallon compression tank and thorough inspection of the electric wiring.

You will doubtless have received a full report from Captain Edwards, whose assistance and cooperation the Commission
The Secretary,

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Dear Sir:

The Assistant Superintendent, J. P. Kirkpatrick, of the Canadian National Railway, Sioux Lookout, informed me he damaged a suit of clothes at the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School fire. He claims it was an $80.00 suit about two years ago, but was still worth $25.00 and he would like to know if I could pay for this. I wrote and told him if he would submit an account I would send it to Ottawa and request payment, but he says he does not feel like doing this, and as I understand the Canadian National Railways, through his assistance, sent down an engine and caboose with men to fight the fire for which they are not likely to make a charge, so I should be glad if there is any way we could pay for the suit for the superintendent.

Your obedient servant,

Frank Edwards

October 19, 1906.

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,

In further reference to my memorandum of the 8th instant regarding the damage occasioned by fire at the Indian Residential School, Sioux Lookout (Elaboral District of Fort Arthur), Ontario, Canada, Kenora Indian Agency, the Anglican Church authorities, Winnipeg, under whose auspices the school is conducted, and the local Indian Agent have recommended the following:

1. That a new engine room be erected, a slight distance from the school building, in which to install the electric light plant and engine for pumping the water supply.

2. That the old engine room in the main building, where the fire occurred, be repaired and a pressure tank installed for the water supply system.

3. That a new Diesel engine be supplied and the old lighting system, comprising generator, crank shaft, magneto, switch board and wiring, be repaired.

4. That an engine be provided for pumping water supply.

The cost of the above work and equipment would be approximately, as follows:

1. New engine room - $1,500.
2. Repairs, old engine room - $1,000.
3. Supplying pressure tank for water system - $200.
4. Supplying Diesel engine - $2,500.
5. Supplying engine for pumping water - $50.
6. Repairs to lighting plant, consisting of generator, crank shaft, magneto, switch board, etc. - $50.

$6,000.

The present water system, consisting of an elevated water tank, of wooden construction, located behind the school.
school, has deteriorated to such an extent as to be unsafe. It is considered that, by installing a water tank in the old engine room, erecting a new engine room separate from the building; supplying a diesel engine for the lighting system and carrying out the repairs mentioned, the school would be placed in good condition, both as regards lighting and water systems.

The alternative scheme would be to carry out only repairs occasioned by the fire to the building and equipment, which would cost approximately $5,000.

I would recommend that the funds required in erecting the new engine room, including the former engine room and also other work required, to a cost of approximately $3,000, be authorized, to be obtained from the amount provided in the Special Building Programme. I would recommend further, that the funds required in supplying a Diesel engine, water tank, etc., to the amount of approximately $3,000, be provided from the Appropriation for Indian Education for the current fiscal year.

It is urgent that whatever work is authorized should be carried out at the earliest possible moment, as the season is getting late in the north country. I would therefore request your approval for the expenditure mentioned above in carrying out the building work for a new engine room, repairing the old engine room damaged by fire and supplying the equipment for the lighting and water systems.

Mr. Agent Edwards, who was first given blanket authority to incur an expenditure of $2,000 to carry out repairs only, obtained a quotation of $1,000 from R. H. Wright & Co., general contractors, Sioux Lookout, for repairing the engine room.

I would recommend, for approval, that Mr. Agent Edwards be granted authority to arrange for the work in erecting a new building, to be used for engine room and power purposes, and to purchase a water tank and Diesel engine and carry out other repairs required. He could purchase all equipment from firms on the approved list in Winnipeg, the nearest source of supply.

In view of the necessity of having all work at the school completed before the extreme cold weather sets in, your direction is requested at an early date.

Deputy Superintendent General.

CANADA
MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,

In further reference to my memorandum of the 6th instant, regarding the damage occasioned by fire at the Indian Residential School, Sioux Lookout (Electoral District of Fort Arthur-Thunder Bay) Ont., Kenora Indian Agency, the Anglican Church authorities, Winnipeg, under whose auspices the school is conducted, and the local Indian Agent have recommended the following:

1. That a new engine room be erected, a slight distance from the school building, in which to install the electric light plant and engine for pumping the water supply.

2. That the old engine room in the main building, where the fire occurred, be repaired and a pressure tank installed for the water supply system.

3. That a new Diesel engine be supplied and the old lighting system, comprising generator, crank shaft, magneto, switch board and wiring, be repaired.

4. That an engine be provided for pumping water supply.

The cost of the above work and equipment would be, approximately, as follows:

1. New engine room - $1,500.
2. Repairs, old engine room - $1,050.
3. Supplying pressure tank for water system - $800.
4. Supplying Diesel engine - $2,500.
5. Supplying engine for pumping water - $250.
6. Repairs to lighting plant, consisting of generator, crank shaft, magneto, switch board, etc. - $850.

$6,950.

The present water system, consisting of an elevated water tank, of wooden construction, located behind the school.
school, has deteriorated to such an extent as to be unsafe. It is considered that, by installing a water tank in the old engine room, erecting a new engine room separate from the building, supplying a Diesel engine for the lighting system and carrying out the repairs mentioned, the school would be placed in good condition, both as regards lighting and water systems.

The alternative scheme would be to carry out only repairs occasioned by the fire to the building and equipment, which would cost approximately $2,500.

I would recommend that the funds required in erecting the new engine room, repairing the former engine room and also other repairs required, to a cost of approximately $3,800, be authorized, to be obtained from the amount provided in the Special Building Program. I would request further that the funds required in supplying a Diesel engine, water tank, etc., to the amount of approximately $3,000, be provided from the Appropriation for Indian Education for the current fiscal year.

It is urgent that whatever work is authorized should be carried out at the earliest possible moment, as the season is getting late in the north country. I would therefore request your approval for the expenditure required, as mentioned above, in carrying out the building work for a new engine room, repairing the old engine room damaged by fire and supplying the equipment for the lighting and water systems.

Mr. Agent Edwards, who was first given blanket authority to incur an expenditure of $2,000 to carry out repairs only, obtained a quotation of $1,029 from R. E. Wright & Co., general contractors, Sioux Lookout, for repairing the engine room.

I would recommend, for approval, that Mr. Agent Edwards be granted authority to arrange for the work in erecting a new building, to be used for engine rooms and power purposes, including a water tank and Diesel engine, and carry out other repairs required. He could purchase all equipment from firms on the approved list in Winnipeg, the nearest source of supply.

In view of the necessity of having all work at the school completed before the extreme cold weather sets in, your direction is requested at an early date.

MEMORANDUM

Ottawa, October 26th, 1936.

DR. H. MCGILL:

I am returning herewith your memorandum of the 19th instant regarding a proposal to have certain work done on the Indian Residential School at Sioux Lookout. The Minister has read your memorandum and has approved of the alternative scheme; that is, to carry out only repairs occasioned by the fire to the building and equipment, which would cost approximately $2,500.00.

When considering your proposal the Minister asked if it would be possible for the Department to purchase their electrical energy instead of generating it, as apparently you are doing at the present time. You might let me have a report on this suggestion.

W.J.F. Pratt,
Private Secretary.

OTTAWA, OCTOBER 27, 1936.

FRANK EDWARDS,

REFERENCE YOUR LETTER NINTH INSTANT CARRY OUT REPAIRS ONLY OCCASIONED BY FIRE TO ENGINE ROOM AND EQUIPMENT SIOUX LOCKOUT SCHOOL COST NOT EXCEEDING TWENTY-FIVE HUNDRED DOLLARS -STOP- NO FUNDS TO ERECT NEW ENGINE ROOM SUPPLY DIESEL ENGINE AND INSTALL WATER TANK OLD ENGINE ROOM.

A. F. MACKENZIE.
Ottawa, October 27, 1936.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 9th instant, relative to the work required in repairing the damage occasioned by fire in the engine room at the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School.

In this connection I beg to confirm the following night telegram to you of today's date:

"Reference your letter, ninth instant, carry out repairs only occasioned by fire to engine room and equipment, Sioux Lookout School - cost not exceeding twenty-five hundred dollars. No funds to erect new engine room, supply Diesel engine and install water tank; old engine room."

The Department will have no funds to erect a new engine room, to supply a tank for the water system or a Diesel crude oil engine or to install a water tank in the old engine room.

The repairs to the old engine room and equipment and other repairs required will be left in your hands, to have the work carried out in a satisfactory manner and at the least possible expense. As stated in our telegram, the entire cost should be kept within the sum of; approximately, $2500. It is noted that you have obtained a quotation for the repairs required to the engine room.

You may arrange with Mumford-Redland, Limited,

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6215, file 470-5, part 3)
for carrying out the repairs to the electric light equipment and supplying a new switch board if it is found the old switch board is not worth repairing. You will be aware of the best arrangements to make with the firm mentioned, in placing the electric light system in a satisfactory condition.

You should obtain itemized accounts, in triplicate, covering all expenditure. These accounts, you should attach to proper voucher forms, certify in the usual manner and forward for payment.

I would request that you give the matter of the repairs required to building and equipment your early attention.

If you have sufficient funds, after carrying out the repairs, you may arrange to supply any fire extinguishers that may be required for the school or inform the Department of the number and size required, when the order could be placed here. We usually supply Pyrene extinguishers in 1½ quart and 2 gallon sizes.

You might inform the Department if the Principal undertook any work in connection with the completion of the barn and root-house or in the erection of a silo. If so, properly certified accounts, in triplicate, should be forwarded, covering the cost.

Yours Truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.
